Len Meyer, pictured above with their dog Tucker, knows what it’s like to fight a health insurance company for coverage. Meyer, who is nonbinary and transgender, spent more than six months battling an insurance company to cover a double mastectomy. The company claimed the procedure wasn’t medically necessary, and denied it three times before the insurer agreed to cover it in 2015, Meyer said. ⠀
⠀
“It was really frustrating,” said Meyer, 47, of Bloomington. “For me to feel like I was my true, authentic self, having that surgery really made a change for me.” ⠀
⠀
More transgender individuals may find themselves confronting similar obstacles to care if the Trump administration finalizes a proposal to roll back a regulation of the Affordable Care Act that prohibits discrimination in health care based on gender identity. ⠀
⠀
That Obama-era regulation, which went into effect in 2016, applies to health care providers who receive federal funds, which most do. Federal rules also prohibit discrimination based on gender identity in health insurance, but the proposed changes would undo those rules as well. A federal court has temporarily put enforcement of the regulation on hold, but the Trump administration wants to go even further, doing away with the rules entirely. Click the link in our bio for the full story. (Zbigniew Bzdak / Chicago Tribune | @bzdak)

The Cook County Forest Preserve District maintains 586 hand-operated water pumps. Only one has a posted limit on use. Only one is ever backed up with lines on the weekend. Only one is rumored to come from a mysterious, special source that makes it the best water there is. ⠀
⠀
It is slick with grease and clacks and groans. There is no sign directing you to it. And yet a steady, purposeful trickle of pilgrims stops in a Schiller Woods parking lot all day nearly every day to fill their jugs with Chicago’s own “holy water.” ⠀
⠀
Tom Rohner, the preserve’s director of facilities, said it’s simply well water, that it comes from an aquifer 85 feet below the surface, that it’s not treated, that it’s not a natural spring, and that it’s tested quarterly. ⠀
⠀
”I don’t know if this water is magic or healthy or not,” said Elizabeth Osika, at 70, as she filled multiple jugs. “But the water that flowed out of mountains in Poland tasted like this, and I have been drinking this water for 20 years now and I am not dead.” ⠀
⠀
As for that identical, neglected pump directly across the street? It pulls from the very same well. Click the link in our bio for the full story. (Camille Fine / Chicago Tribune | @camillefine)

The Bears must travel nearly 4,000 miles to return to Chicago after Sunday’s 24-21 loss to the Raiders at London’s Tottenham Hotspur Stadium. ⠀
⠀
It’s going to be a long flight back on Monday. ⠀
⠀
The Bears came back from a 17-point halftime deficit to take a lead — only to lose it with less than two minutes to play when Raiders running back Josh Jacobs scored on a 2-yard touchdown run, pictured in photo 1. ⠀
⠀
Bears quarterback Chase Daniel, filling in for injured Mitch Trubisky, threw an interception to Raiders cornerback Gareon Conley at the Raiders’ 23-yard line on what could have been a winning drive. The Bears head into a week off with a 3-2 record. Click the link in our bio for full @chicagobears coverage, and follow @chitribsports for more. (Brian Cassella and Chris Sweda / Chicago Tribune | @briancassella) #CHIvsOAK

Miguel Perez Jr. has now gone from U.S. soldier to convicted felon to deportee to U.S. citizen. ⠀
⠀
Raised in Chicago, Perez joined the Army before 9/11 and served with a Special Forces unit in Afghanistan before receiving a general discharge in 2004. But in 2008 Perez was arrested after handing a laptop case containing cocaine to an undercover police officer, and served a 7 1/2-year prison sentence. ⠀
⠀
Perez mistakenly believed serving in the military granted him citizenship, but learned that was not the case shortly before he was released from prison in September 2016. He fought to stay in the U.S for more than a year, but was deported without warning in 2018. Then Perez received a lifeline in August when Gov. J.B. Pritzker granted him clemency for the drug conviction, opening the door for him to return to Chicago. ⠀
⠀
After reciting his oath of citizenship Friday, he turned to the American flag on his left and gave a salute. Click the link in our bio for the full story. (Abel Uribe / Chicago Tribune)

In 2016, Pamela Robinson, pictured in photo 3, found herself at a Memorial Day barbecue, bringing out the old clothesline she occasionally used to jump double Dutch. She was transported back to simpler times, when she and her friends would jump all day, every day, until the street lights came on. ⠀
⠀
Three years later, that moment has blossomed into the 40+ Double Dutch Club, with more than 5,300 members nationwide. Chicago-area members, including an optician, a CPA, a stay-at-home mom and an 81-year-old jumper, come for nostalgia, for fun, for fitness and for camaraderie. ⠀
⠀
“The nostalgia is very attractive for adult women, and the subversive fitness aspect of it, where it seems really fun and it’s not till you get in the rope that you realize, ‘Oh my God, I’m really working out here,’” said Ayana Haaruun, president of Black Girls Jump, a Bronzeville organization with classes for kids, meetups for adults and competitive teams. ⠀
⠀
Click the link in our bio for the full story. (John J. Kim / Chicago Tribune | @johnkimpictures)

Ali Baker, a server at Dos Urban Cantina in the Logan Square neighborhood, feels lucky to work where she does. Her boss is kind, the restaurant is well regarded, and tips can be very good. ⠀
⠀
But on slow weeks, or when customers aren’t feeling so generous, Baker gets nervous. Like most restaurant servers across Chicago, Baker earns a base hourly wage of $6.40 an hour and relies on tips for the bulk of her income. Fluctuating paychecks can make it tough to pay bills. ⠀
⠀
A proposed ordinance being considered by Chicago aldermen aims to tackle the unpredictability of the tipping system by eliminating the subminimum wage that allows employers to count workers’ gratuities toward their base pay. ⠀
⠀
Under the proposal, employers who now pay tipped workers as little as $6.40 an hour would have to pay them the regular minimum wage — which in Chicago is currently $13 an hour — a change that would drastically increase their labor costs and upend the business model of restaurants across the city. Click the link in our bio for the full story. (Chris Sweda / Chicago Tribune)

Nothing changed but the name when the Indiana Dunes became the country’s newest national park. There was no extra money, just the word “park” replacing “lakeshore” on a cardboard sign. ⠀
⠀
But, just as those who fought for a century to win the dunes the elite designation likely imagined, the name changed the park. For those who frequent the Indiana Dunes, the national park designation has shown itself in different ways — an uptick in visitors, busier trails, the need to order more custodial supplies. ⠀
⠀
“Now it’s a national park, and so it must be spectacular, right?” said park superintendent Paul Labovitz. “Well, it’s always been spectacular, but the name seems to resonate. And frankly, we’ll take it.” ⠀
⠀
Chicago Tribune photojournalist Zbigniew Bzdak spent the end of August documenting the park from the air. His photos show the diversity of the landscape — from sandy dunes to beaches, bogs and wooded forests. Click the link in our bio to see them all. (Zbigniew Bzdak / Chicago Tribune | @bzdak)

Four consecutive playoff appearances and managing the Cubs to their first World Series championship in more than a century wasn’t enough for Joe Maddon to retain his job. ⠀
⠀
The @cubs announced today that they severed ties with Maddon, 65, as his contract expired after five seasons. ⠀
⠀
Maddon never had a losing season with the Cubs and guided them to the 2016 title, their first since 1908. They made the playoffs from 2015-18 — the four straight berths a franchise first — but in 2018 failed to advance to the National League Championship Series for the first time under his watch. Click the link in our bio for the full story, and follow @chitribsports for more. (John J. Kim / Chicago Tribune | @johnkimpictures) #chicagocubs

Four years ago Brad Ryan and his grandmother took a road trip to the smoky mountains for a mental reset. What started as one trip, turned into six. Now Brad and 89-year-old Grandma Joy are on a mission to visit all 61 of America’s national parks. ⠀
⠀
“Sure, I get tired sometimes, but what’s the alternative? Stay home? I don’t think so,” she said. ⠀
⠀
The duo have become internet sensations with thousands of followers on Instagram and several national news spots under their belts. The Ryans finished seeing their 31st park this week when they visited the country’s newest: Indiana Dunes National Park. The stop meant Grandma Joy got to visit Chicago for the first time, including a tour of Wrigley Field. ⠀
⠀
“I couldn’t believe all these people live in these great big buildings — millions of them,” she said. “It looked like Christmas time.” ⠀
⠀
We sat down for a Q&A with Grandma Joy to hear about everything from life lessons to that time they got caught in the middle of a bison herd. Click the link in our bio to read. (Armando L. Sanchez / Chicago Tribune | @mandophotos) #grandmajoysroadtrip #findyourpark

Young people are going into debt for school, homes, businesses and yes, their four-legged children. ⠀
⠀
A recent report found that approximately 42% of the millennials surveyed have been in pet-related debt. Nearly 1 in 10 are currently paying it off. Katie Reynolds, a 36-year-old dog mom to three special needs Pomeranians — Rachel, Oliver and Parker — says CareCredit and pet insurance have been “so helpful” for her and her husband financially. ⠀
⠀
“When Oliver was 14 months, he got into Parker’s medication and overdosed,” she recalled. “He spent almost two weeks in ICU, and insurance paid 90% back on that. We rely a lot on insurance.” ⠀
⠀
Reynolds is not alone in purchasing health insurance for her dogs. More millennials have pet insurance than Gen Xers and baby boomers, according to the survey, which found that a credit card was the most common form of payment for emergency pet expenses. ⠀
⠀
“Everything we do is based on what our dogs need,” Reynolds said. “Our dogs are our children. We love and respect them as beings, and think they deserve the best we can give them.” ⠀
⠀
Click the link in our bio for the full story. (Stacey Wescott / Chicago Tribune | @staceywescott27)

In the moments after Angela Bougher gave birth, she and her husband, a suburban Chicago pastor, were eager to hold their new baby girl, Glori, now 1. ⠀
⠀
But as Bougher was being treated in the delivery room, the couple contends, a nurse picked up the infant to administer a vitamin K shot, a common practice in maternity wards across the country to help a baby’s blood-clotting ability in case of emergency. The Boughers said they are not “anti-vaxxers” or against any procedure they believe to be medically necessary, but they don’t think the shot was in that category. ⠀
⠀
The Boughers allege that instead of offering the parents a waiver confirming they denied the shot, the nurse announced she was reporting the couple to the Illinois Department of Children and Family Services and left the room with the newborn. It would be about 12 hours before they got the child back. ⠀
⠀
The incident was the result of a controversial DCFS policy that classified parents’ refusal of their newborn’s vitamin K shot as medical neglect. The policy was rescinded a year ago as agency leaders determined the shots should not be classified as medically necessary. ⠀
⠀
On Monday, the Boughers and several other parents filed a sweeping federal lawsuit accusing the agency, its current and former leaders, a number of doctors and three hospitals of violating their constitutional rights following the births of their children. ⠀
⠀
Click the link in our bio for the full story. (Antonio Perez / Chicago Tribune | @apereztribune)

The Chicago Teachers Union brought some celebrity backing to its push for a new contract Tuesday evening, with actor John Cusack rallying with teachers before the evening’s headliner — Democratic presidential candidate Bernie Sanders — called for big raises for local public school educators. ⠀
⠀
When the Vermont senator later took the stage, he thanked the teachers union for “becoming the conscience of the United States of America.” ⠀
⠀
“What we are seeing is teachers standing up and fighting for justice,” Sanders said. ⠀
⠀
Sanders underscored some of the CTU’s specific demands, calling on the city to “negotiate a contract that substantially reduces class sizes” and to “substantially increase the pay and benefits for the teachers in Chicago and the support staff in Chicago,” as well as address the shortages of nurses and librarians. Click the link in our bio for the full story. (Armando L. Sanchez / Chicago Tribune | @mandophotos)

Brookfield Zoo’s newest residents flew in from California on a FedEx cargo plane to O’Hare International Airport last week. ⠀
⠀
Carolyn and Sabiena, two sea lions, were rescued in California and deemed unreleasable due to health conditions. The sea lions, both around 2 years old, are settling into their new home, said Rita Stacey, curator of marine mammals at the Chicago Zoological Society. ⠀
⠀
Sabiena, who is pictured above getting a check-up, was rescued in May 2018 at Westward Beach in Malibu, California. Carolyn was rescued last November, about 90 miles south of where Sabiena was found, near Dana Point Harbor. ⠀
⠀
Wildlife officials from the National Marine Fisheries Service determined that the sea lions would not survive on their own in the wild. When a call for a forever home was sounded, Brookfield Zoo answered. Click the link in our bio for the full story. (Antonio Perez / Chicago Tribune | @apereztribune)

Jim Steffen, the Mothman of Glencoe, believes that he can help restore McDonald Woods to something like pre-settlement Illinois. And he believes that its moths, one of nature’s least appreciated pollinators, could be the key. ⠀
⠀
So Steffen is conducting a census. ⠀
⠀
For the past few years, he’s been gathering as much information as he can on what species exist in these compact 100 acres of Glencoe. He takes his traps out every week or so, from about the first thaw of spring to the first snow of winter. He would do it more often but he’s coming across new species every two weeks, and he doesn’t want to stress out the moths or do any more damage to the population than his intrusions have already done. ⠀
⠀
That said, if you are a moth, and live in McDonald Woods, Jim Steffen has your number. He’s currently at No. 596. Meaning, he’s identified 596 species of moth here, with at least 50 more waiting to be ID’d and cataloged. Click the link in our bio for the full story. (E. Jason Wambsgans / Chicago Tribune | @ejwamb)

Michael ”Mikey” Fernandez drowned last month after jumping into the Lincoln Park South Lagoon to rescue his 1-year-old husky Sora, pictured here with his mother Katherine Fernandez-Palacios in Evanston. ⠀
⠀
On Aug. 24, Fernandez met his girlfriend Ashley along the lake before heading to their favorite ramen restaurant. While walking to the beach, Fernandez let Sora off his leash. Full of energy, he chased a goose into the lagoon. Fernandez worried Sora would swim across to Lake Shore Drive and get hit by a car, so he jumped in after him. Hours later divers would recover the 29 year old’s body from the murky water. ⠀
⠀
Fernandez’s family wants to find some way to promote safety and awareness at lagoons in his honor. They plan to collect money to fix flags, put in more signs and install flotation devices to rescue swimmers. ⠀
⠀
“I don’t want what happened to be in vain,” his mother said. Click the link in our bio for the full story. (Chris Sweda / Chicago Tribune)

Thousands of students and activists gathered Friday in Grant Park and marched to Federal Plaza in the Loop to call attention to issues related to climate change, joining protests held around the world. ⠀
⠀
Police estimated between 1,500 and 3,000 people marched through downtown. Chicago high school students were excused for the rally but only if they returned after the event ended. ⠀
⠀
As marchers left Grant Park and approached Federal Plaza, their voices began echoing off the buildings lining the streets, and they chanted louder: “Oceans are rising, and so are we.” ⠀
⠀
Click the link in our bio for more photos and the full story from today’s march. (Antonio Perez / Chicago Tribune | @apereztribune) #globalwarming #climatechange #climatestrike

If you’ve already unpacked your scarves in hopes of the perfect day of fall fun at the apple orchard, we’ve got some bad news. ⠀
⠀
Bitter winter temperatures, drenching spring rains and hailstorms have battered Chicago-area orchards, forcing many to open late or not at all, while others might run out before the end of the picking season. ⠀
⠀
“This is my 20th year and this is the first we won’t have October apples to sell,” said Donald Burda (photo 3), owner of Homestead Orchard in Woodstock. Burda counts himself among the lucky ones who have a late summer crop, but several nearby U-Pick orchards were so badly affected by the elements that they opted to close outright. ⠀
⠀
Many farmers are advising customers to check availability before venturing out. Click the link in our bio for the full story. (Stacey Wescott / Chicago Tribune | @staceywescott27)

Griffin Kubik spent two years at Chicago Waldorf preschool before his parents pulled the plug on his formal education. The 6-year-old now spends his days traveling with his parents and 2-year-old sister in their newly purchased van. ⠀
⠀
“For our family, the experience of learning while traveling outweighs the benefits of going to school,” said Griffin’s mom, Tiana Kubik, co-owner of TK Photography, which is based in Chicago. The family’s trips often include stops in Toronto, Montreal, Banff and Jasper, Canada. ⠀
⠀
“School isn’t a one-size-fits-all approach,” said Stephen Spriggs, managing director of William Clarence Education, a London-based education consultancy that works with families around the world. Even some traditional teachers are home-schooling their children. ⠀
⠀
Griffin is just one of about 3.5 million home-schooled children in America. The number of kids who are home-schooled has surpassed children at charter schools and has been growing by 3 to 8 percent each year since 2012. Click the link in our bio for the full story. (Brian Cassella / Chicago Tribune | @briancassella)

As a train rattled into the Healy Metra station, dozens of people gathered underneath the viaduct to see a new mural honoring a historic combat unit. ⠀
⠀
The mural was designed to commemorate the service of the Borinqueneers, the 65th Infantry Regiment, a Puerto Rican Army infantry regiment that participated in World War I, World War II and the Korean War. At the center of the mural is a gold medallion paying homage to the unit. ⠀
⠀
Several members of the Borinqueneers were present Tuesday morning to see the mural unveiled at the stop on the border between the Hermosa and Belmont Gardens neighborhoods. ⠀
⠀
Ramon Rodriguez, a 91-year-old Borinqueneer who is pictured in photo TK, served in the Korean War. He said he was proud to see the unit receive the recognition they fought so valiantly for. ⠀
⠀
“We fought in three wars,” Rodriguez said. “This is a great nation … we gave everything for it.” Click the link in our bio for the full story. (Camille Fine / Chicago Tribune | @camillefine)

Diversity on college campuses long has meant differences among races, ethnicity and religions. In recent years, college leaders are ramping up efforts to recruit a mix of students from urban, suburban and rural areas. But they’ve learned rural students face unique challenges in the college-going process, many revolving around a common theme: access. ⠀
⠀
“We saw that rural students — they are smart, they are talented — are really inhibited by their geography and they’re severely underrepresented on college campuses,” said Marjorie Betley, senior associate director of admissions and director of the rural program at University of Chicago. ⠀
⠀
@uchicago’s outreach has been eye-opening for Grace Coppinger of Beaufort, Missouri, who is pictured sitting on a bluff overlooking the Bourbeuse River in a park in Union, Missouri. The 17-year-old is interested in coastal ecology and marine science, and wants a school near the water. ⠀
⠀
“Colleges need to understand more about rural areas — they are kind of in a bubble,” Coppinger said. “I went to UChicago and it was like being thrown into a big ocean of people and being told, ‘Good luck.’ And that’s exactly what I needed. It definitely showed me what I want in a college.” Click the link in our bio for the full story. (E. Jason Wambsgans / Chicago Tribune | @ejwamb)

Lying back in a chair with her head in a hair-washing sink, Jeanette Saribekian, pictured in the second photo, chatted with the stylist massaging shampoo into her scalp about how she usually goes to the salon with one of her daughters. ⠀
⠀
It’s small talk in a small salon, tucked away in an unexpected place where many crave the normalcy and the pampering of a haircut, wash and style. Saribekian’s recent appointment was at the salon inside Lurie Children’s Hospital. The cut was a much-needed break for the 33-year-old mom of three, whose youngest daughter, Wilhelmina, remains in Lurie’s NICU two months after her birth. ⠀
⠀
“It really means so much to be able to do something normal,” Saribekian said before asking volunteer stylist Eli Winters, pictured in the first photo with Lurie patient Isabella Murphy, to trim up her brunette layers, growing toward her shoulders. ⠀
⠀
Winters, who works at Vandross Hair Design in Lincoln Park, volunteers her time one day a week to work in the salon for appointments and walk-ins. And for patients who cannot leave their beds, Winters will travel to their room for bedside cuts. ⠀
⠀
“It’s great giving back, and I get to use my craft,” she said. “A haircut is a little boost of confidence. You should feel like yourself again.” ⠀
⠀
The salon is in the hospital’s Family Life Center, which offers activities for patients and families, including a teen lounge. Click the link in our bio for the full story. (Antonio Perez / Chicago Tribune | @apereztribune)

A person stands in the moonlight as the Harvest Moon rises east of the Northwestern University campus in Evanston on Friday. ⠀
⠀
According to NASA, the moon will officially be its fullest at 11:33 p.m. Friday, and will appear full in the sky through Sunday morning. The last time a full moon fell on a Friday the 13th was nearly two decades ago, on Oct. 13, 2000, and isn’t predicted to happen again until Aug. 13, 2049. ⠀
⠀
Click the link in our bio for the full story. (John J. Kim / Chicago Tribune | @johnkimpictures) #harvestmoon #fridaythe13th

Friday nights may look a little different in some communities, as high school football participation in Illinois has dipped below 40,000 players for the first time since 1993. ⠀
⠀
From a peak of 51,334 players in 2007, last year the state saw only 38,366 teens go out for the sport, a 25% drop. Coaches told the Tribune several factors are driving the decline, including the trend of children specializing in a single sport. But the continuing fear of head injuries remains the biggest reason. ⠀
⠀
“These are really smart kids,” said Lane Tech coach Tony Faltin. “When you start talking concussions and permanent brain damage, you see some of these parents saying, ‘Eh, I don’t know if I want Johnny to play football.’” ⠀
⠀
Lane Tech is cutting against the participation trend, though, with 95 kids on the varsity and JV teams — 15 more than the school has averaged in recent years. Faltin attributes the gains to vigorous recruiting, a $50,000 investment in top-of-the-line helmets and the sideline presence of the concussion specialist. ⠀
⠀
But not every program has been so fortunate. Click the link in our bio for the full story. (Antonio Perez / Chicago Tribune | @apereztribune) #football #fridaynightlights

Mike Baumann, 32, often feels out of place around other students in his business classes. But his perspective differs not just because of his age — he’s a veteran. ⠀
⠀
Baumann served in the Army for six years, a year of it in Iraq as a combat medic. Now married and living in Chicago, he attends DePaul University and balances a part-time job at the school’s veterans services office, as well as a job as a Lyft driver. ⠀
⠀
According to the U.S. Department of Veterans Affairs, more than 780,000 veterans used their GI Bill benefit to attend school in fiscal year 2018. More than 21,000 of them were at Illinois schools. UIC student Amy Huerta, 23, joined the Navy after high school and worked as an aviation structural mechanic for four years. She plans to become a dentist. ⠀
⠀
“Going into the military helped me grow and gave me confidence,” she said. “I feel like I’ve benefited from it so much. I know myself better, know what I want to do, what I want out of life.” ⠀
⠀
Still, the transition wasn’t easy, she said. “It is a culture shock when you get out.” Click the link in our bio to read the full story. (Camille Fine / Chicago Tribune | @camillefine) #veterans #veteransupport #studentveterans

Mandi Grammer, pictured in photo 5, was already terrified when admitted in March to Logan Correctional Center. Then during intake, a routine test revealed a shock: The inmate was unexpectedly pregnant with her third child, who would continue to grow in her womb as she began serving a three-year sentence for retail theft. The news spurred a flurry of additional worries for the 34-year-old from Carterville, Illinois. ⠀
⠀
Yet some of these anxieties were quelled after Grammer was assigned to a new pregnancy wing at Logan, which is about three hours southwest of Chicago. The special housing unit opened in February with the mission of providing a safer and more humane environment for pregnant and postpartum inmates, said acting Warden Beatrice Calhoun. ⠀
⠀
Offenders have their own rooms and can move about the wing freely. More comfortable bedding and large maternity pillows are permitted. The staff says the women have unlimited access to telephones, as well as video phones, to call their baby’s caretaker or other children. A refrigerator full of donated healthy snacks is available at all times. Classes and nutrition are tailored for mothers-to-be and their offspring, and pregnancy education classes are mandatory. ⠀
⠀
The new wing at Logan is part of a larger shift in the treatment of pregnant women in jails and prisons across Illinois as well as nationwide, a growing recognition of the impact incarceration can have on parenthood as well as the next generation. Click the link in our bio for the full story. (Stacey Wescott / Chicago Tribune | @staceywescott27)

On a Thursday night in late June, Tavarion Laquon Foster put on his best clothes — khaki pants, black loafers, a black button up shirt — and went downtown to celebrate his scholarship from the Chicago Coalition for the Homeless. ⠀
⠀
Growing up, Tavarion didn’t think of himself as homeless. In his mind, moving from home to home, and bed to bed, was just life. Only years later would Tavarion understand that he was a data point in a statistic, one of the nearly 18,000 Chicago Public Schools students who are officially considered homeless. Four out of five of which are African American. ⠀
⠀
Most, like Tavarion, live “doubled up,” meaning with friends or extended family. The doubled-up are the homeless who aren’t living on the street or in a shelter, but who nonetheless endure the tumult of living without a stable home. In Tavarion’s case, doubled up meant more than double. At some points it meant 24 people in a single apartment. But Tavarion credits his extended family, teachers and coaches, for guidance and protection. ⠀
⠀
“Those people are the ones who showed me the things that I didn’t see, which created a bigger picture,” he says. “If you don’t have those people, then you’re not going to be able to see the bigger picture.” ⠀
⠀
Last month, Tavarion left for Stillman College, a small HBCU in Alabama. The $2,500 from the coalition — renewable if he stays in school — won’t pay for everything, but he is piecing together smaller scholarships he hopes will add up to enough. Click the link in our bio for the full story. (Abel Uribe / Chicago Tribune)

Eight months of hype for the 2019 Bears season fizzled into boos last night at Soldier Field. ⠀
⠀
The opener for the NFL’s 100th season was supposed to also be a kickoff for the Bears’ Super Bowl hopes in their 100th year. Instead, the offense’s sloppy play and coach Matt Nagy’s questionable decisions will be remembered in a 10-3 loss to the Packers. ⠀
⠀
Despite being sacked five times, Packers quarterback Aaron Rodgers improved to 17-5 in the regular season against the Bears. He led a 74-yard touchdown drive in the first half to put the Packers up for good. ⠀
⠀
The Bears held the Packers to only a 39-yard Mason Crosby field goal beyond that. But a fine defensive effort wasn’t enough to make up for the offense’s shortcomings. Click the link in our story for more photos and full Bears coverage. (John J. Kim, Jose M. Osorio, Armando L. Sanchez and Stacey Wescott / Chicago Tribune | @johnkimpictures @joseochicagotrib @mandophotos @staceywescott27) #chicagobears #bears100 #GBvsCHI @chitribsports

The view from the 83rd floor of Vista Tower is to die for. But it will never be enjoyed. ⠀
⠀
Instead, it will remain empty — even though a unit here would easily sell for about $10 million. The floor will be covered by a screenlike perimeter that lets Chicago’s famous winds whip right through. This so-called blow-through floor, the first of its kind in Chicago, is expected to cut wind-induced sway by nearly 25 percent. ⠀
⠀
But the blow-through can’t single-handedly stabilize the skyscraper. Water tanks containing more than 400,000 gallons are positioned in the top floors of the tower. When the wind pushes the tower one way, the water will slosh in the opposite direction, joining with the blow-through floor to counteract sway. ⠀
⠀
Vista Tower will be the city’s third-tallest building when it opens next year. Designed by Chicago star architect Jeanne Gang, it’s also going to be the world’s tallest building designed by a woman. Vista’s snaking curves undoubtedly stand out in a city where the right angle has long been king. ⠀
⠀
Click the link in our bio for more photos and the full story on the tower’s engineering. (Brian Cassella / Chicago Tribune | @briancassella) #views #cityscape #architecture

It’s a more intimate experience than the much larger Illinois State Fair about 150 miles north — so much so that some regulars say it reminds them more of a county fair than a state fair. ⠀
⠀
The Du Quoin State Fair, which the state has owned and operated since 1986, is located on a sprawling piece of lush southern Illinois land, and is described as a “park with a party in the middle of it.” In 2010, when the state Department of Agriculture’s budget was slashed, there were some concerns locally at that the fair itself would cease to exist. ⠀
⠀
“This place has been held together on duct tape and baling wire for years,” said John Gross, a Du Quoin native who took the reins of the fair earlier this year. Gross counts among his goals beefing up attendance, which he said was around 100,000 people last year, down significantly from when the Du Quoin State Fair drew people from all over the region, and when many southern Illinois residents would trek there multiple times for the fair’s end-of-summer run. ⠀
⠀
“I want to get the attendance back and make it a destination event again,” he said. Click the link in our bio for the full story. (Armando L. Sanchez / Chicago Tribune | @mandophotos) #southernillinois #fairseason #agriculture #statefair #duquoinstatefair

As Aaron Travis neared his 28th straight hour of streaming, even the thousands of people watching as he played Fortnite begged him to go to bed. ⠀
⠀
Such is life for a streamer — someone who earns a living by playing video games on the internet for a virtual crowd. Tall, thin and vampire pale, Travis admits his lifestyle is unhealthy and extreme. But here’s the crazy thing: It’s not half as unhealthy and extreme as his old one. ⠀
⠀
From the age of 18 to 26, Travis was addicted to heroin, a habit almost cinematic in its awfulness. He overdosed, blew through rehabs, got kicked out of his parents’ house, lived on the street, ripped off stores, went to prison and saw friends die. A moment of jailhouse inspiration set him on a better path, and video games have helped to keep him there. ⠀
⠀
His fixation with streaming is so intense that it worries some in his family, but Travis says it’s an obsession — maybe even another addiction — with a purpose. Click the link in our bio for the full story. (Terrence Antonio James/Chicago Tribune)

Remember that meteor that lit up Chicago’s night sky two years ago? Scientists are searching for it at the bottom of Lake Michigan. Not at its deepest point, where the lake plunges about 900 feet to the bottom, but at a relatively sane, albeit difficult, 200 feet. ⠀
⠀
Phil Willink and his team are looking for the meteorite that slammed into Lake Michigan about 1:30 a.m. Feb. 6, 2017, about 10 miles from shore. It was estimated by researchers to be traveling about 38,000 mph, and before cracking apart, it was initially the size of a car. It glowed green across Midwestern skies and rattled kitchen windows in Wisconsin.⠀
⠀
Starfall is a lawnmower-like, robot-looking contraption designed to trawl the lake bottom with GoPro cameras, LED lights and, most importantly, 72 magnets — because, as the idea goes, if meteorites are rich in iron, the magnets will grab a few. It’s an image of important science done on the cheap. They call this endeavor the Aquarius Project, and so far it’s run into dead fish, spotted a truck tire and recorded the monotonous image of miles and miles of invasive quagga mussels blanketing the lake bottom, which in itself was something of a revelation. ⠀
⠀
When Aquarius contacted the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration for detailed maps of this part of lake bottom, those maps didn’t exist yet. As for space rocks, nothing yet. The good news, researchers say, is that the 100 or so students who have been involved with Aquarius during its three-year existence are getting hands-on experience in the passion and frustration of exploration. ⠀
⠀
Even if nothing is found, Aquarius is establishing precedents for the serious hunting — on a budget — of meteorites in deep water. Click the link in our bio for the full story. (Camille Fine / Chicago Tribune | @camillefine)

In the past, she had been able to explain away the occasional strange symptom — numbness on one side of her body, or an electric shock sensation in her spine. Maybe she had a pinched nerve, maybe her backpack was too heavy. But now Ivy Marcucci couldn’t ignore what was happening. ⠀
⠀
The 20-year-old college student from Riverside said her vision blurred and doubled last December. Her father, a doctor, saw her squinting and observed that her eyes weren’t moving in tandem; it almost looked as if she had a lazy eye. He took her to the emergency room, where she quickly received a diagnosis: Ivy had multiple sclerosis, a disease of the central nervous system with widely varying but often disabling outcomes. ⠀
⠀
“It felt like the air had been sucked out of the room,” Ivy said. She recalls thinking, “Am I going to be in a wheelchair tomorrow?” ⠀
⠀
Ivy has come a long way since then. Last month she was discharged from Northwestern Memorial Hospital after completing a hematopoietic stem cell transplant, the same procedure that actress Selma Blair, who also has multiple sclerosis, recently announced she had received. The treatment, which is not widely available, got a big boost in January when a new study reported it outperformed conventional therapies, with 79 percent of patients experiencing no symptoms after five years. ⠀
⠀
Click the link in our bio for the full story. (Brian Cassella / Chicago Tribune | @briancassella)

What if you could roll out of bed, pull your favorite breakfast meat from the grill, order a bloody mary, relax in a lounge chair and watch Phil Mickelson smash a drive over Lake Kadijah? ⠀
⠀
Welcome to the Tiny House, a 350-square-foot abode on wheels that was positioned next to the 14th tee at Medinah Country Club for the duration of the BMW Championship. Bob Clarizio Jr. of South Elgin-based Bantam Built constructed the Tiny House, which contains a full bathroom and high-end galley kitchen with a four-burner stove, air conditioning and two lofts with queen-sized beds. ⠀
⠀
The house went up for sale at $95,000 at the end of the tournament, but the Medinah staff say they have plans to offer similar homes on the property. Click the link in our bio for the full story. (Jose M. Osorio / Chicago Tribune | @joseochicagotrib) #tinyhouse

By her own account, Keisha Wallace has been every type of homeless: She has bounced around friends’ couches, stayed in shelters and slept on the train overnight. Wallace, who suffers from chronic seizures, is hospitalized five to six times a month, frequenting emergency rooms around Chicago. ⠀
⠀
But her circumstances changed dramatically last week when she received the keys to her own apartment. Wallace, pictured above in her new home, is among the first residents to be housed through the Flexible Housing Pool, a collaboration among public and private health care and housing entities around Chicago that targets homeless “superusers” of emergency services including hospitals, emergency rooms, jails and shelters. ⠀
⠀
The pool is an example of the housing-first approach to combating homelessness, said Sybil Madison, deputy mayor of Chicago, who noted that it’s a more cost-efficient and humane. ⠀
⠀
The program places residents in supportive subsidized housing in apartments across the county and connects them with nearby social and health services. The idea is to get them the help they need on a noncrisis basis — which tends to be better for the recipients and the agencies that serve them. Click the link in our bio for the full story. (Armando L. Sanchez / Chicago Tribune | @mandophotos)

Almost 10,000 triathletes participated in this weekend’s Chicago Triathlon. The race, now in its 36th year, took place Sunday with staggered start times. The swim portion of the triathlon was canceled due to “unfavorable swim conditions” on Lake Michigan, forcing athletes to complete a duathlon instead. Click the link in our bio for more photos. (Camille Fine / Chicago Tribune | @camillefine) #chicagotriathlon #chitri

Born without arms, Tim Bannon became a viral phenomenon thanks to a workout video that showed him overcoming the odds — and his fears — to complete a box jump. ⠀
⠀
Today the 14-year-old from Hillside finished his first Chicago Triathlon. Racing in the senior division, ages 11-14, Bannon completed the 5.7 mile course with a time of 52 minutes and 46 seconds. His mother, Linda, who also was born armless because of Holt-Oram syndrome, will compete in Sunday’s race. ⠀
⠀
Trainer Keri Serota said Bannon was shy at first but came out of his shell as he built up his skills. And while he’s glad people have drawn inspiration from his video and his story, quite frankly, and unapologetically, Bannon’s not all that into athletics. ⠀
⠀
“I’m not an athletic guy,” he said. “I don’t like to lift weights, per se. I don’t like the gym part of athletics. I’m more of a get-on-the-field, get-on-the-court kind of person.” Click the link in our bio for the full story. (Erin Hooley / Chicago Tribune | @malarchy) #chicagotriathlon

Jean Dolores Schmidt’s basketball career started in 1933 with rules that allowed only forwards to shoot. By 2018, she was the star of the NCAA Tournament — bobblehead and all. ⠀
⠀
Today, Loyola’s very own Sister Jean turns 100 years old. Known for her maroon and gold scarf, quick wit and pre-game prayers, the beloved nun has no intention of slowing down. ⠀
⠀
“I never tried to think I was getting old,” she said while sitting in her wheelchair at a computer in her office on a July day. “I think that’s kind of debilitating.” ⠀

She celebrated Wednesday alongside students and Loyola President Jo Ann Rooney, with cake and songs from a campus a cappella group. The university plans to honor her by raising funds for a $100,000 athletic endowment. Sister Jean said she has the key to a long life, following the principles of St. Ignatius. ⠀
⠀
“I eat well and sleep well,” she said. “And hopefully I pray well.” Click the link in our bio for more photos and the full story. (Stacey Wescott, Camille Fine, Erin Hooley, Chris Walker, Nuccio DiNuzzo, and Armando L. Sanchez | @staceywescott27 @malarchy @camillefine @mandophotos)

Rainbow colors flash across singers’ faces. The bass player wears a T-shirt: “Conversion Therapy Dropout.” A pride flag hangs against the brick wall, and Joshua Hundl, a drag performer, wears a dress that says, “God is gay, nonbinary, pan, queer.” ⠀
⠀
That’s what the second Tuesday of every month often looks like at Atmosphere, an Andersonville gay bar where Affirming Worship holds its service. The organization, founded in March, works against what a traditional Christian might think of as Sunday service. It’s a space for queer individuals in the Chicago area to discover or rediscover faith, separate from a church in which they may feel uncomfortable. The traditional narrative, one Affirming Worship and other groups in Chicago work against, is that queerness and faith are disparate, but the common refrain among queer Christians is that Jesus himself was marginalized, and that religion was made for queer people as much as their straight peers. ⠀
⠀
Hannah Kardon, pastor at Urban Village Church, who described Chicago as an “epicenter of a burgeoning movement of bold, queer Christian experiences,” said this phenomenon is logical, since there’s a difference between belief and the institutions that build rules around it. Click the link in our bio for the full story. (Armando L. Sanchez / Chicago Tribune | @mandophotos)

The rhythmic beats filled the park on a rainy summer afternoon, transforming the corner of 57th and Racine to Harmony and Healing for the moment. The sound came from under the eaves of the field house at Moran Park, where Ernest Dawkins, a Chicago jazz musician who performs in clubs around the world, played along with two other drummers sheltered from the rain. ⠀
⠀
This marks the fourth summer that Dawkins, an internationally known jazz saxophonist and composer pictured in photo 2, has been leading drumming circles in Chicago parks — primarily in Englewood, the South Side neighborhood where he has lived for many years. The effort is the latest in Dawkins’ vision to restore the arts to Englewood, but the circles are also this gifted musician’s answer to the decades of violence his community has endured — a communal ritual that all are welcome to join, especially kids, he said. ⠀
⠀
“The children are the ones you want to affect,” he said. “You have to show them there’s other ways of dealing with their situation ... other ways of just managing discord or even chaos.” ⠀
⠀
Click the link in our bio for the full story. (Camille Fine / Chicago Tribune | @camillefine)

Weather for the annual Air and Water Show’s practice runs on Thursday and Friday was much preferred to the main event. Nevertheless, thousands of people packed onto North Avenue and Oak Street beaches and the Lakefront Trail to take in the show Saturday morning as dark clouds rolled in. ⠀
⠀
Crowds of people along the lakefront took shelter in underpasses of Lake Shore Drive, while others remained in their spots, donning ponchos, umbrellas or tents. Saturday’s show ended early after performances were delayed at least twice due to heavy rain and the possibility of lightning. ⠀
⠀
The show is set to continue Sunday, but Chicagoans hoping for better weather might be in for a disappointment. Click the link in our bio for more photos from the show and updated weather forecasts. (John J. Kim, Erin Hooley, Antonio Perez / Chicago Tribune | @johnkimpictures @malarchy @apereztribune) #airandwatershow

Illinoisans have been conducting all-out warfare against invasive species like the emerald ash borer and the Asian carp. And yet, silently, stealthily, another invader has crept into our state, our city — even our own backyards. ⠀
⠀
Jumping worms, aka crazy worms, Alabama jumpers or snake worms, are being found everywhere in Chicago. It’s pretty easy to figure out where jumping worms, which originate in East Asia, got their name. They jump. In fact, if disturbed, they thrash violently and may leap around a little — it’s momentarily entertaining, in that scary-nature-show sort of way. The worms are energetic feeders, too, which is why they present a problem. ⠀
⠀
“Not all earthworms are created equal when it comes to helping soil and gardens,” says Brad Herrick, a University of Wisconsin ecologist. “They will stay in that top layer just consuming the organic matter until it’s all gone. Which is why you can see them so easily, and they’re kind of shocking in high abundance.” ⠀
⠀
Scientists have concerns about the worm’s appetite that go far beyond our city yards. But rolling back the jumping worm invasion is unlikely at this point. Click the link in our bio for the full story. (Armando L. Sanchez / Chicago Tribune | @mandophotos)

Earl Young was shot dead in his South Shore backyard in a petty dispute over dogs with a neighbor, according to police reports. He was one of the very first victims of Chicago’s deadliest weekend of 2018 — when at least 75 people were shot and 13 were killed in 40 attacks across the city. ⠀
⠀
His fiancee, Kendra Rodriguez, had recently given birth to a baby girl. It was a joyful time, she recalled. But after the shooting, she moved herself and her children out of their South Shore home because of the painful reminders of that night, and knowing the suspects were from the area. Adding to the pain was the lack of information from Chicago detectives, who she assumed forgot about Young. ⠀
⠀
More than 30 of the attacks from that deadly August weekend remain unsolved, reflecting the Chicago Police Department’s continuing struggle to boost clearance rates that had fallen abysmally below the national average in recent years. ⠀
⠀
At the end of 2018, the clearance rate was 44.9% for homicides and 16% for nonfatal shootings. Department officials said the homicide rate continued to improve this year and stood at 51% through Aug. 7. Click the link in our bio for the full story. (Abel Uribe / Chicago Tribune)

In the law library of the Cook County Jail, the chase was on. Detainee Emmanuel Garcia, photo two, frantically moved his king around a virtual chessboard, losing one piece after another as his opponent closed in. ⠀
⠀
Just when it seemed all was lost, though, the timer hit zero, ending the game in a draw. A dozen other men dressed in tan jail scrubs applauded: The result helped the team of detainees defeat a band of Brazilian prisoners they were playing over the internet. ⠀
⠀
So it went in the first international chess tournament for inmates, pitting Cook County against prisoners in six countries, including Russia, Armenia, Belarus, Italy and England. The tournament is the latest development in the jail’s chess program, founded seven years ago with the help of Russian grandmaster Anatoly Karpov. ⠀
⠀
About 120 detainees take classes in the game, and 15 of the best were invited to take on the world in the two-day event. Click the link in our bio for the full story. (E. Jason Wambsgans / Chicago Tribune | @ejwamb)

As President Donald Trump left open the possibility he might release Rod Blagojevich from his federal prison sentence, the disgraced former Illinois governor this weekend set off for a solitary run underneath the setting sun. ⠀
⠀
Wearing black New Balance sneakers and rocking his now-silver mane, Blagojevich bounded down the porch steps at the boomerang-shaped camp building where he’s held and ran past a group of fellow inmates. With his head down, Blagojevich jogged 20 laps Saturday. On Sunday, the former governor again left the camp to exercise. ⠀
⠀
Trump’s Wednesday night announcement that he is “very strongly" considering whether to commute Blagojevich’s 14-year sentence for public corruption — which included attempting to trade Barack Obama’s U.S. Senate seat for personal gain as well as trying to shake down executives from a children’s hospital and the horse-racing industry for campaign contributions — has transfixed Chicagoans, who wonder whether the imprisoned former governor will soon be back among them. ⠀
⠀
The president's talk of freeing Blagojevich has drawn criticism from good government experts and Illinois Republicans. But his supporters have continued their public campaign for his release. Click the link in our bio for the full story. (Brian Cassella / Chicago Tribune | @briancassella)

As the Bud Billiken parade moved past her Bronzeville home with bursts of music and cheering, 12-year-old Summer Dailey (photo four) handed out lemonade on the corner, collecting money and smiling at her patrons. ⠀
⠀
For about 12 years, the Dailey family has lived on the corner of 44th Street and King Drive, a prime location for the storied South Side parade. Summer started her lemonade stand about five years ago as a way to launch her own savings account. Her mother, Lakisha Dailey, wanted her to learn about responsibility and the concept of earning her own money. Like some at the parade, the Dailey family has built traditions around the yearly event. Many of the 1.2 million who gather along the parade route, which spans along King Drive from Pershing Road to Washington Park, have attended it for years, even decades. ⠀
⠀
This year, the community celebrated the parade’s 90th anniversary after it was started in 1929 by Robert S. Abbott, founder of the Chicago Defender, the city’s influential black newspaper. Click the link in our bio for the full story. (Camille Fine / Chicago Tribune | @camillefine)

For the second straight month, Lake Michigan has crested to its highest mark in over three decades — each time 1 inch shy of record highs set in 1986. ⠀
⠀
It takes roughly 780 billion gallons of water to raise Lake Michigan 1 inch. Since 2013, the lake has risen nearly 6 feet from record lows. This year, the buoyant water has swallowed at least two Chicago beaches entirely and periodically closed others. It has swiped fishermen from piers, swimmers from beaches and created hazards for boaters. ⠀
⠀
The remnants of 12th Street Beach are split into two pieces. And the stairways that led visitors to the center of the beach plunge directly into Lake Michigan. On the Far North Side, where scores of high-rise residential buildings mirror the shoreline, conditions appear to be among the most precarious. Residents say the generally bustling lakefront there has become lonely as its greatest attraction — the beaches — have greatly diminished or disappeared.
⠀
But perhaps the most worrisome aspect of this summer is that these perils have occurred while the lake has remained mostly calm. The upcoming fall months are when the lake is often its most active. Click the link in our bio for the full story. (Brian Cassella, Antonio Perez, Terrence Antonio James / Chicago Tribune | @briancassella @apereztribune)

A small red-brick, pitched-roof abortion clinic about 90 miles east of downtown Chicago has become the epicenter of a larger war over reproductive rights nationwide as more conservative states enact restrictions poised to challenge Roe v. Wade. ⠀
⠀
Whole Woman’s Health of South Bend has waged a roughly two-year fight to bring abortion access to the city of about 102,000. Volunteers in bright pink vests walk alongside patients to and from their cars, often deploying a rainbow-hued umbrellas to form a colorful barrier between the patient and several protesters. In 2017, the state health department denied the clinic’s application for a license over allegations it failed to meet the requirement of “reputable and responsible character.” The clinic called the state’s objections “politically motivated” and “medically unnecessary.” ⠀
⠀
The clinic’s tenuous survival has been championed by South Bend mayor and Democratic presidential candidate Pete Buttigieg, whose national campaign includes a pro-reproductive rights platform. Buttigieg ignited a local firestorm last year when he vetoed a zoning request from an anti-abortion pregnancy center that attempted to open next door. Click the link in our bio for the full story. (Camille Fine / Chicago Tribune | @camillefine)

People magazine, home of A-List celebrity news, is making space for a four-legged Chicagoan this week. Kele is an 8-month-old shelter kitten with a fluffy white coat, big golden eyes and an outgoing, playful personality. ⠀
⠀
One of nine pets nationwide featured in a two-page spread about adoptable dogs and cats, Kele (KEY-lee) is described as a “special needs kitten.” Erin Mayes, PAWS Chicago assistant director of feline behavior, said Kele appears to have a congenital malformation of the spine, and is incontinent, so she needs to be diapered and gets a bath once a day. ⠀
⠀
Kele probably began her life as a stray, Mayes said. At PAWS, she became good friends with an older cat and got to work learning how to wear a diaper. She has been waiting for adoption since mid-March. Click the link in our bio for the full story. (Erin Hooley / Chicago Tribune | @malarchy)

“Está muerta.” She’s dead. That’s all the police officer said to the family of Marlen Ochoa-Lopez, three weeks after the pregnant teen went missing. Three weeks of hope, then dread, then hope again that the 19-year-old and her unborn son were somehow safe and would return home. ⠀
⠀
Three weeks of wondering how hard police were trying to find out what happened when she disappeared after leaving high school to pick up baby clothes. They would have to wait even longer to learn that police had already arrested two women in a plot to steal Ochoa-Lopez’s baby by strangling her and cutting the boy from her womb the day she disappeared. ⠀
⠀
In interviews with the Tribune, Ochoa-Lopez’s parents talked about those days of panic, despair, grief and confusion — about the silence from police, about crank calls and false leads and, finally, solid clues from friends and strangers gleaned from Facebook and GoFundMe pages. Click the link in our bio for the full story in both English and Spanish. ⠀
⠀
_______ ⠀
⠀
“Está muerta”. Eso es todo lo que el agente de policía le dijo a la familia de Marlen Ochoa-López tres semanas después de la desaparición de la adolescente embarazada. Tres semanas de esperanza, luego temor, luego esperanza de que la joven de 19 años y su hijo sin nacer estuvieran seguros y regresaran a casa. ⠀
⠀
Tres semanas preguntándose con cuánto ahínco la policía trataba de averiguar qué sucedió cuando ella desapareció después de salir de la secundaria para recoger ropa de bebé. Tendrían que esperar aún más tiempo para saber que la policía ya había arrestado a tres personas quienes conspiraron para robar al bebé de Ochoa-López estrangulándola y separando al niño de su vientre el día que desapareció. ⠀
⠀
En entrevistas con el Tribune, los padres de Ochoa-López hablaron sobre esos días de pánico, desesperación, pena y confusión; sobre el inquietante silencio de la policía, sobre las llamadas de broma y las pistas falsas y, finalmente, obtuvieron pistas sólidas de amigos y extraños recogidas de páginas de Facebook y GoFundMe. Sigue el enlace en nuestro perfil para leer el reporte entero en español. ⠀
⠀
(Abel Uribe and Antonio Perez / Chicago Tribune | @apereztribune)

Lollapalooza descended on Grant Park for another four days of music and fashion — marking the festival’s 15th year as a destination event in Chicago. More than 180 bands and artists performed on eight stages for 10 hours each day. ⠀
⠀
As security on Saturday was tested by fence jumpers, thefts and an enormous crowd at rapper Lil Wayne’s set, day three of the festival ended with one death, four arrests, five citations and 30 hospital transfers, according to city officials. Sunday's numbers are not yet available. Fence-jumping, the great Lolla rite of passage, remains one of the weekend’s most active trends. Activity on Saturday’s Chicago police scanner frequencies included reports of efforts to tear down the fence barrier on the Lake Shore Drive side of the festival. ⠀
⠀
Click the link in our bio for full coverage from the weekend, including daily recaps, performance reviews, fashion galleries, artist interviews and more photos. (Erin Hooley, Armando L. Sanchez and Camille Fine | @malarchy @mandophotos @camillefine) #lollapalooza #lollapalooza2019 #festivalseason

He, she or they? At work, Chris Rosario sticks to trousers and button-down shirts. But on the weekends, his look is different. Flowing dresses, bold prints and vibrant colors accompany his thick beard. ⠀
⠀
The 33-year-old content manager was born “he.” But today he describes himself as gender queer, living and dressing as neither male nor female, but somewhere along the spectrum between them. ⠀
⠀
“At work I’m typically in more male dress,” Rosario said. “It’s not that I’m hiding. The individuals I’m close to and work with know who I am and see pictures of my weekend outfits.” ⠀
⠀
Helping Rosario and his co-workers with those conversations is his employer, IBM, one of a number of companies pushing into uncharted territory — making their workplaces inclusive and welcoming for people who don’t define themselves as male or female. There are a number of terms for people who describe themselves as identifying as neither male nor female, identify as both or reject gender labels entirely: gender fluid, gender neutral, gender queer or gender nonconforming. ⠀
⠀
Brilliant Staffing employee Avery Matthew came out at work as nonbinary more than two years ago. The then-senior recruiting manager said while most people are accepting, some colleagues still stumble over the appropriate pronoun to use. ⠀
⠀
“We are constantly putting people in boxes that they may not identify with,” Matthew said. “Whenever you’re assuming who someone is, you may not be right. You need to allow them to tell you who they are.” Click the link in our bio for the full story. (Zbigniew Bzdak and Jose M. Osorio / Chicago Tribune | @bzdak @joseochicagotrib)

Chicago’s Lincoln Park and Brookfield Zoos, two of the most popular attractions in the region, closed their elephant habitats 14 and nine years ago, respectively. ⠀
⠀
Yet the Milwaukee County Zoo, which welcomes more than 1.1 million annual visitors, is spending $16.6 million to provide 1.6 acres outdoors and 20,000 square feet indoors for its two 38-year-old African elephants, Brittany and Ruth. ⠀
⠀
For the most part zoos have been getting out of the elephant business as animal welfare concerns have challenged the ethics and traditional practices in keeping the animals that are among the most intelligent on land. But Milwaukee’s angle on elephant keeping is an intriguing one. ⠀
⠀
As zoos and circuses continue to exit the elephant business, either because of the raised standards, concerns about costs or negative publicity, their animals are going to need a place to go. Milwaukee County Zoo, in so many words, wants to be the rest home for elephants in their golden years. ⠀
⠀
“Everybody wants to breed because babies and breeding are probably a lot sexier than old, geriatric elephants,” added Erin Dowgwillo, the zoo’s elephant care coordinator. “But we just decided our staff experience is also towards the older animals, and there was a need for a facility like that.” Click the link in our bio for the full story. (Brian Cassella/Chicago Tribune | @briancassella)
⠀
#elephants #africanelephant #zoo #zooanimals #milwaukee #mke #animalrights #animalconservation

As 20 presidential contenders descend upon Detroit for the second round of Democratic debates tonight and Wednesday, party officials and African American political leaders point to Hillary Clinton’s loss to Donald Trump in Michigan as a cautionary tale of what can happen when a Democrat takes black voters for granted. ⠀
⠀
In Wayne County, home to Motown and its immediate suburbs, Clinton collected 76,000 fewer votes in 2016 than Barack Obama did in 2012. The majority off the falloff occurred in the city, which is 80% black. Clinton lost the entire state of Michigan by just 10,704 votes. ⠀
⠀
“If you don’t come into my community and talk to me, don’t talk about my issues, don’t ask me for my support, then guess what? Don’t automatically assume I’m going to vote for you,” said Jonathan Kinloch, Democratic chairman of Michigan’s 13th Congressional District, which encompasses Detroit’s western half. ⠀
⠀
This time, party officials say they are being vigilant about engaging Detroit’s black voters earlier, with Michigan again expected to be a pivotal swing state. Click the link in our bio for the full story. (E. Jason Wambsgans / Chicago Tribune | @ejwamb) #2020election #demdebate #detroit

Wakandacon — the convention born last year on the heels of Marvel’s ultra-succesful “Black Panther” film — returned to Chicago this weekend with a theme of “finding your tribe.” ⠀
⠀
Ashley Walker, 30, used the event to amplify her message that the country needs more black women in science. As a future astrochemistry student, she led an Adler Planetarium-sponsored panel about black women in astrochemistry and planetary science, specifically the very low numbers of black women in the U.S. that hold a doctorate in physics. ⠀
⠀
“There are little girls that are being told: Black women don’t like physics. We are often pushed out or we say: ’This isn’t for me, due to a lot of toxic masculinity,’” Walker said. “We want to promote more women of color and more women in STEM, but we also want to hold on to ones that are already there. Finding your tribe is so what we need right now.” ⠀
⠀
Walker will graduate in December with a bachelor’s degree in chemistry from Chicago State University before pursuing her doctorate in astrochemistry. When she earns that degree, Walker will be one of only a handful of astrochemistry doctorates in the nation — something she hopes to change by encouraging more black women to enter the field. Click the link in our bio for the full story. (Zbigniew Bzdak / Chicago Tribune | @bzdak) #wakandacon

When it opens in the coming months, Englewood Brews will be the rare brewery with a Black owner — that’s co-founder Lesley Roth — and even rarer brewery located in a majority Black neighborhood, one that most often makes the news for violence, much of it gang-related. ⠀
⠀
Some people are surprised. Others confused. But the reason why Roth and her partner are launching a brewery in Chicago’s Englewood neighborhood — is a fact equally simple and overlooked during the nation’s craft beer boom during the past decade. ⠀
⠀
“Black people do love beer,” Roth said with a laugh. “And craft beer.” ⠀
⠀
The ZIP code where Englewood Brews will be housed, in a former furniture store at 63rd and Halsted streets, is 98 percent Black according to the latest Census figures. In a neighborhood where investment in new places to eat and drink is spotty at best, Roth sees launching a brewery as “an awesome opportunity.” Chicago has one of the nation’s most robust beer scenes, but its beer culture, as in most places, has mostly been confined to neighborhoods that are predominately white. ⠀
⠀
“Continuing to concentrate breweries on the North Side is missing out on a growing population that wants to enjoy good beer, too,” Roth said. Click the link in our bio for the full story. (Jose M. Osorio / Chicago Tribune | @joseochicagotrib) #craftbeer #beer #brewery

Jonathan Logemann is among an estimated 400 members of the Illinois Army National Guard who leave this weekend to begin a more than yearlong deployment to Afghanistan. Officials say the deployment of the 1st Battalion, 178th Infantry Regiment, headquartered on Chicago’s South Side, marks the largest mobilization of Illinois National Guardsmen and women in nearly a decade. ⠀
⠀
The latest deployment means the families of the hundreds of National Guard members will be disrupted. Logemann left his job at a Rockford public school earlier this year to focus on training and recently resigned from his first term on the Rockford City Council in anticipation of his deployment. ⠀
⠀
“I’m not worried about me at all. I’m going to be very busy enough,” he said. “But I’m just making sure that all the bases are covered at home because we are going from like a two-parent household to like a one-parent household. There is a lot of family support, and I think that’s really important because it’s the whole family that kind of deploys.” ⠀
⠀
The soldiers will first spend a few weeks undergoing additional training in Fort Bliss, Texas, before heading to Afghanistan around the time of its planned presidential election on Sept. 28. Click the link in our bio for the full story. (Stacey Wescott / Chicago Tribune | @staceywescott27)

Choosing milk for morning cereal or coffee used to be pretty simple: skim, low-fat or whole. These days, though, the dairy aisle is crowded with milk alternatives made with cashews, hazelnuts, macadamia nuts, oat, rice, hemp, peas and bananas, many sweetened, flavored or fortified. ⠀
⠀
The plant-based explosion has caused headaches for the dairy industry, which for years has been grappling with falling milk consumption and sales. At their small dairy farm in Campton Hills in Chicago’s western suburbs, Andy and Sarah Lenkaitis have invested heavily in innovations to remain viable. ⠀
⠀
Two robotic milkers operate 24 hours a day, allowing the farm’s cows — referred to by their individual nicknames — to enter and milk when they wish, typically three times a day. Enticed by feed pellets, the cows line up at the machine like they’re waiting for the bathroom at a nightclub. The couple monitor the operation through closed-circuit TVs or data pushed to their smartphones. Sensors that hang around the cows’ necks monitor how much they are eating and flag issues suggesting when a cow may be unwell. ⠀
⠀
Sarah, who grew up on a dairy farm in Wisconsin and studied dairy science in college, hopes inviting people to see their cutting-edge operation inspires the next generation of dairy farmers and encourages more consumers to keep cow’s milk on the table. ⠀
⠀
Click the link in our bio for the full story. (Stacey Wescott / Chicago Tribune | @staceywescott27) #milk #dairy #farm #cows #dairyfree #milkalternative #farmlife #dairyfarm

Yolanda Anderson remembers when she first saw the 2,667-square-foot home her parents bought in 1986. She was 13 years old. The exterior was originally dark evergreen. Pink, however, symbolized the love the family wanted the house to convey. ⠀
⠀
The Austin neighborhood house, built in 1894, is now widely known for its pink and white exterior. But because of disrepair and high repair costs, the Andersons recently put it on the market for $290,000, then dropped their asking price to $160,000. Now, the owners of the iconic house on Chicago’s West Side have launched a GoFundMe campaign in an effort to keep the home that has been in the family for more than 30 years. ⠀
⠀
“Like the community, the house can be judged for its run down state, or misrepresentation of the nicks and cuts, scars and bruises,” the family said on the GoFundMe page. “The house still stands through the punishment of the elements, its survival of two fires, and has protected the Anderson family when a less formidably made home may have not given them enough time to make it to safety. Like the West Side, it is a strong giant, in need of love, support, and recognition.” ⠀
⠀
Anderson now lives in the home with her mother, three younger siblings and another family member. The bright pink hues of both the inside and outside of the house never felt out of the ordinary for the family. If anything, it made the family with origins in the South feel more at home. Click the link in our bio for the full story. (Antonio Perez / Chicago Tribune | @apereztribune) #historichomes #architecture

Unlike most roller derby, often played in adult leagues, the Chicago Riots gives girls ages 10 to 18 an early opportunity to experience the gritty and inclusive sport. ⠀
⠀
Formed in 2009, the Riots are part of a self-sustained community of female and nonbinary skaters coached and mentored by The Chicago Outfit, one of the city’s adult teams. Head coach Karen Kinderman, derby name Rhonda Swanson, said the camaraderie is addictive. ⠀
⠀
“Kids see (derby) and they’re like, ‘I want to do that,’” Kinderman said. “Like, ‘I want to be that person who’s hitting people down on the ground and still skating or getting knocked down and getting back up.‘” ⠀
⠀
Anyone who’s seen roller derby, its spit-flying, sweat-drenched mania, might balk at the idea of bringing children into the mix. But participants say the gritty nature of the sport, the knock-down always waiting to happen, lends itself to players’ development both in and outside of the rink. Click the link in our bio for the full story. (Erin Hooley / Chicago Tribune | @malarchy) #chicagooutfitrollerderby #rollerderby

Pitchfork Music Festival returned to Union Park in Chicago over the weekend for its 14th year. ⠀
⠀
Attendees faced heat-stroke-worthy humidity, rain, thunder and evacuations but the festival went on with acts including Ibeyi, Mavis Staples, JPEGMAFIA and Haim. ⠀
⠀
Click the link in our bio for more photos and full festival coverage. (Camille Fine, Terrence Antonio James, John J. Kim and Chris Sweda / Chicago Tribune | @camillefine @johnkimpictures) #p4kfest

Mamby on the Beach, the music festival that collided with species-saving efforts for two federally endangered birds, has been canceled. And the birds, who have made the beach their summer home, are likely not packing up anytime soon. ⠀
⠀
Monty ran into Rose at Montrose Beach in early June and immediately, right there, on a busy stretch of Lake Michigan, they began having a lot of sex. We know, because Tamima Itani, who lives in Evanston, was watching. She took notes. In fact, a lot of people have taken a lot of notes on Monty and Rose. ⠀
⠀
The two are piping plovers, and the first of their kind with confirmed residency in Chicago. Their most recent offspring — hatched earlier this week — mark a major victory for preservation efforts. It’s the first time one of the birds has hatched in Cook County in more than 60 years. And following that victory comes a cancellation. ⠀
⠀
“We are saddened to announce that Mamby on the Beach has been canceled for 2019 due to circumstances beyond our control,” said a statement posted on the festival’s Twitter account late Friday afternoon. “These unforeseen issues include significantly higher than average waters of Lake Michigan eliminating the beach portion of our intended site. Additionally, our original footprint was affected by the presence of the Great Lakes Piping Plover shorebirds, a federally protected species.” ⠀
⠀
Click the link in our bio for the full story. (John J. Kim / Chicago Tribune | @johnkimpictures) #pipingplover #plover #birds #endangeredspecies #conservation #mambyonthebeach #mamby #musicfestival #festivalseason

For Alexandra Waldman, co-founder and creative director at Universal Standard, fashion is all about providing access to style and quality-made clothing regardless of size. She wants to end the industry’s segregation of plus-size and non-plus-size clothes, so women of all sizes can shop together and dress any way they want. ⠀
⠀
The result is Universal Standard, a fashion brand focused on making quality “elevated essentials” from sizes 00 to 4XL. Glimpse their online presence and see minimalist aesthetic pieces like gauzy tunics, supple tie-dresses, glossy tees that transition from work to play, and classics like a good jean jacket and tuxedo collar shirt. ⠀
⠀
The New York-based company opened its Chicago Universal Standard 1:1 location this month in the West Loop — an experiential space that will mix retail with community, or as Waldman puts it, “an extension of your own home.” It’s a place where one can stop by in the morning to work while enjoying a coffee or a bowl of cereal, or a place to just hang out before you meet up with friends for dinner. Click the link in our bio for the full story. (Chris Sweda / Chicago Tribune) #fashion #plussizefashion #styling #customstyle #westloopchicago #shopchicago

Chicago is an island? An “urban heat island” has the power to split an incoming storm system in two or keep a city and its suburbs significantly hotter than surrounding areas, especially once the sun goes down, meteorologists say. ⠀
⠀
Chicago is one such island — and this week the magnitude of the island’s impact on our weather will be on display. The National Weather Service said it expects Friday will easily be the hottest day of the year. So what is an urban heat island? And how does this meteorological phenomenon apply to Chicago? ⠀
⠀
Click the link in our bio to learn what you need to know about urban heat islands as Chicago braces for a heat wave. (Armando L. Sanchez, John J. Kim, Antonio Perez, Jose M. Osorio / Chicago Tribune | @mandophotos @johnkimpictures @apereztribune @joseochicagotrib) #summer #heatwave #cubs #cycling #running #basketball #chicagosummer

The alligator in the Humboldt Park Lagoon that eluded authorities for a week was caught overnight and made an appearance at a news conference Tuesday morning. ⠀
⠀
The male, 5-foot-3 alligator weighing 30 to 40 pounds, was captured around 1:30 a.m. at the northwest side of the lagoon, officials said. New alligator trapper Frank Robb, who was brought in from Florida to replace a volunteer trapper, spotted him hiding in the lily pads. ⠀
⠀
“The Humboldt Park alligator has captured the imaginations of the entire city of Chicago and beyond and has united residents who have been following this story for the last week,” Chicago Animal Care and Control said in a release earlier Tuesday. “Officials will inform residents about the plan that led to his successful capture and the next steps for him.” ⠀
⠀
Click the link in our bio for the full story. (Jose M. Osorio / Chicago Tribune | @joseochicagotrib) #chancethesnapper

Mark Goralski was sick for most of his life, but that didn’t stop the Naperville father of three from volunteering at a hospital or visiting children in prison. ⠀
⠀
“He was just the best guy,” said his daughter Hannah, 24. “When you asked him how he was doing, even if he wasn’t feeling well, he didn’t want to burden anyone with his health problems, even though they were such a burden to him sometimes.” ⠀
⠀
After he died last fall following a long struggle with Crohn’s disease and kidney failure, his daughters, Hannah and Bethany, 25, took his example of giving freely and ran with it. They called Northwestern Memorial Hospital, where he’d been treated, and said that they wanted to honor their dad by each donating a kidney to a stranger. In the photo above, Bethany compares her scar with her kidney recipient, Melanie Mavec, after meeting for the first time on July 1, 2019.
⠀
Their donations led to a chain of additional anonymous donations, in which people who wanted to donate to loved ones but weren’t a match gave to strangers, with the understanding that their loved ones would in turn receive kidneys from strangers. In all, five people have now received kidneys because of the series of lifesaving kidney swaps that started with the Goralskis. Click the link in our bio for the full story. (Brian Cassella / Chicago Tribune | @briancassella)

Last month, The Licking, a soul food restaurant best known for a partnership with hip-hop star DJ Khaled, opened with lines out the door in the South Austin neighborhood of Chicago. ⠀
⠀
Despite the restaurant’s suggestive name and star power, the growing empire began when CEO and Miami area-based music mogul Elric “E-Class” Prince discovered struggling chef Tasha Colton. Unlike celebrity restaurateurs, E-Class has spent weeks personally training his team in Chicago — he’s been spotted in the kitchen, behind the take-out counter and walking the dining room at the restaurant in South Austin, his sixth location, which made sense to the partners but raised questions from locals, across the street and across town. ⠀
⠀
“It’s just crazy to me, how you come to a neighborhood to bring something good, and everybody who comes in is like, why is it here?” E-Class said. “It’s like you have no faith in your community or your city. … I could have started in Chicago downtown, but we just wanted to start it in the 'hood, give back to our people and give employment to the people of this community.” ⠀
⠀
The fate of the West Side restaurant, as well as plans for a South Side location, rests not on its famous partners or the fan favorite entree of the fried lobster dinner, but the restaurant’s  soft-spoken, food-loving CEO. Click the link in our bio for the full story. (Brian Cassella / Chicago Tribune | @briancassella) @chitribfood @louisachu1

As major cities across the county prepare for raids promised by the Trump administration, Chicagoans took to the streets to oppose the Immigration and Customs Enforcement policies. ⠀
⠀
Thousands crowded into the Loop in nearly 90-degree heat, chanting “Immigrants are welcome here” and holding signs. Large, rainbow-colored block letters floated above the crowd, spelling “Resist.” The rally was the city’s second in two days, after hundreds gathered in Federal Plaza on Friday night ahead of deportation sweeps expected Sunday. ⠀
⠀
Chicago’s immigrant communities are preparing for the possible raids as advocates educate city residents about their rights should they encounter federal immigration agents. Click the link in our bio for more coverage, including what could happen if ICE raids come to your neighborhood. (Abel Uribe / Chicago Tribune) #immigration #ice

With demand growing faster than the plants themselves, Illinois farmers are making big bets on hemp. Based in Tazewell County, southeast of Peoria, Trent Lawrence is one of about 475 Illinoisans who have received licenses to farm hemp since the state started accepting applications last month. ⠀
⠀
Hemp, a cousin of the marijuana plant, is perhaps best known for its use in foods and fibers. But certain varieties of hemp produce cannabidiol, or CBD, the wildly popular cannabis compound that is being infused into everything from animal treats to teas and cosmetics. CBD, which does not get users high, has been touted as a cure for stress, inflammation, insomnia and any number of other ailments. ⠀
⠀
Farming hemp for CBD is much different than farming hemp for fiber or grain. From planting to harvesting, hemp that is raised for CBD must be tended to manually, while hemp raised for grain and fiber can be farmed with the same equipment that is used with other crops. If everything goes according to plan, Lawrence estimates he could make $100,000 per acre of CBD hemp. And it’s not just the potential profits. For corn and soybean farmers, hemp is also a means of diversifying away from the state’s two primary crops, the latter of which has been socked with tariffs. ⠀
⠀
