Despite hemp’s finicky needs, farmers like Lawrence are depending on this year’s crop. Click the link in our bio for the full story. (John J. Kim/Chicago Tribune | @johnkimpictures) #hemp #cbd #hempfarm #cbdoils

After the hottest day of the year Wednesday in Chicago, Thursday’s temperature on shore should be just right, but forecasters are warning of rip currents and waves up to 5 feet, posing a high swimming risk along the Lake Michigan shoreline in Illinois and Indiana. ⠀
⠀
“People visiting the beaches should stay out of the water,” the weather service warned in the advisory. The waves are potentially life-threatening to swimmers, the weather service said. Structural currents can also form along piers and sweep swimmers into deeper water. ⠀
⠀
The beach hazards statement comes a day after Chicago logged its hottest day of 2019, with an official temperature of 94 degrees, and the hottest day since August 2018. Click the link in our bio for updated weather coverage. (Armando L. Sanchez / Chicago Tribune | @mandophotos) #lakemichigan #sunrise #summer #weather

The search for an alligator spotted in Chicago’s Humboldt Park Lagoon has entered its second day Wednesday, as police warned people to leave the gator trapping to a volunteer animal wrangler known as Alligator Bob, who works with Chicago officials to capture exotic animals. ⠀
⠀
Police had “independently confirmed the alligator is in the lagoon and state reptile specialists” said it was 4 to 5 feet long, police spokesman Anthony Guglielmi said in a tweet. The animal is expected to be trapped and relocated to a zoo for veterinary evaluation. Alligator Bob set three baited traps Tuesday with different baits, including raw chicken, rat and bluegill. They were undisturbed overnight, except by turtles. ⠀
⠀
Officials believe someone had the alligator as a pet and recently released it into the lagoon. But this is far from the first exotic animal located in Chicago waterways, and not even the first time one has been found in the Humboldt Park Lagoon. ⠀
⠀
In 1984, people fishing in the lagoon found a small South American caiman, a relative of the alligator, and reported seeing a larger one that didn’t get caught. In 1983, someone caught a piranha while fishing at the lagoon, leading to the Park District stationing lifeguards at the lagoon to keep people out of the water. Click the link in our bio for updates. (Armando L. Sanchez, Chris Sweda, Jose M. Osorio / Chicago Tribune | @mandophotos @joseochicagotrib) #humboldtgator #alligator #humboldtpark #🐊

Decked out in red, white and blue jerseys, American flag shorts and stars-and-stripes leggings, thousands of Chicagoans rallied behind the USA at the World Cup watch party in Lincoln Park. ⠀
⠀
With a 2-0 victory over the Netherlands on Sunday, the U.S. women’s national soccer team won the World Cup and several thousand supporters in a tree-shaded corner of Lincoln Park came out to witness the broadcast on the big screen. Several fans also wore “Equal Pay” T-shirts in support of the team’s push for fair pay in comparison with their male counterparts. ⠀
⠀
The women won the World Cup for the second straight time, and their fourth overall, while the men’s national team has never won the globe’s most prestigious soccer tournament. Click the link in our bio for more photos and the full story. (Camille Fine / Chicago Tribune | @camillefine) #FIFAWWC #USWNT #OneNationOneTeam @chitribsports

Their day jobs vary. A graphic artist, an accountant, a coder. One has a background in architecture, another a business degree. The thing they all have in common: On the weekends, they strip. ⠀
⠀
If the 2012 film “Magic Mike” gave a fictional glimpse into the world of male entertainers, Hunk-O-Mania, a New York-based entertainment company that specializes in male strippers and dancers, is the real deal. The men of Hunk-O-Mania Chicago produce 100 shows a year, holidays included, in a variety of venues across the city. Each show features five acts of 15-minute dance routines. Performers choose their own costumes and clothing (or lack thereof) based on personal interests. ⠀
⠀
“When people think male dancer, I think everyone thinks male bimbo. That’s everybody’s perception,” said Brian Maldonado, 32. “Even though a lot of the guys I work with are educated and multifaceted.” ⠀
⠀
Single and married, entrepreneurs and military veterans — each of the men have different reasons for joining the company, which operates 52 weeks a year. People also assume the job easy, but that’s not true, says 25-year-old Avelino Martinez, aka Romeo Suave, a dancer of eight years, pictured in photo 2. ⠀
⠀
“It is really psychological,” he said. “It’s mental — you have to look like you’re carefree, but in reality, you’re always strategizing, always assessing the customer base, and trying to feel out and understand what people are comfortable and not comfortable with.” Click the link in our bio for the full story. (John J. Kim/Chicago Tribune | @johnkimpictures)

In roughly 33 minutes, Mauyak, a 38-year-old beluga whale, gave birth to a 5-foot-long, 150-pound calf at Chicago’s Shedd Aquarium Wednesday night. ⠀
⠀
The birth was Mauyak’s fourth, but her first — as well as the aquarium’s — since 2012. Staffers monitoring the proceedings saw Mauyak’s motherhood experience shine through as she and her offspring quickly achieved all the early milestones including the newborn’s first breath and nursing. The calf’s sex is still unknown. Before Wednesday’s birth, Shedd kept seven belugas in its pod, so they won’t know which male is the newborn’s father until a DNA test can be done. ⠀
⠀
“It couldn’t have been more beautifully done by Mauyak,” said Peggy Sloan, chief animal operations officer. “Just textbook.” ⠀
⠀
Some animal-rights activists contend it is cruel to keep the large mammals in the confines of an aquarium pool, while the Shedd argues it is important to educate the public about this bellwether species for climate change and to pass on knowledge gleaned from the close observation of captive animals to people helping care for them in the wild — such as sharing photographs of Mauyak during her approximately 15-month pregnancy with researchers, which should help them spot pregnant animals in open water. ⠀
⠀
The mother and calf are back on public display this weekend. Click the link in our bio for the full story. (Peter Tsai / Chicago Tribune | @petetsai) #belugawhale #whale #aquarium #marineanimals

From North Mayfair to Hyde Park, Chicagoans of all ages celebrated the Fourth of July on Thursday. The summer’s unpredictable weather cooperated as thousands celebrated under sunny skies with parades, barbecues and fireworks. Click the link in our bio for more photos. (Erin Hooley, Abel Uribe, Stacey Wescott and Camille Fine / Chicago Tribune | @malarchy @staceywescott27 @camillefine) #july4th #4thofjuly

Illinois’ first capital is an island that’s home to just 18 people. This isolated village, where history runs deep, is an oddity even during dry weather. ⠀
⠀
Kaskaskia, the capital of Illinois from 1818 until 1820, has been severed from the rest of the state for more than 135 years, when the Mississippi River took the path of least resistance and cut a new route to the east, leaving the town stranded alone on the west side of the river. The once powerful epicenter of Illinois government has been even more isolated from the rest of the country since April, when floodwaters swamped the lone link to the island. Because most of the island’s 14,000 acres are surrounded by levees to protect it from the powerful flow of the Mississippi, the water has nowhere to go. ⠀
⠀
“The water can’t go anywhere because the river’s so high,” Chester Wingerter, the site superintendent for the state historic sites in and near Kaskaskia, said. “It’s not necessarily the river, it’s the rain water.” ⠀
⠀
Residents have been forced to choose between an elaborate and inconvenient system of transportation or seek temporary living options with friends and family. Those who have remained in their homes must plan ahead for groceries or medicine, since there is no store on the island, only a collection of homes, barns, workshops and the historic buildings of the village. ⠀
⠀
The attraction of place — the farms passed down among generations, the memories and the uniqueness of the location — it’s all too strong for residents to leave behind. Click the link in our bio for the full story. (Zbigniew Bzdak / Chicago Tribune | @bzdak) #history #dronephotography

The 2-1 U.S. win delighted most of the estimated 1,000 people gathered in front of a giant video screen in Lincoln Parkin to watch Tuesday's U.S.-England World Cup semifinal. ⠀
⠀
After a path that took the Americans through hosts France in the quarterfinals and England in the semis, the U.S. is now one win away from repeating as World Cup champions. Click the link in our bio for the full story. (John J. Kim / Chicago Tribune | @johnkimpictures) #FIFAWWC #ENGUSA #USWNT #OneNationOneTeam

In the 50 years since a brick thrown at the Stonewall Inn started a riot and catapulted a movement, members of the LGBTQ community have marched down Halsted Street in Chicago led by all sorts of exceptional grand marshals — a Puerto Rican boxing champ, TV stars, former NFL players. ⠀
⠀
But on Sunday afternoon, there was a grand marshal who made history: Chicago’s first openly gay mayor. ⠀
⠀
Before Mayor Lori Lightfoot tipped her hat to an endless wave of paradegoers — and a 90-degree day ended in a downpour that caused the parade’s historic anniversary to be cut short — she reflected on her political journey from marcher to mayor. ⠀
⠀
“It feels like I’ve come a long way,” she said. “Our battles are not over, but today feels particularly sweet.” ⠀
⠀
At 2:25 p.m. the parade was called due to severe thunderstorms that brought the threat of strong winds, hail and intense rainfall, but not before colorful floats, animated performers and special guests made their way down the route. Click the link in our bio for the full story. (Brian Cassella and Camille Fine / Chicago Tribune | @briancassella @camillefine) #pride #chicagopride

City officials, dog owners and their four-legged friends made it to Calumet Park for the official opening of the first Park District dog park on the South Side, Calumet Bark. ⠀
⠀
Chicken, a 12-year-old Labrador mix, pictured in the third photo, was the first to go in and pace the perimeter, quickly marking his territory. Right behind him was Bear, an 11-year-old flat-coated retriever, also pictured with Chicken, who moseyed around the park. ⠀
⠀
In Chicago, designated dog-friendly areas, or dog parks, are the only public areas where canines can legally run off-leash. Of the city’s 25 Park District dog parks, 22 are on the North Side. Two are in the South Loop, and Calumet Bark is the first to open south of 18th Street. But dog parks are more than a space where dogs can legally run freely. Their presence, or lack thereof, is symbolic of a larger issue: a chasm between the North and South sides, said Jocelyn Rangel, a member of the Southeast Chicago Dog Park Committee. ⠀
⠀
“A dog park may seem like a little thing, but it can serve as a catalyst for more change,” she said. “We’re a vibrant community with families.” ⠀
⠀
Dog parks in the Bronzeville and McKinley Park neighborhoods are now in the planning stages. Click the link in our bio for the full story. (Jose M. Osorio / Chicago Tribune | @joseochicagotrib)

On clear, sunny days, The 606 offers everything its drafters likely imagined when it was first conceived: A diverse group of bicyclists, joggers and pedestrians share the commuter bridge that crosses four bustling Northwest Side neighborhoods along its 2.7-mile path. ⠀
⠀
In the light of day, The 606′s tranquil setting makes it an easy choice as a meeting place. But after dark is another story, according to many. A relatively small number of criminal incidents are connected to the trail, officials said. But the recent gang-related shooting death of a young father on the trail, the first since its opening in 2015, has cast a pall over the elevated pathway. ⠀
⠀
Statistics from police suggest it is hardly a trouble spot. Thirty-three criminal incidents — including the May homicide — have been reported on the trail between its opening in 2015 through mid-June this year. But the demographics have changed on the western end of The 606 in recent years, as more affluent white families, young professionals, and trendy restaurants and bars have moved into the neighborhood. ⠀
⠀
As a result, critics say the trail has become emblematic of the city’s struggle to invest resources in cash-strapped neighborhoods, creating a divided playground connected to rising rents, gentrification and displacement. Click the link in our bio for the full story. (Armando L. Sanchez / Chicago Tribune | @mandophotos)

Javier Baez flailed at a 1-2 slider, his second whiff of the game, and screamed at himself as he descended the steps to the Cubs dugout on Sunday, June 23. ⠀
⠀
Then he channeled that rage in a way that was quintessential Javy. ⠀
⠀
With the Cubs in danger of losing their third straight to the Mets, he pounced on a fat 0-2 breaking ball and launched it into the right-field bleachers. The three-run bomb flipped the script, delivered a 5-3 victory and kept the Cubs in first place in the National League Central. ⠀
⠀
On what felt like the first day of summer at Wrigley Field, the crowd of 39,077 demanded a curtain call — and got one. Click the link in our bio for more photos and the full story. (Brian Cassella / Chicago Tribune | @briancassella) #cubs @chitribsports

As beads of sweat dripped down his forehead, Yo-Yo Ma, famed cellist extraordinaire, carefully lowered a magnolia sapling into the ground at Unity Park in North Lawndale. Using a wheelbarrow to pour dirt around the base, he packed down the earth with a shovel created by artist Pedro Reyes, who had forged it using repurposed weapons originally seized by the Chicago Police Department. ⠀
⠀
“There’s something about the word ‘cultivation’ that means everything to me,” Ma said, after the tree was successfully in the ground. “That’s the word that’s formed from ‘culture.’ It’s what we invent, what we build in order to live and to have hope.” ⠀
⠀
TMa seeks to cultivate art and discussion in communities around the world through the Bach Project, his tour of 36 cities and six different continents that seeks to explore how culture can better society. At each destination, Ma works with community leaders to organize a “Day of Action” that examines an prevailing issue. In Chicago, Ma asked, “How can we use culture to confront gun violence in the city?” ⠀
⠀
Click the link in our bio for the full story. (Zbigniew Bzdak / Chicago Tribune | @bzdak) #cultureconnectsus #yoyoma

When Lincoln Park’s Zoo’s last baby rhino, King, was born in 2013, he became something of a web sensation. Juvenile rhinoceroses, if you hadn’t noticed, exist somewhere on the border between prehistoric and adorable. It is a winning combination. ⠀
⠀
King is now a healthy juvenile transferred to suburban Brookfield Zoo. And Lincoln Park’s new arrival, another male, yet to be named, is the newest in the family of Eastern black rhinoceroses, a species critically endangered in the African wild. Mom Kapuki, 13, who also gave birth to King, is the newborn’s constant companion in these early weeks of life and will be for the next couple of years. The sire in both cases is Maku, now 33, kept in a separate enclosure. ⠀
⠀
The young’un, who was born May 19, was seen via video monitors standing at less than an hour old and has been developing nicely, according to zoo staff. Click the link in our bio for the full story. (Antonio Perez / Chicago Tribune | @apereztribune) #babyrhino #rhinoconservation #zooanimals

Charlie Whitmer spent his first Father’s Day in the neonatal intensive care unit, watching over his triplets. The day before, he attended the funeral of his wife, Kathryn, who died from complications of a stroke she suffered a week before giving birth. ⠀
⠀
His red-headed, blue-eyed babies just celebrated their first birthday, and now Charlie is learning how to parent Bobby, J.P. and their sister, Arden, as a single father, while channeling their mother’s giving spirit. He left his job as an options trader to focus solely on his kids. It’s not the life he had planned, “but my dreams changed when Kathryn passed.” ⠀
⠀
There’s no shortage of people to help Charlie with the awesome and inherently chaotic responsibility of caring for three babies. His house is often filled with visitors: friends, family and nannies. A spiritual man who is used to working with numbers, Charlie said he doesn’t believe in bad luck and that there must be a reason for his family’s profound loss. ⠀
⠀
“You have to find hope, and you have to find some kind of joy,” he said. “All of this happened for a reason. It’s my job to find that.” Click the link in our bio for the full story. (Erin Hooley / Chicago Tribune | @malarchy) #fathersday #triplets #parenting

Sunday will be Amelie Liu’s seventh Father’s Day without her dad and Grace Bauer’s second. ⠀
⠀
Amelie’s dad, Donald Liu, was a pediatric surgeon at University of Chicago Medicine’s Comer Children’s Hospital. He drowned in Lake Michigan while saving the lives of two boys who were caught in a treacherous current in August 2012. Grace’s dad, Paul Bauer, was a Chicago police commander who was shot and killed in the Loop while pursuing a suspect in February 2018. ⠀
⠀
Now the girls, both 14, are finishing eighth grade, ready to head to high school, and they’ve teamed up on a project to help other teenagers who’ve lost a parent feel less alone in their grief. ⠀
⠀
“Losing a parent is such a huge thing in your life,” Amelie said. “Sometimes it doesn’t hit you hard, and sometimes it does. I want people to know about this community and know they don’t have to share anything if they’re not comfortable, but if they do, it’s a safe space.” ⠀
⠀
Shortly after Grace’s dad was killed, Amelie’s mom contacted Grace’s mom to offer her support. She knew what it felt like to lose a husband, for children to lose a father, in such a sudden, public way. The two families eventually got together, and it was then that Amelie and Grace decided to revive Surviving Life After a Parent Dies, a website launched by Amelie’s older sister in 2014. Only now they want to move it away from a static website to be an app with a strong social media component. ⠀
⠀
“We want to connect a bunch of people through the one experience that changed the whole course of their life,” Grace said. Click the link in our bio for the full story. (Brian Cassella/Chicago Tribune | @briancassella)

Molly Currey and Jim Jacoby were both recently divorced and living separately when their future Logan Square home popped up on an internet search. ⠀
⠀
The former Catholic church, built in 1890, had been converted to a single-family home whose original owners restored it from St. Hedwig’s Mission Church in the early 1990s and lived there for 20 years. ⠀
⠀
“When we walked in and saw it, it was one of those moments where we had to figure this out. These types of homes don’t come along very often,” Currey said. “This might sound a little crazy, but we feel like the house found us.” ⠀
⠀
Places of worship that once thrived are re-emerging with “for sale” signs across the city as attendance continues to dwindle. A spokesperson for the Archdiocese of Chicago said the archdiocese often sells churches to other denominations, but across the country, many have been converted to residential, educational or community use, or demolished for redevelopment. ⠀
⠀
Currey described the home as a giant loft space with a two-part basement, calling it a “quirky home that we knew we could share with our family in entirely new ways.” Click the link in our bio for the full story. (Jose M. Osario / Chicago Tribune | @joseochicagotrib) #homerenovation #architecture #churcharchitecture #chicagohistory

Justin Pierce fought long and hard for a seat in his gleaming downtown office building. ⠀
⠀
Pierce, who has Asperger’s syndrome, a high-functioning form of autism, laid out the numbers: 328 applications, 135 rejection letters and 14 interviews, resulting finally — after almost five years — in his first professional job offer, as part of a technology team at the Chicago office of Ernst & Young. ⠀
⠀
“It was like winning the lottery or finally getting your Cinderella story happy ending,” said Pierce, 31. ⠀
⠀
The unemployment rate is estimated at 66 percent or more for people with autism — a developmental disability that affects communication and social interaction — but thanks to a new program at EY, Pierce and 14 of his Chicago co-workers are beating the odds. The company tried recruiting high-functioning autistic people, who can have very strong technical skills and the ability to manage large amounts of data. In a pilot program, autistic employees showed they could learn new technologies very quickly and apply them in powerful and unexpected ways. ⠀
⠀
“This is a talent pool that we think can be an integral part of helping us build and thrive,” said Hiren Shukla, director of the program. Click the link in our bio for the full story. (Jose M. Osorio/Chicago Tribune | @joseochicagotrib)

When Daisy Feidt took her 4-year-old daughter, Ana Tow, to Styles 4 Kidz to get her hair braided for the first time, the little girl requested a style she had seen in a book. ⠀
⠀
“We had been reading a book to her about a black girl who has beads that click and clack, so that was her request when she first came in,” said Feidt, a white woman who, with her Latina wife, Berenice Tow, adopted Ana, an African American, when she was two days old. ⠀
⠀
After Ana got the beads, Feidt remembers that the little girl couldn’t help but look at herself, pose and show off her new style to her friends and day care workers. “She was just really proud of it,” Feidt said. ⠀
⠀
Styles 4 Kidz provides hair care education and styling services for African American children in transracial adoptive families and foster care. South Side native Tamekia Swint founded the nonprofit organization in 2013 after noticing the hair of girls who were transracially adopted or in foster care group homes. ⠀
⠀
She knew she had to to do something to help kids like Ana Tow and Maggie Mead, both in transracial families and pictured getting their hair done. Click the link in our bio for the full story. (Youngrae Kim / for the Chicago Tribune | @raeraekim)

Where do you start when 100 years of football history comes flooding down the orange carpet? You start at the Donald E. Stephens Convention Center in Rosemont, where the Chicago Bears are celebrating a century of history this weekend. ⠀
⠀
“It’s a hell of an organization,” said Hall of Fame member Dick Butkus. “I get a kick out of all these players who say how great the fans are in Tampa Bay or Seattle. I’m like, ‘Give me a break, man!’ They must not have been here in Chicago.” ⠀
⠀
Saturday’s Bears100 Celebration was a daylong walk down memory lane. For this franchise, that colorful road winds through eight NFL championship teams and one Super Bowl championship. It’s lined with dozens of memorable players and personalities, including Mike Singletary, Mike Ditka (and his cigar), Virginia McCaskey, Devin Hester, Butkus, Matt Forte, Jim McMahon, Mitch Trubisky and Gale Sayers — just to name a few. ⠀
⠀
The euphoria and appreciation continues Sunday until 12 p.m. Click the link in our bio for live updates, recaps and what to know if you go. (Chris Sweda and John J. Kim / Chicago Tribune | @johnkimpictures) #bears #dabears #beardown #bears100 #chicagobears

When James “Lil" James” Collins was 16 years old, a trip to grab a bite to eat ended with his older brother dying before his eyes. His brother pushed him back into a gangway to save him, he recalled, as he sat there listening while shots continued to ring out. ⠀
⠀
Nine more people in his life would be killed by gun violence by the time Collins was 18. Traumatized, he started carrying a gun every day — until an aggravated unlawful use of weapon charge got him six months in Cook County Jail and seven days in an Illinois Department of Corrections facility. ⠀
⠀
In hopes of changing the trajectory of Collins’ life, an uncle told him about the Inner-City Muslim Action Network (IMAN), which helps men reintegrate after incarceration. ⠀
⠀
“This program saved my life,” Collins said in an interview. “I always thought I’d be a statistic, either dead or in jail. They actually care; they ain’t just talk,” he said. “They help you out in so many ways: housing, clothes, food, whatever. I never met anybody who asked you, ‘What’s going on in your life?’ and actually try to help me change it.” ⠀
⠀
There have been myriad programs aimed at breaking the cycle of violence — some focusing on education, others focusing on jobs. But Green ReEntry is hoping a program built around the whole person — mental health, behavior, job training, housing assistance — will decrease recidivism and gun violence while building healthy communities. Click the link in our bio for the full story. (Abel Uribe / Chicago Tribune)

A partial train derailment Thursday in the Bronzeville neighborhood on the South Side that sent seven people to hospitals is expected to disrupt service on the CTA Green Line for much of the afternoon into rush hour. ⠀
⠀
An “L” train derailed near 47th Street around 11 a.m. with 30 people on board. Officials said 23 people refused treatment and seven people were taken to area hospitals for minor injuries. The remaining passengers were helped down from the elevated train by about 80 firefighters who were called to the derailment, said Larry Merritt, a Chicago Fire Department spokesman. ⠀
⠀
Bus shuttle service was available between Ashland/63rd-Cottage Grove and Roosevelt. A number of buses in the area can provide access to other rail lines, the CTA said. Click the link in our bio for the full story. (Terrence Antonio James / Chicago Tribune) #cta #commute #rushhour

After school on Wednesdays, about 50 boys gather behind Granger Middle School in Aurora, where the parking lot becomes a cricket field, chairs become wickets, and a cultural tradition is shared among peers. ⠀
⠀
“I always like playing it,” said Sameer, a sixth-grader who started playing cricket at age 4. “We all talk about it at school. I tell other students: ‘You should play cricket. So many kids do it. It’s the thing for our culture. You should try it and see if you like it.’ ” ⠀
⠀
The Asian student population has risen at Granger from 21 percent in 2014 to 31 percent in 2018, more than six times the state average. Sameer is one of the middle school boys who have embraced the club sport that has grown since its first “season” in 2013. ⠀
⠀
While the middle school doesn’t break down student demographics by nationality or ethnicity, Cindy Chejfec, a foreign language teacher who supervises the club, said about 20 percent of the students are of Indian descent. ⠀
⠀
Once the students at Granger expressed interest in starting a club to play cricket, the school realized the club would benefit its changing population. Click the link in our bio for the full story. (Brian Cassella / Chicago Tribune | @briancassella)

On a winding road on the outskirts of a small Rust Belt town in eastern Indiana, a fish hatchery is poised to raise the country’s first genetically engineered animal approved for human consumption by the U.S. Food and Drug Administration. ⠀
⠀
AquaBounty Technologies, a Massachusetts-based biotechnology company, altered the genetic makeup of the Atlantic salmon to include a gene from chinook salmon and DNA sequence from an eel-like species known as an ocean pout. The result is a salmon that grows to market size about twice as fast as its natural counterpart. ⠀
⠀
The company, which already breeds the salmon in Canada, received its first batch of bioengineered eggs last week at its indoor facility in Albany, Indiana, and the first salmon fillets raised there could appear in U.S. supermarkets in late 2020. AquaBounty’s decision to raise the salmon in Indiana is a landmark moment for the Midwest, a region known globally for its agricultural prowess but one where land-based fish farming operations have struggled mightily to become profitable. Click the link in our bio for the full story. (Zbigniew Bzdak/Chicago Tribune | @bzdak)

Pride month is here and visitors and residents of Boystown can start walking on rainbows. ⠀
⠀
Fourteen crosswalks representing LGBT pride are being installed along Halsted Street. Thirteen will use the colors of the rainbow, while the already-completed crosswalk at Melrose has the pink, white and blue colors of the transgender flag. The area is known for its mix of LGBT bars and other businesses, and is the center of the Chicago Pride Parade, which will celebrate its 50th year this summer. ⠀
⠀
“As the gay and lesbian community has become more visible citywide, we want to be sure this historic street remains welcoming to the LGBT community and preserves the history of the LGBT community in Lakeview,” said Ald. Tom Tunney. ⠀
⠀
The approximately $60,000 cost is being funded entirely through the Northalsted Business Alliance, using donations received at neighborhood festivals. Click the link in our bio to read the full story. (Jose M. Osorio/Chicago Tribune | @joseochicagotrib) #lgbt #pride

Paw by paw, about 30 dogs rescued from Oklahoma emerged from their crates with the help of volunteers as they arrived at their temporary home in Chicago. ⠀
⠀
The dogs — varying in age and breed — arrived at PAWS Chicago’s medical center in the Little Village neighborhood after making a 15-hour trip by car from Oklahoma. In the past week, Oklahoma experienced two tornadoes — one near Oklahoma City and another in a suburb of Tulsa — and flooding in Muskogee County caused the evacuations of more than 2,400 people. The influx of animals after a natural disaster often causes shelters to run out of space.⠀
⠀
Most of the puppies brought to Chicago were living outside and never got vaccines. Once in Chicago, the dogs undergo a medical evaluation, some go to foster homes to allow time to get healthy enough to be spayed or neutered and all of them will eventually be moved to the organization’s adoption centers.

Click the link in our bio to read the full story and learn how to adopt or foster with PAWS. (Antonio Perez/Chicago Tribune) #adoptdontshop #rescuedog #rescuedogsofinstagram #puppiesofinstagram

At a time of fraught debate about immigration and national identity, the hijab — or Muslim headscarf — has become a flashpoint and a symbol of solidarity. In response to many high-profile incidents, the Tribune interviewed six Chicago-area women about why they wear the hijab, what it means to them, and what kinds of reactions they get.⠀
⠀
“Hijab is part of me, a part of who I am, something I can call basically home,” said Saeda Sulieman (photo 1) a college student from Oak Lawn. When asked her if she felt different wearing a headscarf, she told her friends she felt more confident because she was acting on her beliefs. ⠀
⠀
While the Muslim holy book, the Quran, does not explicitly require head covering, it does call on Muslims — both men and women — to be modest in speech, action and self-presentation. Some Muslim women believe they are required to wear the hijab, while others do not. It can be a signal to others that you demand respect. The hijab can be a very American assertion of the right to self-expression. It can be flat-out feminist. ⠀
⠀
“It’s a big ‘screw you’ to beauty standards, you know?” said graduate student Naima Zaheer (photo3) of Oak Brook. “Sometimes we buy into the idea that we’re not enough, that we have to do a certain thing a certain way to be considered beautiful, and I feel like this is a way to say, ‘No, I’m just going to be who I am.‘” ⠀
⠀
While some women reported overwhelmingly positive reactions to their hijabs, others detailed negative encounters. Click the link in our bio to read the full story. (Raquel Zaldivar / Chicago Tribune | @raqzal)

It’s no surprise May has been a waterlogged mess in Chicago, with severe thunderstorm alerts almost daily and weeks of flooded streets and swollen rivers. ⠀
⠀
If you’re wondering if the area has actually received more rain than usual this month or if your vitamin D-deprived brain is playing tricks on you, it’s the former. The National Weather Service said Wednesday that 2019 is expected to break a record for the wettest May since 1870, when meteorologists began keeping records in Chicago. ⠀
⠀
The forecast for the remainder of the week calls for a round of thunderstorms late Wednesday into Thursday, and meteorologists again expect heavy rainfall from the system with “strong to severe” storms. Click the link in our bio for updated weather coverage. (Armando L. Sanchez / Chicago Tribune | @mandophotos)

Memorial Day is meant to honor America’s fallen warriors, but at two Chicago services Monday, the thoughts of many were also with the living — veterans of conflicts old and new, whose needs, some say, have not been fully met by their country. ⠀
⠀
“A lot of veterans get a real bad taste with the Veterans Administration,” said Peter Kukurba, who was twice wounded while serving with the Marine Corps in Vietnam. “They’re getting pushed, put on wait lists. They should be No. 1 for everything. They’re suffering mentally and physically.” ⠀
⠀
He spoke just after a service at Rosehill Cemetery on the North Side, where among the 190,000 interments are veterans of conflicts ranging from the Revolutionary War to Afghanistan. Meanwhile, at a wreath-laying ceremony in Grant Park, Mayor Lori Lightfoot and Cook County Board President Toni Preckwinkle shared their thoughts on fallen service members and their surviving comrades as the Junior ROTC Color Guard from Sean High School stood at attention. ⠀
⠀
“We cannot have our veterans out on the streets at night,” Lightfoot said. “We must do everything we can to support them.” Click the link in our bio for the full story. (Brian Cassella and Jose M. Osorio / Chicago Tribune | @briancassella @joseochicagotrib) #memorialday #veterans #memorialdayweekend

In February, the Indiana Dunes joined a small group of destinations east of the Mississippi River that hold an elite title, becoming America’s 61st national park. ⠀
⠀
Strung between steel mills and rumbling trains, blanketed by oak savannas and lined with wild lupine, the Indiana Dunes National Park is a Midwestern mix of harsh and wonderful. Some national park fans are confused about how the relatively small park surrounded by factories, marked for years by pollution and decay, got lumped in with Yellowstone and Yosemite. For those who worked for more than a century to solidify the national park title, staging pageants and lobbying for legislation longer than it took to build the Great Pyramid of Giza, the name means a lot — even if it doesn’t technically mean anything. ⠀
⠀
The park title doesn’t come with more money or resources, especially as the park service is expected to face a 15 percent budget cut in the coming year. But as soon as the change went through, rangers posed for a photo with a makeshift cardboard sign, replacing “Lakeshore” with “Park” to make it official. On a May weekend between activities for the Birding Festival, patrons picked the new “National Park” stamp over the half-dozen other available stamps to add to their national park passports. ⠀
⠀
Ranked in the top 10 in biodiversity among more than 400 places overseen by the park service, the Indiana Dunes are bracing for hundreds of thousands more visitors this summer season. Click the link in our bio to read the full story. (Zbigniew Bzdak / Chicago Tribune | @bzdak) #dunes #indiana #nationalpark

On May 25, 1979, an engine broke away from the left wing of a DC-10 during takeoff at O’Hare Airport. After 31 seconds of flight, the plane plunged back to earth, killing all 258 passengers, 13 crew members and two people on the ground. The wreckage strafed an open field and mobile home park, scattering debris and erupting into flames. Forty years later, American Airlines Flight 191 remains the deadliest aviation accident on U.S. soil. ⠀
⠀
Kevin Moncrieff, pictured above in the field where the plane went down, was 7 years old when his father died in the tragic crash. Today he is a Boeing 737 captain for United Airlines. ⠀
⠀
“It’s quite unusual, I think, for someone to become a pilot and be based where your father died in an accident, flying over it every week,” he said. ⠀
⠀
In the years since the tragedy of Flight 191, the accident has helped spur reforms that contributed to the improvements in commercial aviation safety we see today. Click the link in our bio for the full story. (Stacey Wescott / Chicago Tribune | @staceywescott27)

As Lori Lightfoot completed her ascension Monday from a long-shot candidate to Chicago’s first black woman and openly gay mayor, the former federal prosecutor stood in front of thousands at a crowded arena and vowed to fundamentally transform a city government that for months has operated under the cloud of an ongoing federal public corruption investigation. ⠀
⠀
Moments after placing her hand on the Bible and taking the oath of office, Lightfoot bluntly promised to restore integrity to a city government and City Council that has at times been hobbled by allegations against some of its highest-ranking members. Her fiery speech drew numerous standing ovations from a raucous crowd, but also potentially set the stage for future conflict with aldermen as they prepare to jointly tackle some of the city’s other lingering problems — massive budget shortfalls and endemic violent crime. ⠀
⠀
“For years, they’ve said Chicago ain’t ready for reform. Well, get ready because reform is here,” Lightfoot said in her inaugural address. “I campaigned on change, you voted for change and I plan to deliver change to our government. That means restoring trust in our city’s government and finally bringing some real integrity to the way this city works.” ⠀
⠀
Click the link in our bio for more photos and the full story. (Brian Cassella and Jose M. Osorio / Chicago Tribune | @briancassella @joseochicagotrib) #ChicagoInaugural

Eight years ago on a brisk morning in Millennium Park, Rahm Emanuel held up his right hand, swore to honorably discharge the duties as mayor of America’s third-largest city and then declared the dawn of “a new day for Chicago.” ⠀
⠀
“Stronger schools, safer streets, an affordable and effective government, good-paying jobs. These are the fundamental challenges facing our city,” Emanuel said that day. “If we can get these things right, nothing can stop Chicago.” ⠀
⠀
Emanuel will leave office Monday with a mixed record on those four key issues he vowed to fix. ⠀
⠀
Through it all, Emanuel governed with a consistent chutzpah, deploying an in-your-face political persona he honed over his previous decades working at the White House and in Congress to pressure aldermen into backing his agenda, cajole business and union leaders into cutting deals and solicit tens of millions of dollars in campaign contributions that served as the bedrock of his political power. Click the link in our bio for the full story. (Brian Cassella / Chicago Tribune | @briancassella)

The ninth month of the Islamic calendar, Ramadan, considered a holy month, often poses a challenge in endurance for those who participate — and a particular difficulty for Muslims with disabilities. ⠀
⠀
Ramadan is meant to be a time of slowing down and spiritual connection, and most Muslims refrain from eating or drinking anything — even water — from dawn to sunset. Many mosques hold extra prayers in the evenings for people who attempt to read and recite the entirety of the Quran throughout the month.

In the past, Muslims who have disabilities or chronic health issues often felt left out of these rituals, which are meant to encourage togetherness. But many who struggle with fasting or praying during the month have found alternative ways to participate with their communities that allow them to uphold the values Ramadan is meant to encourage.

Omer Zaman was diagnosed with muscular dystrophy when he was 17, and soon it was painful for him to pray standing up. For a while, he continued to pray on his feet, like everyone else, for fear of being accused of trying to get out of prayers. As he struggled with movement and strength in his early 20s, he said he became a hermit, retreating to the back of the mosque for prayers and avoiding talking to people.

When he finally felt able to engage in his faith again, he started attending a different mosque. His presence there, he said, is encouraged by other members who, like his family, support him being there. Zaman is able to park his wheelchair behind chairs set up for those who need them on the right side of the men’s prayer hall at Islamic Center of Wheaton, where he prays some Friday afternoons. He greets members he knows from his wheelchair as he enters the prayer space and feels part of the mosque community. ⠀
⠀
“I needed that social interaction,” he said. “I wanted to hear someone else’s prayer.” Click the link in our bio to read the full story. (Zbigniew Bzdak/Chicago Tribune | @bzdak) #ramadan

Marlen Ochoa-Lopez was promised a stroller and baby clothes. Instead, police say she was strangled before her unborn child was cut from her womb.
⠀
The 19-year-old went missing on April 23 after leaving Latino Youth High School and had one quick errand to run before picking up her 3-year-old son from day care. Nine months pregnant, Ochoa-Lopez drove to a home on the Southwest Side where a woman she met through Facebook was offering a double stroller and baby clothes for a little boy. ⠀
⠀
Once inside the home, police say Ochoa-Lopez was strangled before her baby boy was cut from her womb. But the newborn had problems breathing, and the woman who had lured Ochoa-Lopez to the home made a frantic 911 call claiming she had given birth and the baby was “pale and blue.” The baby was rushed to a hospital, where the teen’s family say the boy is brain-dead but still hooked up to life support. Police said detectives found coaxial cable used to strangle Ochoa-Lopez in the same garbage can in which her body was discovered behind the Southwest Side home.
⠀
“Why did these people, why did these bad people do this? She did nothing to them,” said Yovani Lopez, Ochoa-Lopez’s 20-year-old husband. “She was a good person.” ⠀
⠀
Clarisa Figueroa, 46, and her daughter, Desiree, 24, were both charged with one count each of first-degree murder and aggravated battery of a child causing permanent disability. Clarisa’s boyfriend, Piotr Bobak, 40, was charged with concealment of a homicide. Police said the younger Figueroa confessed to assisting her mother in strangling Ochoa-Lopez. ⠀
⠀
Authorities said Ochoa-Lopez had been to the residence in the past to purchase other items. The motive for the killing is unclear, but police Superintendent Eddie Johnson said “we can only assume” that the Figueroas planned to raise the baby as their own. Click the link in our bio for the full story. (Antonio Perez / Chicago Tribune) @apereztribune

When Millennium Park opened in 2004, the iron beginnings of Cloud Gate were already in sight, but it wasn’t until May 15, 2006 — 13 years ago Wednesday — that the reflective sculpture, known to most as The Bean, was officially dedicated to the park. ⠀
⠀
Sculptor Anish Kapoor said the idea behind his design was to create a shape that would lead viewers to the vortex underneath it. The artist also said he was surprised by the view that was ultimately reflected by the sculpture. ⠀
⠀
“I always knew we’d have views of the city, but I didn’t know how powerful it would be,” Kapoor said. ⠀
⠀
Click the link in our bio to take a look back at the sculpture’s first 13 years. (Armando L. Sanchez / Chicago Tribune | @mandophotos) #thebean #cloudgate #millenniumpark

Overnight Sunday in Lincoln Park Zoo’s Regenstein Center for African Apes, Rollie, a female gorilla born at Lincoln Park 22 years ago, gave birth to an apparently healthy male, the 53rd gorilla birth in the history of the North Side institution. ⠀
⠀
“It’s like when a (human) mom has a kid,” said Lincoln Park Zoo curator of primates Jill Moyse in front of the habitat for the zoo’s western lowland gorillas, a critically endangered species in its native Africa. “Even though this isn’t my first gorilla, I was really shocked and very excited.” ⠀
⠀
The zoo has two western lowland gorilla troops, a bachelor group and the one centered on silverback Kwan, 30, the father of the newborn. The last gorilla birth at the zoo was Bella in 2015, the daughter of Kwan and the female Bahati. ⠀
⠀
The mother is expected to keep her child close for at least a couple of months, Moyse said, and visitors should be able to see the pair amid the troop when outdoor displays reopen to the public beginning at noon Wednesday. Click the link in our bio for more photos and the full story. (Jose M. Osorio / Chicago Tribune | @joseochicagotrib)

BTS, a record-breaking K-pop group, came to Chicago for two sold-out concerts at Soldier Field over the Mother’s Day weekend as part of its “Love Yourself: Speak Yourself” world tour. ⠀
⠀
ARMY members (Adorable Representative MC for Youth — a moniker for the group’s dedicated fan base) have been preparing for weeks. By Friday, some were already in line to purchase official BTS tour merchandise outside the stadium. Others were driving from Kentucky and Ohio or arriving on trains and planes from New York, Kentucky and Texas, even Canada and Mexico. A pop-up store on State Street (launched last week and closes Monday) saw 3,700 fans come through the door Friday alone, according to staffers. ⠀
⠀
On Saturday morning, the Twitter hashtag #btsxchicago was trending before 8 a.m. as fans coordinated various meetups, photo ops and other tailgatelike activities ahead of their idols’ arrival. ⠀
⠀
“BTS fans are way more united than people think we are,” said Madalyn Rain, a photographer from Zion who organized a “family photo shoot” meetup of BTS fans. “People, they think K-pop and they’re like ‘Why?’ BTS has a message. They’re all about loving themselves, and every person here just showed they care about that message.” Click the link in our bio for the full story. (Erin Hooley / Chicago Tribune | @malarchy)  #bts #btsarmy #loveyourselftour

Chicago’s Insta-friendly wndr museum, which has been a surprise hit, re-opened this month with a new concept and new exhibits. ⠀
⠀
The start-up also makes a much stronger case for wearing the word “museum” in its title than it did when it opened in September. It’s gone from fewer than 20 exhibits to closer to 40, with an emphasis on buttons, touch and video screens, and even a paintbrush-wielding stationary bicycle, all aiming to put the visitor more firmly in the center of the action than before. ⠀
⠀
And give wndr credit, too, for being able to transition from experimental, pop-up status to something more permanent, for growing into its skin, for being a new kind of art museum. Click the link in our bio for the full review and ticket info. (Terrence Antonio James / Chicago Tribune)

Two-year-old Opal Lang had been hospitalized for more than 100 days when a doctor finally delivered the news: She was getting a new heart. Three days after her transplant, Opal’s mother also made a big delivery: Her new brother, Apollo, was born. ⠀
⠀
Priscilla Lang delivered her son at another hospital, but 24 hours later, they were back at the Ronald McDonald House in Chicago, where she and her husband, Tyler, have been staying since December when Opal was admitted to Lurie Children's Hospital. A week after Opal's heart transplant and the birth of the newest family member, the family is establishing a new normal. ⠀
⠀
Opal was a seemingly healthy baby when, at 15 months old, her pediatrician noticed her heart rate was irregular when she cried out or screamed. Doctors aren’t sure what exactly led to her health problems, but her heart was failing and she was deteriorating. Opal had an emergency pacemaker placed inside her when her heart stopped, and she later had a minor stroke. ⠀
⠀
On a recent afternoon, Priscilla and Tyler guided their daughter through her small hospital room overlooking the city as she learned how to walk. The only machine hooked up to her monitors her heart rhythm. Opal must continue to take medication to make sure her body doesn’t reject the heart, and she is at a higher risk for infections, but she should otherwise be able to live a normal life, doctors said.⠀
⠀
“I don’t know how they are going to keep her down,” said Dr. Osama Eltayeb, a cardiovascular surgeon who was on Opal’s heart transplant team. “She’s a happy kid. She’s just a normal kid. You can’t even tell that she had a transplant.” Click the link in our bio for the full story. (Brian Cassella / Chicago Tribune | @briancassella)

Addison Russell is back after completing a 40-game suspension for violating Major League Baseball’s domestic violence policy. ⠀
⠀
Months of therapy and the support of his employer helped save Russell’s career, which began a new chapter Wednesday night at Wrigley Field. Many Cubs fans booed Russell when he came to the plate in the third inning, and they booed again after he struck out. ⠀
⠀
“He should expect to face adversity along the way. He doesn’t deserve to be met with an unconditionally warm welcome and with open arms,” Cubs President Theo Epstein said before Wednesday’s game. “I think he will receive an appropriate response, and that’s something he needs to take responsibility for, to process, to handle the right way and to grow from.” ⠀
⠀
Russell was the Cubs’ starting shortstop for the last 3½ seasons before he was placed on administrative leave Sept. 21 after his ex-wife, Melisa Reidy, alleged on her blog that he physically and mentally abused her. ⠀
⠀
“We remained in touch with people who are important to him, people who are in his orbit, including Melisa, and I’ve received a lot of positive testimonials about Addison’s growth to this point,” Epstein said. “The improvement in his coping skills, emotional control and his communication skills and engagement as a father. There are positive signs to this point.” ⠀
⠀
Russell admitted he has been challenged by the responsibility of maintaining civil relationships with the mothers of his children while also facing media scrutiny and personal and baseball obligations in an effort to become a better person. Click the link in our bio for the full story. (Brian Cassella / Chicago Tribune | @briancassella) #cubs #mlb #baseball

After several days of what felt like winter, the city sprang into summer Sunday, at least ceremonially. ⠀
⠀
Buckingham Fountain’s signature display resumed at 2 p.m. and was celebrated as part of the “Switch On Summer” party that offered families a fun afternoon out during the weekend’s warmest weather. ⠀
⠀
The fountain first opened in 1927, and usually operates from early May through mid-October. Water displays occur for 20 minutes every hour, beginning at 9 a.m. ⠀
⠀
Though conditions were near-perfect for Sunday’s event, showers and thunderstorms are expected to hit the Chicago area Monday afternoon. Click the link in our bio for the full story. (Brian Cassella / Chicago Tribune | @briancassella)

Illinois Gov. J.B. Pritzker proposed a marijuana legalization bill Saturday that would allow possession of up to 30 grams, 5 plants grown at home, and expunge an estimated 800,000 low-level drug convictions.
⠀
The governor appeared alongside other lawmakers and stakeholders at the Black United Fund of Illinois in Chicago to introduce the bill, saying “Illinois is going to have the most equity-centric law in the nation.” Revenue from Illinois’ marijuana industry would be reinvested in communities that lawmakers said have been “devastated” by the nation’s war on drugs. Under the proposed rules, no new large-scale commercial growers would be permitted to set up shop here, at least for now. Instead, the focus would be on small “craft” growers, with an emphasis on helping people of color become entrepreneurs. ⠀
⠀
Of the tax revenue generated, 35 percent will go to the state General Fund, 25 percent for community reinvestment, 20 percent for mental health and substance abuse treatment, 10 percent for the state’s unpaid bills, 8 percent for law enforcement training grants, and 2 percent for public drug education. ⠀
⠀
Click the link in our bio to read the full story — including the bill summary. (Photos by Zbigniew Bzdak and Abel Uribe / Chicago Tribune | @bzdak) #marijuana #cannabis

Chicago street artists now have the option of taking an extra step to protect their work: stamping a city seal on their creation. ⠀
⠀
After several incidents last year in which street art was mistaken for vandalism and removed, the city has launched a public mural registry. But some question adding another layer of bureaucracy to what they say should be a purely creative process. ⠀
⠀
“I think they’re well-intentioned, but my background is as a graffiti artist — I just want to paint, man,” said Rahmaan “Statik” Barnes, a street artist from Woodlawn. “I think a lot of artists don’t really want to have to check in with someone to make sure their work isn’t whitewashed.” ⠀
⠀
The registry is expected to help the city raise its public art profile by providing a searchable database for tourists and locals as well as serve as a guide for city workers who sometimes are unable to differentiate between art and graffiti. Click the link in our bio for the full story.

Pictured above: the Muddy Waters mural by Brazilian street artist Eduardo Kobra. (Chris Sweda/ Chicago Tribune) #streetart #art #graffitiart #mural #urbanart

For the past six years, the team behind Lost Girls Vintage — co-owners Kyla Embrey and Sarah Azzouzi — have curated a collection of vintage clothing and accessories. Operating out of a 1976 Dodge RV camper (nicknamed Winnie) and an ice cream truck, they took to the streets by way of festivals, flea markets and pop-up shops. ⠀
⠀
“The beauty of vintage is that you can get pieces made of better materials,” Embrey said. “Something made of 100 percent silk or head-to-toe sequins that are going to be constructed better than something that is made today and also be more approachable in terms of a price point.” ⠀
⠀
Now, the duo has gone off-road and into their first brick-and-mortar store in West Town. The store sells clothes, small housewares and plants. And for the things that aren’t vintage, but handmade, Azzouzi and Embrey are making it a point to feature works solely by female artists — like Britteny Riordan of Luvsick Plus, who curates plus-size vintage clothing. ⠀
⠀
“We wanted to feature things in our shop that we feel speak to our customer and aesthetic,” Embrey said. “So it’s important for us to be working with women-identifying makers.” Click the link in our bio for the full story. (Jose M. Osorio / Chicago Tribune | @joseochicagotrib) #vintage #vintagefashion #vintageclothing @lostgirlsvintage

Last week, Bob Dwyer took his final communications exam — one of the last hurdles to becoming a college graduate. ⠀
⠀
The 90-year-old Chicago native is pursuing his degree in interdisciplinary studies at Northeastern Illinois University. When he graduates May 6, he will be the oldest student to receive his first bachelor’s degree since the school began keeping such records in 1962. ⠀
⠀
Dwyer has already lived a successful life. He was lucky in love, married for 56 years to his wife, Peggy, until her death in 2010. He had a lucrative career in manufacturing, which allowed him to provide for the couple’s nine children. They’re grown now with families of their own, giving Dwyer a fulfilling role as family patriarch. He has volunteered, traveled the globe extensively and served in the Army. ⠀
⠀
Pursuing his degree is something he has wanted to do for more than 70 years — not because he felt something was missing from his life, but because he wanted to enhance it.
⠀
”I have no regrets,” he said. “Basically, education is always a plus and we can never have too much of it.” Click the link in our bio for the full story. (Antonio Perez / Chicago Tribune | @apereztribune) #NEIU #decisionday #graduation

Twice a year White Sox fans get to bring their four-legged friends to the ballpark — and Monday was the first Dog Day of the season. Swipe right to see portraits of some of the good boys and girls in attendance and click the link in our bio for the full story. (E. Jason Wambsgans / Chicago Tribune | @ejwamb)

Vista Tower reached its final height last Friday, when construction workers poured concrete to form the Chicago skyscraper’s 101st and final floor. ⠀
⠀
That marked the highest point of construction in Chicago in more than a decade, and it brought Chicago’s Magellan Development Group closer to its planned spring 2020 completion of what will become the city’s third-tallest skyscraper. ⠀
⠀
Topping out the 1,191-foot-tall Vista Tower came more than a decade after Trump International Hotel & Tower reached its full height in August 2008, in the throes of a real estate crash. Trump’s 1,389-foot-tall condo and hotel tower, Chicago’s second-tallest building, was completed in 2009. ⠀
⠀
Swipe through to see views from the tower’s top floor and click the link in our bio for more info. (E. Jason Wambsgans / Chicago Tribune | @ejwamb)

Can the famously creative minds at Hamilton Inc. pull off their biggest gamble yet? ⠀
⠀
With the acclaimed set designer David Korins spinning the artistic roulette wheel, “Hamilton: The Exhibition” came to life Saturday — housed in a huge, bespoke, temporary building of some 35,000 square feet on Northerly Island. ⠀
⠀
No Broadway show ever has attempted anything like this — and certainly not some 800 miles from Manhattan. Then again, no Broadway show ever has put in motion the same kind of educational imperative as “Hamilton,” a musical about the founding of America itself that has historiography baked into its very identity. The interactive, experiential and immersive exhibition is a painstakingly detailed, visually imaginative and huge exploration of Alexander Hamilton and the birth of the American republic that he got swept up in and, in significant ways, helped to shape. ⠀
⠀
Care has been taken not to confuse “Hamilton: The Exhibition” with “Hamilton,” the musical. Indeed, you are reminded of the play throughout, in the music and in some of the top-line wall text, but you are not bludgeoned with it. And Lin-Manuel Miranda, as the major-domo over all of this, makes the right choice to have this exhibit repeatedly upstage his play on the matter of factuality. ⠀
⠀
While there have been other explorations of artifacts surrounding Hamilton that have piggybacked on his current popularity, only “Hamilton: The Exhibition” has authorized access to this material. Click the link in our bio for ticket info and a behind-the-scenes look at the exhibit. (Zbigniew Bzdak/Chicago Tribune | @bzdak) #hamilton #linmanuelmiranda

A rare late winter storm made its way across the Chicago area Saturday canceling more than 700 flights — and the Sox-Tigers game. ⠀
⠀
According to the National Weather Service snow accumulation will be anywhere from 3 to 8 inches, and will continue to fall overnight with temperatures dropping to 35 degrees. Click the link in our bio for up to date weather info. (John J. Kim / Chicago Tribune | @johnkimpictures)

An army of volunteers is trying to control Chicago’s feral cat population — and it looks like it’s working. ⠀
⠀
Chicago is home to an estimated 200,000 feral cats, and since 2007, the primary duty for managing that population has fallen to “colony caretakers” who are encouraged to trap strays and get them fixed. After that, the cats can be adopted or released back into their neighborhoods, a process known as “trap, neuter, release,” or TNR. ⠀
⠀
Though the program’s impact isn’t crystal clear — you try counting skittish, streetwise cats throughout the entire city — there’s some reason to believe it’s making a difference. The number of strays coming into the city’s animal shelter has fallen dramatically. More than 40,000 feral cats have been sterilized through the county’s TNR program since 2008, including 10,000 last year, and some caretakers say their colonies are shrinking. ⠀
⠀
PAWS Chicago, which does TNR on the South Side, tries to assist its volunteers with a pet food pantry. It also fixes cats at no cost to low-income residents. Click the link in our bio for the full story. (Zbigniew Bzdak / Chicago Tribune | @bzdak)

The parents of 5-year-old Andrew “AJ” Freund have been charged with his murder, after authorities found what they believe is the body of the Crystal Lake boy wrapped in plastic and buried in a shallow grave near Woodstock. ⠀
⠀
Police said both parents gave authorities information about the whereabouts of the boy’s body after officers analyzed cellphone records and confronted them with that information. Both JoAnn Cunningham, 36, and Andrew Freund, 60, face first-degree murder and battery charges.⠀
⠀
Back at the Freunds’ house, a makeshift front lawn memorial laden with toys and teddy bears began to form, and a candlelight vigil was attended by hundreds. ⠀
⠀
“It’s too close to home,” said Kelly Backer, 38, who lives with her three children nearby. “To do this to a child is totally wrong.” ⠀
⠀
Blue ribbons remained tied on poles around the neighborhood and a sign hung at a neighboring house said, “Pray for A.J.” Click the link in our bio for the full story. (John J. Kim / Chicago Tribune | @johnkimpictures)

Ryan Rucci enthusiastically pushed an elderly fan in a wheelchair up a ramp two weeks ago before the Wrigley Field home opener, a fitting reminder of what makes him more than just another Cubs guest services employee at Clark and Addison. ⠀
⠀
“You always dream about working for your favorite sports team, but you never think you’re going to,” Rucci, who is pictured in the first photo, said. “But I just feel like I’m the same as anyone else here. It doesn’t feel any different than another supervisor doing the same job. That’s also what’s cool about the Cubs — everyone just treats me like everyone else.‘’ ⠀
⠀
Rucci, 28, has cerebral palsy, a developmental disorder that affects muscle movement, motor skills and speech patterns of 500,000 children and adults in America. The disorder doesn’t stop the Cubs from hiring the right people like Rucci and Tanner Salinas, who also lives every day with CP. ⠀
⠀
In the upper deck, Salinas, who is beginning his third season with the Cubs, enjoys the same kind of experience as a guest services ambassador, managing bathroom accessibility and answering whatever questions fans ask — except about pitching changes. ⠀
⠀
No two days are alike for Rucci and Salinas, but their demeanor usually is. That helps at a ballpark where expectations have soared almost as high as ticket prices and emotions can be as inconsistent as the Cubs bullpen. Click the link in our bio for the full story. (John J. Kim / Chicago Tribune | @johnkimpictures)

Five-year-old Andrew “AJ” Freund was last seen at bedtime, about 9 p.m. Wednesday, and was reported missing from his Crystal Lake home Thursday morning. ⠀
⠀
Police do not believe the boy was abducted. Canine teams that were used during the investigation “only picked up Andrew’s scent within the residence, indicating that Andrew had not walked away on foot,” police said. ⠀
⠀
On Friday, his younger brother was placed into DCFS custody and his mother obtained a lawyer. On Saturday, the boy’s father visited the police station for roughly four hours, but officers would not say what for. Crystal Lake police Chief Jim Black said both the boy’s father and mother were not cooperating with the investigation. Black described the whole situation as “disturbing.” ⠀
⠀
DCFS confirmed the agency has been involved in AJ’s life since his birth in 2013, when he was born with opiates in his system, and he remained in foster care until 2015. In March 2018, DCFS investigated allegations of neglect by the father and mother, but concluded they were unfounded. In December 2018, DCFS investigated another allegation of abuse and neglect by the mother, but the allegations were ruled unfounded and bruising on the child was attributed to the dog. ⠀
⠀
A small group of community members searched wooded areas around Crystal Lake on Saturday, and a candlelight vigil was held in hopes the boy will be found safe. Both Andrew’s mother and father attended the vigil. Click the link in our bio for the full story. (Photos by Stacey Wescott, Abel Uribe and Chris Sweda / Chicago Tribune | @staceywescott27)

Michael Gillam and Mary Green, both originally from Ohio, loved Chicago’s skyline, lakefront and restaurant scene while living in the Ravenswood neighborhood in 2016, and then enjoyed a more suburban lifestyle for another year in Naperville.
⠀
Yet when it came time to put down roots, the couple moved to Houston in February 2018, seeking more affordable housing and a warmer climate in one of the fastest growing areas of the country. ⠀
⠀
“We just wanted to move somewhere where our money would stretch further,” said Gillam, 29, a software developer. ⠀
⠀
The metro Chicago area lost an estimated 22,068 residents from 2017 to 2018, according to U.S. Census Bureau data released Thursday. Among the 10 largest metro areas, New York and Los Angeles also shrank, while the remaining seven grew. ⠀
⠀
The census numbers don’t explain the many reasons why people might move out of the Chicago area, but in interviews with the Tribune, former residents who chose to leave gave a litany of reasons, including high taxes, government corruption, crime rates, economic instability, long commutes, an overall rise in the cost of living and the weather. While Gillum and Green will return to Chicago for their wedding in summer 2021, they have no plans to do so permanently. ⠀
⠀
“No regrets at all. We never looked back,” Gillum said. Click the link in our bio to read the full story. (Armando L. Sanchez / Chicago Tribune | @mandophotos)

Each time Yasmianne Dortch uses Uber, she calls someone or shares her phone’s location. The 21-year-old has been doing this ever since she read about women being attacked while using ride-share apps. ⠀
⠀
Her fears only worsened when she saw the news about Samantha Josephson, a 21-year-old student killed last month, allegedly by a man who lured her into his car after posing as her Uber driver. ⠀
⠀
“That could have been me,” Dortch said. “Being a female, we have to overthink things more than guys do. Like, maybe he’ll try to abduct me, maybe he won’t. Is this going to be my last ride?” ⠀
⠀
Ride-share apps are especially useful late at night to avoid dangerous situations. But DePaul University senior Sophia Modzelewski (pictured above) said every college-age woman she knows has had an uncomfortable experience while taking a ride-share. ⠀
⠀
“I would love to get into a ride-share and feel comfortable every single time, but that’s just not the reality,” the 22-year-old said. Click the link in our bio for the full story. (Armando L. Sanchez / Chicago Tribune | @mandophotos)

Former Bears cornerback Charles Tillman is afraid of lakes (and sharks). But those fears, along with the fact that he has zero experience as a rower and has never built anything before, aren't stopping him from building a boat he plans to row across Lake Michigan this year. ⠀
⠀
While Tillman is taking on this feat in part to conquer his phobia, he and his friend marketing executive Jacob Beckley, who is pictured in the third photo, are using their “Row4Kids” trek in August to raise money for pediatric cancer research and to financially support families of child cancer patients. ⠀
⠀
“It’s a lot of people out there who helped me when my daughter Tiana was sick,” said Tillman, referring to when his then-infant daughter needed a heart transplant in 2008. “This is our way of giving back.” ⠀
⠀
For weeks, the pair have been assembling the 22-foot-long boat from scratch in Downers Grove. Click the link in our bio for the full story. (Mike Mantucca/For the Chicago Tribune)

Pete Buttigieg, the young, openly gay mayor of South Bend, Ind., made it official Sunday afternoon: He’s running for president of the United States. ⠀
⠀
“It is time to walk away from the politics of the past and toward something totally different,” Buttigieg (prounounced boot-edge-edge) told a crowd packed into an unheated old warehouse, rain dripping through holes in the roof. ⠀
⠀
The 37-year-old Harvard graduate, Rhodes scholar and Afghanistan war veteran becomes the latest Democrat to join the crowded field for 2020. ⠀
⠀
Buttigieg said there is “a myth being sold to industrial and rural areas” of the country about what American greatness means, and that “resentment and nostalgia” is not the way forward. ⠀
⠀
If he emerges from the increasingly crowded field of Democratic candidates, Buttigieg would become the first openly gay nominee from a major party. Click the link in our bio for the full story. (Zbigniew Bzdak/Chicago Tribune | @bzdak)

More than 25 years ago, Stacey Ballis moved into an apartment adjacent the Ryan Mansion on Logan Boulevard. In 1993 the first floor unit became available. Ballis rented it for 20 years, eventually buying the entire building from her landlord in March 2013. ⠀
⠀
“It is home in a way that is so in my bones I can’t tell you,” she said. ⠀
⠀
Now she and her husband, Bill Thurmond, are working to turn this 8,000-square-foot mansion from the three-unit rental it was built as to a cohesive single-family home. The goal is to keep as many original elements as possible, paying homage to the building’s more than 100-year history, but making high-tech updates tailored to a modern couple. ⠀
⠀
Built in 1907 by Irish immigrants, the castle-inspired mansion features the original white marble vestibule and a first floor dedicated to entertaining with an open sitting room, large formal dining room and prep kitchen. Take the stairs — or elevator — to the second floor, which functions as the couple’s primary living quarters. The third floor boasts the ultimate couple’s suite, with his and hers dressing rooms and a master bath with views of Willis Tower. ⠀
⠀
The couple worked with a general contractor skilled in historic preservation who came to the project with knowledge and passion for historic buildings. Click the link in our bio for the full story and more photos. (Brian Cassella / Chicago Tribune | @briancassella) #architecture #architecturephotography #chicagoarchitecture

“You always stood tall even though you’re short.” -Ald. Carrie Austin, 34th ⠀
⠀
“You a hustler, man. In a good way! You are a hustler.” -Ald. Walter Burnett, 27th ⠀
⠀
“How do you say goodbye to someone who is part of Chicago?” -Ald. Ariel Reboyras, 30th ⠀
⠀
These were just a few of the remarks made as Rahm Emanuel presided over what is scheduled to be his final City Council meeting as Chicago’s mayor, drawing tributes from aldermen who praised his leadership over the past nearly eight years. ⠀
⠀
Asking the City Council for “one last favor,” Emanuel said aldermen should “stand shoulder to shoulder with our mayor-elect … united with her in the defense of the hard-won gains. Do not allow those who stood in the way of progress before to reverse the progress we collectively have made over the last eight years.” ⠀
⠀
No one specifically mentioned the controversies that have roiled Emanuel’s tenure — the Laquan McDonald police shooting, tax increases and school closings among them. The city also is facing a projected $252 million budget shortfall as well as $276 million in required new public pension payments for the 2020 budget. ⠀
⠀
Nevertheless, the mayor was praised for his leadership through tough times. Click the link in our bio for the fully story. (Antonio Perez/Chicago Tribune | @apereztribune)

Ed Chainski and Steve Mullins, both 86, have spent the last two decades traveling the country visiting minor league baseball parks. ⠀
⠀
After the 1994 players’ strike, the two friends — one a Cubs fan, the other a Sox fan — decided being able to hear the crack of the bat and the calls of the ump made for better baseball than the overpriced major league seats. ⠀
⠀
“We wanted to see baseball,” Chainski said. “Where they really like baseball. Where they really hustle. Where they wanted to get to the big leagues.” ⠀
⠀
The two met while stationed in Germany in 1955. After their military service ended, the Chicago natives remained in touch. One went to law school, the other got an MBA. They stood up in each other’s weddings. They went to a lot of Cubs and White Sox games. ⠀
⠀
A few months ago, Mullins was diagnosed with spinal cancer. But they’re not letting that get in the way of their plans to head west this summer — Reno, Nev., to be exact — to see their 100th minor league ball park. ⠀
⠀
Click the link in our bio for the full story. (Armando L. Sanchez / Chicago Tribune | @mandophotos) #baseball #cubs #sox #minorleaguebaseball

He accompanied Mayor Richard M. Daley to China. He has been sued, arrested and ejected from games. He has also topped the Forbes list of the most popular sports mascots in America. ⠀
⠀
Have you lived as much as Benny the Bull has? ⠀
⠀
Seven people, and countless understudies, have slipped into Benny’s shoes since he debuted on Oct. 17, 1969. As he turns 50, we look into how Benny — arguably the most popular mascot in professional sports — was created, how he has evolved and what it takes to don the beloved red suit. ⠀
⠀
Behind the scenes, in the bowels of the United Center, Benny remains silent, always the entertainer, a true bullshtick artist. Like a theater kid, he is always on. He is surrounded, at all times, by an efficient trio of Bulls employees in matching warmups called Team Benny who, depending how you see it, are enablers or members of a benign cult. Because Benny is forbidden to remove his head in public, they have worked out hand signals to communicate. Only in his dressing room is Benny allowed to speak. ⠀
⠀
After 50 years on the job, Benny has grown secretive, and corporate, and wildly successful. He has gone from a sideshow attraction to — after yet another pitiful Bulls season — the main attraction. But it hasn’t always been this way. Click the link in our bio for the full story. (Photos by Chris Sweda & Armando Sanchez / Chicago Tribune | @mandophotos) #bulls #chicagobulls #bennythebull

Timmothy Pitzen’s father dropped him off at his Aurora grade school on May 11, 2011. He was picked up shortly after by his mother, Amy Fry-Pitzen, who took the 6-year-old boy on a three-day trip before she was found dead in a Rockford motel room. Her cryptic suicide note stated her son was safe but would never be found. That prophecy has held up ever since, until this week when it appeared the search might finally end. ⠀
⠀
A police report filed in Ohio on Wednesday said a 14-year-old named Timmothy Pitzen had fled across a bridge near Cincinnati over the Ohio River and into Kentucky, claiming he escaped two kidnappers who held him hostage for seven years. ⠀
⠀
But DNA testing proved the man to be an impostor —  a 23-year-old man named Brian Rini who was released from prison last month. Further FBI investigation showed that Rini had portrayed himself as a juvenile sex trafficking victim on two prior occasions. Ohio police also reported other incidents dating back to 2016 involving Rini making false claims to police and a history of mental health issues. ⠀
⠀
News of the false alarm came as a devastating blow to Timmothy’s family, which has suffered several of them since the disappearance. ⠀
⠀
“It’s been awful,” said his grandmother, Alana Anderson, pictured with her daughter Kara Jacobs. “We’ve been on tenterhooks, hopeful and frightened. It’s just been exhausting. I feel so sorry for the young man who’s obviously had a horrible time and felt the need to say he was somebody else.” ⠀
⠀
Rini has been charged with making a false statement to an agency of the United States. Click the link in our bio to read the full story. (Joe Shuman/for the Chicago Tribune)

Lori Lightfoot won a resounding victory Tuesday night to become both the first African-American woman and openly gay person elected mayor of Chicago, dealing a stinging defeat to a political establishment that has reigned over City Hall for decades. ⠀
⠀
After waging a campaign focused on upending the vaunted Chicago political machine, Lightfoot dismantled one of its major cogs by dispatching Cook County Board President Toni Preckwinkle, whose candidacy had been hobbled in part by an anti-incumbent mood among voters and an ongoing federal corruption investigation at City Hall. ⠀
⠀
Lightfoot’s campaign, which started last May as a long-shot bid to replace the city’s clouted politics with inclusive change, took the former federal prosecutor and first-time candidate from toiling in relative political obscurity to toppling the head of the Cook County Democratic Party. ⠀
⠀
“Today, you did more than make history,” Lightfoot told hundreds of supporters at the Hilton Chicago. “You created a movement for change.” ⠀
⠀
Click the link in our bio for the full story. (Armando L. Sanchez / Chicago Tribune | @mandophotos)

In a promising start to 2019, homicides and shootings have dropped sharply over the first three months, Chicago police say, continuing a decline since 2016, when violence hit levels not seen since the 1990s. ⠀
⠀
Homicides dropped 38 percent through March 24, the latest department statistics show, as most of the city’s 22 patrol districts reported declines, including in the South and West Side neighborhoods that traditionally struggle with violence, poverty and other social ills. Shooting incidents fell by 19 percent. ⠀
⠀
In recent years, Chicago has garnered unflattering national attention as the big city with the most homicides and shootings, though other cities have worse per capita rates. Homicides in Chicago have outnumbered both New York City and Los Angeles combined in recent years, despite their considerably larger populations. Click the link in our bio for the full story. (Armando L. Sanchez / Chicago Tribune | @mandophotos)

A sword plunging almost 20 inches down your throat to the bottom of your stomach feels as gentle as running the back of your hand down your arm. So says Chicago’s only active sword-swallowing burlesque performer Sally Marvel. And please, take her word for it. ⠀
⠀
“Sword-swallowing, along that line, is not like riding a bike where once you know how to do it, you can always do it,” Marvel says. “I would equate it more to weight-lifting. You can know how to lift 200 or 300 pounds, but not be able to do it. I can tell you how to swallow a sword exactly, but your body would not allow it because it hasn’t been trained to accept it. You have to keep training.” ⠀
⠀
As of 2017, the Sword Swallowers Association International counts 126 active members worldwide. Of those, fewer than 30% identify as female — and of the three active members based in Illinois, Marvel is one of two women. ⠀
⠀
For the last four years, she has been priming her craft — one of many picked up through various sideshow and vaudeville trades, which include fire-eating and “human pincushion” acts. Marvel performs weekly at the Bordel. Click the link in our bio for the full story and showtimes. (Chris Walker / Chicago Tribune | @walkerpix)

Blue Line riders rejoice. The CTA has finished work on the redesigned Belmont Blue Line station in the Avondale neighborhood and it is open for business. ⠀
⠀
