The $17 million project that includes a dramatic blue canopy is the biggest project so far under the $492 million “Your New Blue” program to modernize and improve the O’Hare branch of the Blue Line. The Belmont station is one of the busiest on the CTA system, with 1.8 million entries to the Blue Line annually. ⠀
⠀
The station’s steel canopy was designed by the Chicago architecture firm Carol Ross Barney. It resembles a bird in flight, a butterfly or the top of a 1950s drive-in, depending on your perspective. Click the link in our bio for the full story. (Brian Cassella/Chicago Tribune | @briancassella) #cta #commute #avondale

Hoffman is a dog eager to please. He took the stage Wednesday at his graduation ceremony ready to show off his new obedience skills.

The 19-month-old pit bull is one of five graduates of Tails of Redemption, a program in the Cook County Jail in partnership with Chicago Animal Care and Control. The program, which began working at the jail late last year, pairs dogs at risk of being euthanized with inmates at Cook County Jail. Since the dogs need to bond with their handler, they must be paired with an inmate who is expected to be in the jail for an extended period of time. Only inmates who face homicide or sexual assault-related charges are excluded from the program. ⠀
⠀
“I always thought of it as a program that had the ability to really get to the empathy part of a person’s psyche,” Sheriff Tom Dart said. “To get someone to change mentally so when they leave here they are looking at the world in a different way.” ⠀
⠀
Inmates live in their cells with a dog over six to eight weeks and train the dogs to make them more adoptable. So far three of the five dogs that graduated Wednesday have been adopted or claimed. Click the link in our bio for the full story. (Abel Uribe/Chicago Tribune)

In a stunning reversal, Cook County prosecutors abruptly dropped all charges against “Empire” actor Jussie Smollett in an indictment accusing him of staging a Jan. 29 attack in Streeterville and falsely claiming he was the victim of a hate crime. ⠀
⠀
In exchange, prosecutors said, Smollett agreed to forfeit the $10,000 he’d posted for his bond and perform community service. The purported deal appeared to be hastily arranged — Smollett only completed the community service Monday — and apparently was not put in writing. ⠀
⠀
While prosecutors claimed to have overwhelming evidence, the deal did not require Smollett to admit he did anything wrong. What’s more, Smollett’s lawyers have vehemently disputed there was an agreement at all, and now the entire court file has been sealed at the defense’s request. ⠀
⠀
Both Chicago police Superintendent Eddie Johnson and Mayor Rahm Emanuel were infuriated, not just because the charges were dismissed but because prosecutors had not informed investigators first. Johnson said the decision allowed Smollett to hide behind a secret deal. The mayor was more blunt: “This sends an unambiguous message that there is no accountability.” ⠀
⠀
In a debate today, mayoral candidate Lori Lightfoot, a former federal prosecutor, said the public deserved more answers from Cook County State’s Attorney Kim Foxx’s office about its decision to drop all criminal charges against Smollett. Cook County Board President Toni Preckwinkle offered no personal opinion about the latest development in a polarizing case that has drawn national attention and instead deferred to the prosecutor’s office for further explanation. Click the link in our bio for full coverage. (Jose M. Osorio, Brian Cassella and Zbigniew Bzdak / Chicago Tribune | @joseochicagotrib @briancassella @bzdak)

Monica Paprocki has competed in the C2E2 Crown Championships of Cosplay for four years in the now 10-year-old Chicago Comic & Entertainment Expo. ⠀
⠀
This year she decided to be the obscure Arthenya VI, a kind of Elizabethan priestess from a French tabletop war game. To do that, she wrote the company and asked for its designs. Incredibly, the company obliged — and even sent 3D renderings. She sketched the costume and spent six months testing and sourcing materials, as well as buying a 3-D printer to create the parts. ⠀
⠀
“It’s a long, stressful, nerve-wracking experience, and the costume is so heavy, it’s like wearing a chandelier,” Paprocki said. ⠀
⠀
Once everything is in place, Paprocki is carrying roughly 20 pounds of fabric and electronics for more than 12 hours. Click the link in our bio to see her step-by-step process. (Raquel Zaldivar / Chicago Tribune | @raqzal) #c2e2 #cosplay

Are weed tour buses in Chicago’s future? As Illinois lawmakers draft a proposal, with the support of Gov. J.B. Pritzker, to allow legal recreational marijuana, they’ll have to answer fundamental questions, such as where smoking is allowed, and what products can be sold, who can sell them and how much to tax them.

Denver bus operator My 420 Tours considers its chartered limo bus a private smoking area, whereas local officials consider it public and therefore in violation of a ban on smoking pot in public. My 420 Tours runs almost-daily $69 sightseeing trips to pot grow houses and stores, with side trips to breweries, wine bars, and classes in rolling sushi and joints.

The legal battle is one of many disputes over the regulation of cannabis in Colorado, a pioneer in marijuana legalization, and a hint of what may come if Illinois allows recreational use of the drug, as expected. Learning from Colorado, Illinois lawmakers will probably limit home growers to five plants per person, possibly for medical patients only, state Sen. Heather Steans said. Medical marijuana became available in Illinois in 2015, but the law does not allow patients to grow it at home.

Illinois lawmakers also plan to prohibit public consumption and private lounges in the state, which would preclude smoking on tour buses, and to ban butane hash oil except by licensed producers. Click the link in our bio to read the full story. (Brian Cassella/Chicago Tribune | @briancassella)

A powerful storm, known as a “bomb cyclone,” walloped the Midwest last week and unleashed widespread flooding, including in northwestern Illinois, where record flooding prompted communities near the Rock River to evacuate. ⠀
⠀
A new report released Thursday by a team of Midwestern researchers suggests extreme bouts of precipitation and flooding could be the new normal in the Great Lakes region due to climate change. ⠀
⠀
For every 1 degree of warming, the atmosphere can hold 4 percent more water vapor that can turn into precipitation. Illinois has already warmed about 1.2 degrees statewide in the last century. According to the National Weather Service, the Rock River basin has been on the receiving end of 14 inches of average annual runoff, a 75 percent increase compared with the 1950s. ⠀
⠀
The boosted precipitation is expected to exacerbate urban flooding and challenge aging infrastructure. Water quality will be diminished as stormwater and sewer systems are overpowered, and as fertilizer, animal waste and other pollutants is swept into waterways, possibly triggering algae blooms and bacteria. ⠀
⠀
Perhaps the greatest setback will be to Illinois farmers. The soggy conditions will likely delay planting — again — reducing corn and soybean production by up to 30 percent. Click the link in our bio to read the full story. (E. Jason Wambsgans/Chicago Tribune)

At Butler College Prep on the Far South Side, five seniors and a recent graduate were surprised on Tuesday with scholarships offered through a program aimed at addressing the lack of male African-American teachers in the country’s schools. ⠀
⠀
As members of the second class of Call Me MISTER scholars, the teens were awarded full scholarships to study education at the University of Illinois at Chicago. ⠀
⠀
“I was in shock to hear my name called,” said Teon Nesbitt, one of the recipients. “I’m an athlete, so I’m not used to being portrayed as an educator. But I work hard in class and on the court. So it just shows that you can be anything you want to.” ⠀
⠀
Last fall, UIC launched the MISTER program — Mentors Instructing Students Toward Effective Role Models — which recruits and trains male elementary education majors of color. Research has shown that the “role model effect” means students of color who have black male teachers often find more success at school. ⠀
⠀
But in Illinois public schools, the percentage of black male teachers is about 1 percent, according to an analysis of 2017 figures from the Illinois State Board of Education. In Chicago Public Schools, fewer than 375 of 665 black male teachers, out of 21,000 teachers total, work at the elementary level. Click the link in our bio for the full story. (Zbigniew Bzdak / Chicago Tribune | @bzdak)

In 1973, Glenview resident Ellen Smith and her sisters moved their mother into a smaller apartment. Gertrude Van Someren, now 95, gave her daughter a box containing letters from a fiance she barely spoke of who died during World War II. ⠀
⠀
“You start reading them … and this whole part of our mother we didn’t know about suddenly opens up to us,” Smith said. ⠀
⠀
Bernard Steenwyk served in the Army’s 38th Infantry Division. Van Someren was around 19 when she started dating Steenwyk. He was three years older than she was, but they shared many of the same friends and interests. They were engaged within a year. In a series of heartbreaking letters from Van Someren to her beloved, written in early March 1945, she wonders why she and his parents hadn’t heard from him in weeks. He died Feb. 6, 1945, during the Battle of Zig Zag Pass, a fight against the Japanese for control of a strategic highway on the coast of the Philippines. ⠀
⠀
Van Someren recently signed up for a writing course at her retirement community. She and her fellow students are learning to write memoirs. “Now that I’m older, things are coming back to me more. I have 90 years of memories,” she said. Click the link in our bio for the full story. (Stacey Wescott / Chicago Tribune | @staceywescott27)

Spring may not have arrived just yet, but there was plenty of green to be seen in downtown Chicago for the city’s annual St. Patrick’s Day celebration. ⠀
⠀
Early Saturday morning, a crew of six people boarded their boats to dump a secret formula of orange powder into the Chicago River — turning it a bright green. Hours later, spectators packed South Columbus Drive to see bands, floats, local politicians and even MMA fighter Conor McGregor. ⠀
⠀
But the fun doesn’t stop there. Click the link in our bio for more weekend festivities — including a list of places serving green beer. (Abel Uribe / Chicago Tribune) ⠀
⠀
#stpatricksday #stpattysday #stpatricksday2019 #stpatricksdaychicago #chicagoriver #chicagoriverwalk

Last week, several residents of an old neighborhood tucked along the Chicago River received an email with the subject line “duck emergency.” ⠀
⠀
It began: I just got a call about a duck in distress at cullom, plastic wrapped around its neck. A neighbor wondered if there was anyone who might like to try to save it. ⠀
⠀
And with that summons, the good citizens of Riverbank Neighbors began to mobilize. On Sunday morning, the neighbors gathered at the river, united by the duck. ⠀
⠀
“Our duck, even though it’s got this six-pack thing around its head, can fly and swim and it’s very, very skittish,” Sigrid Schmidt said after a fruitless canoe rescue expedition. ⠀
⠀
The duck-seeking neighbors know that in a city plagued with human problems, their effort to save a duck might strike some as foolish. But it’s their duck, a member of the neighborhood, a community that is marked by the communion of humans and nature. ⠀
⠀
As of Tuesday, the duck was still on the loose, but the quest continues. Click the link in our bio for the full story. (Armando L. Sanchez/Chicago Tribune | @mandophotos)

Friends and colleagues of slain McHenry County Deputy Jacob Keltner remembered him at his funeral Wednesday as a brave and tenacious fugitive hunter who, when the workday ended, transformed into a lighthearted husband and tender father. ⠀
⠀
Officials said about 3,500 people, including hundreds of uniformed police officers from around the country, attended the service, filling two gymnasiums at Woodstock North High School. Keltner’s flag-draped casket rested in front as other officers shared their memories. ⠀
⠀
“Jake hunted evil and violent men, and he was great at it,” said Tony Penna, a fellow member of the U.S. Marshal’s Service Great Lakes Regional Fugitive Task Force. “He was truly gifted. … Bad guys even respected Jake when they were taken into custody.” ⠀
⠀
Keltner, 35, was shot and killed at a Rockford hotel last week by a fugitive he and others on the task force were trying to arrest on multiple warrants. That man, Floyd Brown, now faces federal and state murder charges. Click the link in our bio for the full story. (Antonio Perez / Chicago Tribune | @apereztribune)

While at the Naperville Chuck E. Cheese’s a few weeks ago, 9-year-old Marie Marcum decided to show off her skills in a baseball throwing game. ⠀
⠀
Marie, who plays second base for the Plainfield Twisters travel softball team, said she had no trouble hitting the strike zone, but when one ball bounced off the game and onto the floor, she heard a disturbing taunt from the machine. ⠀
⠀
“Oh well, there’s always softball.” ⠀
⠀
“I was upset and mad,” Marie said. But she didn’t just want to complain. She wanted to take action. ⠀
⠀
What started as a suggestion from her mom to write a letter to Major League Baseball — because the game was plastered with @mlb logos — has led to the game manufacturer removing the softball-dissing soundbite from arcade games at Chuck E. Cheese’s restaurants across the country. Click the link in our bio for the full story. (John J. Kim / Chicago Tribune | @johnkimpictures)

At 98 years old, Helen Sinclair is still as resolute in her mission as she was when she started ministering to men in prison nearly 75 years ago. ⠀
⠀
The way she sees it, it’s her job to remind men who have been convicted and condemned that they are still loved by God, and that they have a purpose to fulfill, even while locked up. ⠀
⠀
“I feel like I’m here to serve,” she said during a recent interview at her home on Chicago’s South Side, decorated with artwork made for her by inmates. “How can I quit when people need me? I know I wouldn’t have lived this long if I hadn’t been doing this work.” ⠀
⠀
And so Sunday after Sunday, despite her aging body and fragile memory, Sinclair journeys to state prisons to lead worship services she has designed to resemble traditional church affairs. She sings, offers prayers, teaches about black history and shouts words of encouragement. She offers hugs and broad smiles. She listens as the inmates testify about how God has helped them find their better selves and a sense of peace. ⠀
⠀
The inmates call her Queen Mother. It’s a name that’s been embraced by her entire community. Click the link in our bio for the full story. (Brian Cassella / Chicago Tribune | @briancassella)

There is a place within social media, tucked away behind the trolls and eye-rolling GIFs, where the weather is mild and disagreements are conducted at reasonable volumes. It’s called bookstagram, a tidy, well-appointed subculture awash in images of books, stacks of books and book lovers reading books. ⠀
⠀
“There are days on it where I think, ’Wow, this is social media as it was intended,’” said Hailey Dezort, of Chicago. ⠀
As with Instagram itself, bookstagram is an aesthetically minded peek into literary-minded lifestyles, albeit ones so heavily edited at times as to verge on fantasy. Bookstagrammers say they’ve heard it all before. ⠀
⠀
“People say we’re taking cutesy pictures, we don’t actually read, we’re just using the gravitas of certain books as content,” Chicago bookstagramer Megan Prokott said. “It’s funny — basically, bookstagram is another millennial scapegoat.” ⠀
⠀
In simpler terms, bookstagram is the social-media equivalent of poring through your neighbor’s bookshelves. Except here, your neighbors appear to live inside a Pottery Barn. Click the link in our bio to read the full story. (Stacey Wescott / Chicago Tribune | @staceywescott27) #bookstagram #bookstagrammer #books

Luna the orphaned otter is back in the news as the Shedd Aquarium rolls out a new “Extraordinary Experience.” The sea otter experience will provide opportunities to see the charming animals in their off-exhibit environments, to feed them, photograph them and, yes, if the animal is feeling cooperative, to pet them a bit. ⠀
⠀
“We’re always looking to make their sessions fun and engaging,” said Christy Sterling, a supervisor on the otters and penguins team. “So by participating in those encounters, they are getting different enrichment, seeing different people, and also at the same time we monitor them very closely.” ⠀
⠀
Behind-the-scenes animal offerings are a burgeoning part of the menu at zoos and aquariums, especially at the Shedd, Chicago’s top paid cultural attraction, which saw 1.9 million visitors in 2018. Click the link in our bio for ticket info. (Jose M. Osorio / Chicago Tribune | @joseochicagotrib)

If all had gone as planned, the remake of the Jane Byrne Interchange could have been done by now. ⠀
⠀
Instead, drivers continue to face snarled traffic, closed lanes and construction signs at the juncture of the Eisenhower, Kennedy and Dan Ryan expressways west of the Loop. Records obtained by the Tribune show that it wasn’t just one problem that caused this to happen, but a series of issues that contributed to unforeseen delays, conflicts over who was to blame and a price tag that is now $713 million. ⠀
⠀
Completing the construction project will take at least another 3½ years and will cost at least $170 million more than originally expected. Click the link in our bio for the full story. (Brian Cassella / Chicago Tribune | @briancassella)

When transplant surgeon Dinee Simpson sits in a consultation room with a patient, often they’re joined by the patient’s spouse or children. And sometimes, particularly if the patient is black, more than a century of mistrust of the medical community also joins them. ⠀
⠀
Simpson, 40, is Northwestern Memorial Hospital’s first female, African-American transplant surgeon. This month marks her one-year anniversary with the hospital. She is also the only black, female organ transplant surgeon in Chicago. ⠀
⠀
“I’m here to serve everybody,” Simpson said, “But there’s a specific population that I feel has a disadvantage, because of social issues, because of genetic predispositions, because of a lot of reasons. They need assistance, and I recognize that I can provide some of that assistance just by looking the way I look.” ⠀
⠀
In some families, a deeply ingrained sense of betrayal, passed down through generations, can permeate doctor visits. It’s a product of medical experiments widely performed on slaves in the mid-1800s, a product of the 40-year Tuskegee syphilis experiment, begun in 1932, that denied hundreds of black men a proper diagnosis or treatment for a debilitating disease. It’s a product of quality medical care existing just out of geographic reach. ⠀
⠀
Simpson understands that mistrust, even as she tries everything in her power to assuage that sense of betrayal and help patients leave it in the past. Click the link in our bio for the full story. (Raquel Zaldivar / Chicago Tribune | @raqzal)

Researchers at Brookfield Zoo have taken the lead in the largest international study on the welfare of captive dolphins and whales in history. ⠀
⠀
The researchers believe these animals are prospering, but say there’s little science on what conditions are optimal for dolphins and whales under professional care: What are the characteristics of the best habitat? How does the type and timing of animal training influence the behavior of these marine mammals? The project, which incorporates the work of 44 accredited aquariums and zoos in seven countries, intends to fill that void by analyzing every aspect of their lives. ⠀
⠀
The study, expected to be complete in 2020, comes as zoos and aquariums face heightened scrutiny, with some animal rights activists questioning the ethics of keeping wild animals in captivity. Click the link in our bio for the full story. (Antonio Perez / Chicago Tribune | @apereztribune

People jump into freezing Lake Michigan water March 3, 2019, during the 19th annual Polar Plunge fundraiser for Special Olympics Chicago athletes at North Avenue Beach in Chicago. According to Special Olympics Illinois, all proceeds collected by plungers will benefit the more than 23,000 traditional athletes and 20,000 Young Athletes of Special Olympics Illinois. Click the link in our bio for more photos. (Erin Hooley / Chicago Tribune | @malarchy)

After a storied 45-year career, rock and roll legends KISS launched their final tour, appropriately named "End of the Road" in January. The band made its stop at the United Center on Saturday. Click the link in our bio for more photos. (Chris Sweda/Chicago Tribune| @chris_sweda)

Temperatures are dropping back to single digits next week, but at the Chicago Botanic Garden, the tropics are alive and well for this year’s annual Orchid Show. ⠀
⠀
There’s a reason two-thirds of the world’s flowering plants live in tropical regions: The average temperature ranges from 77 to 82 degrees, and in the regions' rainforests, it can rain 400 inches a year. Do not think about what that would be as snow. ⠀
⠀
These fascinating, lush, colorful flowers are on display now through March 24. Click the link in our bio for more photos, hours and admission details. (John J. Kim/Chicago Tribune | @johnkimpictures)

Scientist and engineer John Rogers imagined a wire-free world for premature babies. So he invented tiny high-tech stickers that could revolutionize NICU care worldwide. ⠀
⠀
The wafer thin, Band-Aid like monitors (shown on 8-week-old Genesis in photo 1) do away with the wires and cords attached to the tiny patients, replacing them with tiny electronics that bend and stretch and delicately attach to fragile skin. Eventually, the technology is likely to change the face of preemie care in countries around the globe. ⠀
⠀
Northwestern is betting on Rogers in a big way, allowing him the chance to bring his engineers and scientists into direct collaboration with doctors and medical researchers. After a year of NICU testing at Lurie Children’s Hospital (where 8-week-old Riley is pictured in photos 2 and 3) Rogers and his team are in the final stages of proving that the new monitors deliver the same quality of data as current monitors. ⠀
⠀
Later this spring, they will begin their next phase — thanks to a partnership with the Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation, tens of thousands of the new monitors will eventually be deployed on newborns and mothers in Africa and Asia. Click the link in our bio for the full story. (Jose M. Osorio/Chicago Tribune | @joseochicagotrib)

Chicago will soon elect a black woman as mayor for the first time in the city’s history. Former federal prosecutor Lori Lightfoot and Cook County Board President Toni Preckwinkle won enough votes Tuesday amid a record 14 candidates to move on to an April runoff election. ⠀
⠀
With his voice hoarse from emotion, Bill Daley conceded as his powerful family – including his brother, former Mayor Richard M. Daley – looked on. Daley, who did not throw his support toward either Lightfoot or Preckwinkle, said he will remain committed to the issues he raised during the campaign. ⠀
⠀
Unofficial results showed Lightfoot with 17.5 percent of the vote, Preckwinkle with 16 percent and Daley with 14.8 percent with 95 percent of precincts counted. They were trailed by businessman Willie Wilson with 10 percent, state Comptroller Susana Mendoza with 9 percent, activist and policy consultant Amara Enyia with 8 percent. ⠀
⠀
The 14 candidates marked the largest field to run for mayor in Chicago’s 181-year history. Click the link in our bio for full election coverage. (Erin Hooley, Chris Sweda, Brian Cassella / Chicago Tribune | @malarchy @chris_sweda @briancassella)

Seventeen-year-old Morgan Holmes, pictured in photo 3, has been able to participate in Boy Scouts activities for years, but was never allowed to become a full-fledged member of the program — until now. ⠀
⠀
This month the Boy Scouts of America began accepting girls from fifth grade through high school into a newly named program called Scouts BSA, which allows girls the same opportunities boys have, including becoming Eagle Scouts, the highest rank in Boy Scouts. ⠀
⠀
The move comes a year after girls from first to fifth grade were allowed to join Cub Scouts. And already, all-girl Scouts BSA troops have sprung up in the Chicago suburbs and around the country, where scouting attracts about 2.4 million children. ⠀
⠀
“I’m loving it,” Holmes said. “I finally get to wear the uniform now.” ⠀
⠀
Six middle school girls have joined Holmes in Troop 48 in Lake Forest. Many are also involved in Girl Scouts of the USA, and many have brothers in the Boy Scouts, meaning now their whole families can take part in activities together. Click the link in our bio for the full story. (Chris Sweda / Chicago Tribune)

R&B superstar R. Kelly surrendered to Chicago police tonight on charges he sexually abused four victims over a span of a dozen years. ⠀
⠀
The four separate indictments charged Kelly with a combined 10 counts of aggravated criminal sexual abuse. Three of the indictments refer to girls who were under 17 at the time of the alleged abuse. Kelly will remain in custody until a bond hearing that is scheduled for Saturday afternoon. ⠀
⠀
This marks the second time that Kelly, 52, whose legal name is Robert Kelly, has been charged with a sex crime in Cook County. Prosecutors indicted the singer in 2002 on child pornography charges, but following a sensational trial six years later, a jury acquitted him of charges alleging he filmed himself having sex with his goddaughter, a girl estimated to have been as young as 13. ⠀
⠀
If convicted, Kelly would face a sentence ranging from probation to up to seven years in prison. Click the link in our bio for the full story. (Abel Uribe / Chicago Tribune)

Actor Jussie Smollett leaves the Cook County Jail in Chicago, Feb. 21, 2019, after posting a $10,000 bond on charges that the “Empire” actor staged an attack on himself, falsely claiming that two men called him slurs and beat him last month in downtown Chicago. ⠀
⠀
Hours earlier, Chicago police Superintendent Eddie Johnson spoke in anger when describing the allegations. Johnson said Smollett paid two brothers he knew $3,500 to fake the attack — because he was dissatisfied with his salary — striking him a few times and putting a noose around his neck in front of a camera they erroneously thought caught the act. The superintendent called the scheme “shameful” and wondered how an African-American could stage a racist attack for a “publicity stunt.” ⠀
⠀
Smollett surrendered to Chicago police around 5 a.m. Thursday on a felony charge of disorderly conduct. If convicted, he faces up to three years in prison and could be ordered to pay for the cost of the investigation. Click the link in our bio for more updates. (Terrence Antonio James / Chicago Tribune)

Remember during the polar vortex when many Chicago businesses let employees work from home but some of us nearly lost our minds after two days? ⠀
⠀
To remedy the stir-crazy the next time you’re allowed to work remotely, we’ve rounded up some quiet, quaint and creative locales from Hyde Park to Lakeview worth checking out. Click the link in our bio for the full list. (Chris Walker, Nancy Stone, Brian Nguyen / Chicago Tribune)

UPDATE: Medical staff at Brookfield Zoo had to euthanize the tiny African antelope born on Valentine’s Day due to a birth defect. ⠀
⠀
Brookfield Zoo’s new baby African antelope, a Kirk’s dik-dik named Valentino, was born on Valentine’s Day and weighs in at just over 23 ounces. Kirk’s dik-diks are one of the smallest antelopes in the world. Click the link in our bio for more photos. (Antonio Perez / Chicago Tribune | @apereztribune)

The 911 calls started at 1:24 p.m. on Friday. A man who had just been fired was shooting up Aurora’s Henry Pratt Co. ⠀
⠀
Police arrived four minutes later and almost immediately encountered gunman Gary Martin, a 45-year-old with a history of violence and a .40-caliber Smith & Wesson pistol he wasn’t legally entitled to have. Martin had already killed five of his co-workers. Within minutes, he had wounded five police officers and vanished into the warehouse. ⠀
⠀
The manhunt lasted 66 minutes. Thus concluding America’s latest mass shooting, leaving the residents of Illinois’ second-largest city to mourn an outbreak of heartbreaking, bewildering violence. Click the link in our bio for the full story. (Abel Uribe / Chicago Tribune)

Six people, including a gunman, died in a mass shooting at a manufacturing firm Friday afternoon in Aurora. Five officers were struck by gunfire, officials said. ⠀
⠀
Aurora Police Chief Kristen Ziman confirmed the shooter, Gary Martin, 45, was killed in a shootout with law enforcement. Martin was an employee at Henry Pratt Co. in the industrial park, but the motive for the shooting is still unknown. Click the link in our bio for the latest updates. (Antonio Perez / Chicago Tribune | @apereztribune)

After missing the National League Championship Series for the first time in four seasons, the Cubs began spring training this week at Sloan Park in Mesa, Ariz., ahead of the 2019 season. Wednesday marks the first workout for Cubs pitchers and catchers. Click the link in our bio for our full spring training coverage and follow @chitribsports for more.(Brian Cassella / Chicago Tribune | @briancassella)

Morgan Richardson was on an evening walk when she got a cellphone notification: The DNA testing website she used had found a new relative. ⠀
⠀
She stopped to check the details, and that’s how she discovered, at age 31, that she had a half-sibling she’d never seen or heard of before. ⠀
⠀
“It’s exciting, but it is a little bit jarring,” said Richardson, who was conceived via a sperm donor and has located 15 half-siblings in the last four years. “I always wonder, ‘What do they do?’ ‘Where do they live?’ ‘What are they like?’ ‘What’s their experience as a donor-offspring child?‘“ ⠀
⠀
Richardson was mostly curious about her donor and her ancestors’ countries of origin when she submitted her DNA testing kit. But 23andMe quickly located a half-sibling, launching her on a journey that’s increasingly common in the age of consumer DNA tests. Click the link in our bio for the full story. (Terrence Antonio James/Chicago Tribune)

Detroit Red Wings center Dylan Larkin (71) and Chicago Blackhawks defenseman Connor Murphy (5) get in a scuffle in photo 1 during the second period of the Hawks versus Red Wings game Sunday, Feb. 10, 2019, at the United Center. ⠀
⠀
The 5-2 victory over the Red Wings marked the Blackhawks’ seventh straight win, making it their longest winning streak since winning seven straight in 2017. Click the link in out bio for full Blackhawks coverage. (Erin Hooley / Chicago Tribune | @malarchy)

Arjun and Jessica Sud routinely use a baby monitor to keep tabs on their 7-month-old son’s bedroom. Last month, they heard something chilling through the monitor: A deep male voice was speaking to their child. ⠀
⠀
The couple grabbed their son and headed downstairs. When they passed their Nest thermostat, normally set around 72 degrees, they noticed it had been turned up to 90. Then, the voice was back, coming through the speaker in a downstairs security camera. And this time, it was talking to them. At first, Sud yelled back, but then he composed himself and stared into the camera. ⠀
⠀
“He was like, ’Why are you looking at me? I see you watching me,’” Sud said. “That’s when I started to question him back.” The voice was rude and vulgar, using the N-word and cursing. The family’s Nest cameras and thermostat had been hacked. ⠀
⠀
Nest users across the country have reported similar incidents in recent weeks, but the Google-owned company has insisted that it was not breached. Instead, Nest has said that affected customers could have done more to protect their devices. Click the link in our bio for the full story. (Erin Hooley/Chicago Tribune | @malarchy)

Hidden away in boxes and barns — or merely hanging in plain sight — many gorgeous fixtures of Chicago's historic Uptown Theatre have spent the past few decades vacationing in Barrington Hills, being cared for by an eccentric but loving crew of collectors, restorers and guardians after being rescued from the neglect of a convicted slumlord. ⠀
⠀
The story of how the family home of Jasper Sanfilippo, a hugely successful American businessman, came to help save the treasures of the Uptown is a fascinating one. The Sanfilippo Estate is not a public museum, but it is well-known locally and frequently opens its doors to charity fundraisers and for concerts in its grand private theater. It so happened that an Uptown-loving engineer named Curt Mangel was working at the Sanfillipo Estate after the Theatre’s 1979 closure. The Friends of the Uptown, both upper- and lowercase, decided that Mangel should approach Sanfilippo about quietly moving as much as possible to Barrington Hills — where it could wait for a happier time. ⠀
⠀
Last month, under the careful eyes of most of those who have cared for them for so long, the lost treasures all began their journey back home to Uptown. Click the link in our bio for the full story. (Stacey Wescott/Chicago Tribune | @staceywescott27)

Chaya Milchtein’s first memory of a car is her mom — then seven months pregnant — trying to jump-start the family’s 1995 Chevy Express. The oldest of 15 children with ultra-Orthodox Jewish parents, she said she felt at odds with her conservative upbringing and often sneaked off to the library to read the books banned at home. ⠀
⠀
“Education was always very important to me,” she said. “I always felt like not having the resources to educate yourself is one of the worst things in the world.” ⠀
⠀
With a finely tuned, informative blog and a series of online course offerings, Milchtein, now 24, calls herself the “Mechanic Shop Femme.” Her mission: to put the steering wheel back in the hands of women, femmes and queer folks. Milchtein says her quest to educate others arose from her own experiences of disempowerment. ⠀
⠀
“I went into foster care when I was 16, and when I was aging out at 18, I had a very difficult time finding a job," she said. "I started working at Sears as a service adviser, and they taught me everything I knew.” ⠀
⠀
Just don’t call her a mechanic — she considers herself an automotive educator. Click the link in our bio for the full story. (Brian Cassella/Chicago Tribune | @briancassella)

Rebecca Marsalli, right, occasionally had thought about getting genetically tested, knowing her mother had breast cancer twice. Having it offered at her obstetrician-gynecologist appointment in November at no cost to her made it easy to act, she said. Marsalli was one of about 1,000 NorthShore patients who agreed to undergo genetic testing. ⠀
⠀
Starting in April, NorthShore University HealthSystem will offer extensive genetic testing to 10,000 primary care patients to determine whether they’re at higher risk of developing conditions such as breast cancer, colorectal cancer and heart disease. The tests could also help steer patients toward the most effective pain and depression medications based on their genetics. ⠀
⠀
It’s a glimpse into what some say could be the future of primary care — a way to keep patients healthier and hold down costs by catching treatable diseases earlier. It’s also a way for health systems to capitalize on the growing popularity of genetic tests like 23andMe, by offering their own tests and follow-up care. ⠀
⠀
Still, questions remain about integrating genome sequencing into primary care. Click the link in our bio for the full story. (Stacey Wescott / Chicago Tribune | @staceywescott27)

Mother Nature isn’t wilting under the weight of the polar vortex at Chicago’s Garfield Park Conservatory, which remained open Wednesday and Thursday as large portions of the city shuttered. ⠀
⠀
In fact, the frigid temperatures this week helped to create a dazzling spectacle at the West Side greenhouse: Fern-shaped ice crystals frosted the glass ceiling, forming a pattern that appeared to mimic the plants inside. ⠀
⠀
The intricate patterns stretched across the glass in the Fern Room, Aroid House and Show Room, said Mary Eysenbach, director of conservatories at the Chicago Park District. Daniel Horton, an assistant professor of earth and planetary sciences at Northwestern University, said the crystals are fittingly called fern frost. ⠀
⠀
But, name aside, the frost and the pattern it takes on has nothing to do with plants, Horton said. Click the link in our bio for more photos and to learn more. (Erin Hooley / Chicago Tribune | @malarchy)

While this week’s sub-zero temperatures are keeping most people shuttered indoors, those with pets will likely have to make special considerations for their four-legged friends. ⠀
⠀
Animal advocates say if proper precautions aren’t taken by pet owners, they can be putting their dogs at risk if they’re outside too long. There is no hard and fast rule for pets because breed, health and age play a role in how much cold certain dogs can tolerate. ⠀
⠀
“Just think of it this way: If you’re cold, they’re cold," said Dr. Brian Dent, the medical director for the Anti-Cruelty Society. Click the link in our bio for more. (Erin Hooley, Brian Cassella and Antonio Perez/ Chicago Tribune | @malarchy @briancassella @apereztribune ) #dogsofinstagram #dogs_of_instagram #dogsinboots

Just before Christmas, Strawberry Hampton, a 27-year-old transgender inmate, was granted a rare transfer to a women’s prison in alignment with her gender identity. ⠀
⠀
The move came amid her yearlong court battle chronicling allegations of abuse and sexual assault by both inmates and corrections staff at four men’s facilities across Illinois. She says she’s enjoyed newfound security at Logan Correctional Center in Lincoln, Ill. ⠀
⠀
“At the end of the day, I’m safe here, I feel good,” she told the Tribune. “I don’t have to worry about someone trying to attack me for being a woman.” ⠀
⠀
In court documents, Hampton said she endured beatings, sexual misconduct and transphobic slurs and other derogatory terms while housed with men as she serves a 10-year sentence for a Cook County residential burglary conviction. The case spurred a federal judge in November to order the Illinois Department of Corrections to implement transgender training for all staff, and to re-evaluate Hampton’s previously denied request to be moved to a women’s prison. ⠀
⠀
At Logan, surrounded by some 1,500 female inmates, Hampton says she’s finally able to live as a woman without fear of harm or reprisal. Click the link in our bio for the full story. (Armando L. Sanchez/Chicago Tribune | @mandophotos)

Chicago is bracing for bitter cold with near-record low temperatures this week. ⠀
⠀
Some area residents awoke to more than 7 inches of snow Monday. In some spots, more snow fell midday and then again in the evening. These bursts of snow created slippery conditions for the evening commute. ⠀
⠀
Meanwhile, one of the coldest air masses in years will drop temperatures to around 23 below zero Tuesday night, according to the National Weather Service, with a daytime high of about minus 14 on Wednesday and another plunge to minus 25 overnight. The lowest temperature ever recorded in Chicago was minus 27 on Jan. 20, 1985. ⠀
⠀
“If you don’t have to be outside, don’t,” said National Weather Service meteorologist Amy Seeley. ⠀
⠀
Click the link in our bio for more photos and information on warming centers, transit changes and other city services affected by the frigid cold. (Armando L. Sanchez, Stacey Wescott, Jose M. Osorio, Erin Hooley, Terrence Antonio James / Chicago Tribune | @mandophotos @staceywescott27 @joseochicagotrib @malarchy)

Don Wachter scrounged up enough money to go to his first game at Soldier Field in 1983, and was a season ticket holder by 1985. The turning point in his Bears fandom came during a home game in 1996. ⠀
⠀
“I saw a guy had a whole bearskin rug. He had it over his head and draped over his back,” Wachter said. “It kind of gave me an idea. Can I get one of those heads from a bearskin rug and actually wear it?” ⠀
⠀
Now Wachter is one of six nominees competing to be the superfan named to the Ford Hall of Fans, housed at the Pro Football Hall of Fame in Canton, Ohio. Hall of Famer Brian Urlacher knocked on Wachter’s door in Plainfield in December to surprise him with the news that he was a finalist. Some of Wachter’s competition have decked out their homes as shrines to their favorite teams and players, and Wachter’s west suburban home is no different, but arguably he takes his mania up a notch. ⠀
⠀
Standing sentry in his driveway is his “Bearolla,” a blue 2010 Toyota Corolla decked out in plastic bear heads, team decals and a growling horn. Inside, it’s wall-to-wall Bears, with navy-and-orange walls and a wooden plaque that reads “The Bearman’s Den.” Bear figurines adorn furniture, and two stuffed bears — Wally (for Walter Payton) and Dougie (for Doug Plank) — are mounted on walls.

Wachter and his rivals have been campaigning for online votes, but their body of work will also have to impress judges from the Hall of Fame. The field will be narrowed to three finalists, who will be notified Monday, and then flown to Atlanta for the Super Bowl where the winner will be chosen. Click the link in our bio for the full story. (Erin Hooley and John J. Kim/Chicago Tribune | @malarchy) #bears #chicagobears #dabears #beardown

Despite frigid temperatures in Chicago this weekend, at least 370 people showed up at Oak Street Beach on Saturday, Jan. 26, to participate in the 18th annual Polar Plunge, hosted by the Chicago Polar Bear Club. Participants braved single-digit temperatures and ran into Lake Michigan to raise funds for families in need. Click the link in our bio for more photos of the plunge. (John J. Kim / Chicago Tribune | @johnkimpictures)

Chicago’s Uptown Theatre, said to be one of the most spectacular movie palaces ever built, is on the verge of a long-dreamed-of restoration to return the towering structure on North Broadway back to its 1925 opulence. ⠀
⠀
In large part, the Uptown stands ready for its $75 million makeover because of a few guardians who’ve helped protect the theater since the 1980s. The Uptown’s protectors have lent a collective hand to historic properties ranging from Wrigley Field to the Chicago Theatre. But the Uptown stands out as a particularly enduring and demanding labor of love for the three men. ⠀
⠀
“When you love a place like this, it’s in your heart,” said Jimmy Wiggins, who also oversees the Vic and Riviera theaters on the North Side. “They’ll never build anything like this again. I mean, just look at it.” ⠀
⠀
Wiggins is joined by restoration expert Curt Mangel and retired civil engineer Bob Boin in the protection of the theatre during which they have endured broken promises, false starts, late-night alarms, pigeon poop and oil fumes. They’ve repaired roof drains, shooed away intruders and sacrificed countless hours of their nights and weekends — and, in some instances, their retirements. ⠀
⠀
“Very few people know about them, but they’ve been heroes,” said Jerry Mickelson, co-founder and co-owner of Jam Productions, which has owned the Uptown since 2008. Click the link in our bio for more. (Jose M. Osorio / Chicago Tribune | @joseochicagotrib)

Thousands of icicles have come together just in time for Lake Geneva's biggest tourist draw of the season.

The much-anticipated Ice Castles complex is open for business, and will surely be a prime photo destination during the city's annual Winterfest — which kicks off this weekend. Made up of dozens of tall towers as well as fountains, caves, tunnels, thrones and slides, the surreal looking structure takes on an especially colorful glow at night, when embedded LED lights twinkle to synchronized music. Crews have been growing 5,000 to 10,000 icicles a day at “ice farms” on-site. These 1- to 2-foot-long icicles are placed on the structure and sprayed with water, turning them into thick, soaring pillars as high as 60 feet in some places.

Utah-based Ice Castles built six of these frozen palaces in North America this winter. Lake Geneva’s is open every day, weather permitting, except Tuesday. Click the link in our bio for the full story and details on how to get tickets. (Brian Cassella/Chicago Tribune | @briancassella) #icecastles #icecastleswi #lakegeneva #winterfest #wisconsinwinter

As people around the country watch and listen to decades of abuse allegations in the new Lifetime documentary “Surviving R. Kelly,” LaShanda Nalls considers how her clients hear messages within that conversation: that black women and girls don’t matter. That even after decades of allegations, a man is not in jail. That women might be blamed if they come forward. ⠀
⠀
All of these are things Nalls expects to begin talking about this week. ⠀
⠀
Nalls is a therapist and director of trauma therapy at Resilience, a group that provides services to sexual assault survivors. In the wake of the documentary, she will lead a new group beginning Jan. 24 for African-American, female-identified women who have been affected by sexual trauma. Nalls holds the group for African-American women each year, but this year feels different. ⠀
⠀
“I’ve never had a waitlist for this group before,” she said. Click the link in our bio for the full story. (Antonio Perez / Chicago Tribune | @apereztribune)

When Waffles, an 85-pound golden retriever, visited Lane Tech College Prep on Wednesday, students shrieked, hugged and cried tears of joy as they snuggled with the certified therapy dog, an activity designed as a break from the demands of preparing for final exams. ⠀
⠀
“I think a lot of adolescents today put a lot of stress on themselves. Finals have always been stressful, but now more than ever, it’s the end of the world for kids if they don’t perform well,” said Jacqueline Rhew, a licensed clinical professional counselor who works with adolescents and teachers. ⠀
⠀
This is the second year the dogs and volunteers have been brought into the school from Chicago-based Canine Therapy Corps to provide much-needed relief for stressed or anxious kids. Click the link in our bio for the full story. (Stacey Wescott/Chicago Tribune | @staceywescott27)

At 15 months, Opal Lang was reaching the typical milestones like finally toddling across the living room without falling. Then at a routine checkup, her pediatrician noticed her heart rate was irregular. ⠀
⠀
In the months that followed, Opal went into cardiac arrest, had machines hooked up to her to keep her heart pumping and celebrated her second birthday this month in her hospital room. Now, she is among 130 children between 1 and 5 years old across the country who are on a waiting list for a heart transplant. Opal is among 17 patients being treated by doctors at Lurie Children’s Hospital who are in line for the operation. ⠀
⠀
In early December, Opal lost consciousness, and a CT scan later showed the girl had a minor stroke. The Langs spent the holidays watching their daughter be lifted slowly from sedation and paralysis. Now relearning her motor skills, Opal has since smiled at her parents, recognized the family dog Booboo in a video and identified her own tongue. ⠀
⠀
Doctors aren’t sure what caused Opal to develop her heart condition; it could be a genetic abnormality, but there are no tests available to confirm that possibility. Click the link in our bio for the full story. (Brian Cassella/Chicago Tribune | @briancassella)

Police are searching for a gunman who shot and killed a man near the food court inside the Orland Square Mall on Monday night, according to deputy police Chief Joseph Mitchell. A bystander also suffered a graze wound in the incident and was treated at Advocate Christ Medical Center in Oak Lawn. ⠀
⠀
Investigators don't know the motive for the shooting and believe the shooter knew the victim, calling the situation an "isolated incident." Click the link in our bio for the full story. (Armando Sanchez/Chicago Tribune | @mandophotos)

The heaviest snowfall of Chicago’s first winter storm of 2019 may have passed, but expect frigid temperatures to stick around. ⠀
⠀
Downtown Chicago could see wind chills as low as minus 15 degrees by early Monday morning, according to the National Weather Service. Monday's high temperatures will be about 15 to 19, with wind chills between minus 10 and zero. On Tuesday, temperatures will rise to the low 30s, but then dip again, with a combination of snow and freezing rain possible Tuesday evening. ⠀
⠀
Although snowfall has mostly ended, about an inch of lake-effect snow is still possible in Cook County, with 3 to 7 inches possible in Indiana’s Lake and Porter Counties. Click the link in our bio for more weather updates and photos. (Armanda Sanchez/Chicago Tribune | @mandophotos)

Former Chicago police Officer Jason Van Dyke has been sentenced to less than seven years (81 months) in prison for the fatal shooting of 17-year-old Laquan McDonald, closing one of the most racially and socially significant chapters in Chicago history. ⠀
⠀
After a daylong hearing, Judge Vincent Gaughan sentenced Van Dyke only on the second-degree murder conviction, finding that it was the more serious crime and the 16 aggravated battery convictions should “merge” into it for sentencing purposes. ⠀
⠀
That decision means Van Dyke will serve only half of the sentence -- less than 3 1/2 years in prison – if he earns credit for good behavior. ⠀
⠀
The highly anticipated sentencing came with added tension one day after three Chicago police officers were acquitted of all charges alleging they conspired to cover up for Van Dyke in regard to McDonald’s killing. Click the link in our bio for more. (Antonio Perez / Chicago Tribune | @apereztribune)

Laura Lefkow-Hynes had long viewed her teenage relationship with her chemistry teacher at Lincoln Park High School as mutual, though dysfunctional. Then, as an adult with a daughter of her own and the #MeToo movement, she began to see it differently. ⠀
⠀
“Abuse doesn’t always look like a sexual relationship of some kind. It can be emotional, and it can be destructive,” said Lefkow-Hynes, 34, who is a lawyer. “And it can happen to anyone.” ⠀
⠀
She wrote a letter to Chicago Public Schools officials in October 2017 to make them aware that one of their current employees had been in an inappropriate relationship with her during her sophomore and junior years. Sharing journal entries, she described to CPS investigators what she recalled: the pet names, the long late-night phone calls, him holding her hand and brushing his mouth against her neck. Driving her in his car. Chastising her when she kissed a boy at a party. ⠀
⠀
After interviews and email reviews, CPS determined Lefkow-Hynes’ account was credible. The district removed James Galinski from school grounds earlier this year. Click the link in our bio for the full story. (Jose M. Osorio / Chicago Tribune | @joseochicagotrib)

After an unseasonably mild December, all the hallmarks of a Chicago winter could be on display this week. Forecasters are calling for an elevated risk of ice accumulation and a limited snow risk for Thursday, and the National Weather Service expects 2 to 5 inches of snow to fall over much of the area from late Friday afternoon into Saturday. ⠀
⠀
Temperatures are expected to drop Friday night with bitter and dangerous cold expected Saturday night through Monday. By nightfall Sunday, most Chicagoans should expect the temperature to be in the single digits. Click the link in our bio for more Chicago cold weather updates and photos. (Brian Cassella/Chicago Tribune | @briancassella) #winter #winterweather #chicagowinter #skyline #chicagoskyline

With his body draped in the Puerto Rican flag, his emotions struggling to get through the song titled “Hurricane” and his presence celebrated all across San Juan, “Hamilton” creator Lin-Manuel Miranda returned to the role of Alexander Hamilton on the island of his beloved father’s birth. ⠀
⠀
“Hamilton” has caused a stir wherever it lands, but the scene in San Juan was extraordinary. The show sold out immediately, raising some $15 million toward a Puerto Rican post-hurricane renaissance in just three weeks of sold-out performances. Celebrity guests included Shonda Rhimes, Leslie Odom Jr. and Jimmy Fallon, who brought his “Tonight Show” to the island for a special episode which airs tonight. ⠀
⠀
Opening night was a two-way flow of emotion from Miranda’s appearance to an island whose people have been at the core of so much of his work and now clearly expect Miranda to look after their interests. Click the link in our bio for the full story. (Zbigniew Bzdak / Chicago Tribune | @bzdak) #hamilton #puertorico #tonightshowpuertorico

Democrat J.B. Pritzker became Illinois’ 43rd governor Monday night. Now, the billionaire Hyatt hotel heir starts a four-year term with Lt. Gov. Juliana Stratton and a Capitol packed full of Democrats. Stratton was inaugurated as the first African-American to hold the post. ⠀
⠀
In his speech, Pritzker sought to suggest times were changing in Springfield after outgoing governor Bruce Rauner’s term without mentioning his name. ⠀
⠀
"At 200 years old, Illinois is still a young promise. Our time here has been but a blink. In 2019, we must begin a new century with new maturity … and enough foolishness to believe we can make a difference. That starts with leadership that abandons single minded, arrogant notions. No. Everything is not broken." ⠀
⠀
Despite his billions, Pritzker tried to highlight middle class themes, repeating his call to raise the minimum wage, highlighting the work of teachers and trumpeting his proposal to tax wealthier Illinoisans at higher rates. Click the link in our bio to read Pritzker's full speech. (Armando Sanchez/Chicago Tribune | @mandophotos)

If your Red Line ride was a bit interesting today, as you witnessed someone disrobe on your car, try not to worry — that person is (probably) part of the annual No Pants Ride. ⠀
⠀
Wannabe exhibitionists, aspiring comedians and fans of non-threatening nudity took to the CTA Red Line Sunday for the No Pants Subway Ride. Organizers said at least 110 people took part this year, which was the eighth year the ride has been held in Chicago. ⠀
⠀
The No Pants Subway Ride began in New York City as a project of Improv Everywhere and has spawned concurrent rides throughout the world, including Chicago. Click the link in our bio for more scenes from this year's ride. (John J. Kim/Chicago Tribune | @johnkimpictures) #nopantssubwayride #cta #chicagotravel #chicagocomedy

Kendra Rodriguez survived the bloodiest weekend in Chicago in recent history, but she lost her fiance, her home and much of her life. ⠀
⠀
Most Chicago homicides happen outdoors and are rooted in some sort of conflict among small, loosely aligned gang factions. Earl Young’s death was different. It happened on the back steps of his relatively small apartment building. It involved neighbors. Earl Young’s slaying would appear to be a case detectives had a strong chance of solving. There were witnesses, and a suspect was immediately identified. Yet five months later, a suspect has yet to be arrested or charged. ⠀
⠀
In Chicago, police have been clearing fewer and fewer shootings and homicides over the past 10 years, dropping far beneath national averages and well below other big cities. The Tribune has spent the past five months analyzing that first weekend of August, when Young and at least 74 other people were shot, looking at the department’s struggles and their impact on victims, their loved ones, and whole neighborhoods. Click the link in our bio for the full story. (Armando L. Sanchez / Chicago Tribune | @mandophotos)

Experts say a deep sense of identity tethering individuals to their parishes is what Chicago’s Catholics have been known for, what made them unlike other notable populations of Catholics in America. ⠀
⠀
But across Chicago, the number of Catholics is dwindling. There are fewer priests. Less funds. Fewer people in the pews. In just a few decades, those identifying with the faith have dropped by hundreds of thousands. In 1975, the Chicago Archdiocese was home to 455 parishes. More than 40 years later, that number has shrunk by 24 percent. And further declines are likely. The declines have prompted the archdiocese to launch Renew My Church, a multiyear restructuring program that will force many parishes to consolidate with one another — or, in some cases, shut down altogether. ⠀
⠀
“When they close churches, they kill communities,” said Dominic Pacyga, a retired history professor who grew up in Back of the Yards attending Sacred Heart. ⠀
⠀
As dioceses across America face backlash from sex abuse scandals — including recent revelations that the number of clergy accused of sex abuse in Illinois is much higher than previously disclosed — and adapt to an increasingly secular society, Chicago’s church leaders hope to reanimate and rebuild the city’s Catholic population. The data seem to point to a grim future for the church, but Betsy Bohlen, chief operating officer for the archdiocese, said Chicago’s Catholics have reason to hope. The current restructuring process, perhaps long overdue, aims to adapt the parochial system so it provides ample resources to minister to the Catholic faithful. ⠀
⠀
St. Ita in Edgewater and St. Adalbert in Pilsen, pictured, will both be consolidating their parishes with other churches. Click the link in our bio for the full story. (Zbigniew Bzdak / Chicago Tribune | @bzdak)

Debra West has dialed a number to reach the detective investigating the death of her 26-year-old son, Kendall Brown, over and over, each time hoping for good news. ⠀
⠀
On the August weekend Brown was killed, he was one of at least 75 people shot in the city’s most violent weekend in more than two years. Brown is among hundreds who have been killed in Chicago in recent years, with most of those cases going unsolved. Police believe they know who shot West’s son, she told the Tribune, but a witness declined to identify a suspect. ⠀
⠀
It’s a familiar story for many Chicago mothers who can feel powerless when investigators come close to solving their children’s slayings but hit dead ends. Yet they have come to play a unique — and effective — role in fighting Chicago’s violence. They are often detectives’ link to the community and a crucial advocate for young men society may not have sympathy for. ⠀
⠀
As much as they may feel it, they are not powerless. They search Facebook to find leads, they speak to neighbors and they even seek out key witnesses to move cases along. They show up at vigils to remember the dead sons of other women. And they take to the streets to march, chanting, “We are mothers” and “We want justice.” Click the link in our bio for the full story. (Armando L. Sanchez / Chicago Tribune | @mandophotos)

The Bears’ remarkable turnaround season came to an early end Sunday night at Soldier Field at the hands of the defending Super Bowl champion Eagles. ⠀
⠀
Bears kicker Cody Parkey missed a 43-yard field goal attempt with 5 seconds to play, and the Eagles pulled off a 16-15 victory in the first round of the playoffs. The Eagles advance to play the Saints in New Orleans in the divisional round. ⠀
⠀
Click the link in our bio for full Bears coverage. (Brian Cassella, John J. Kim and Jose M. Osorio / Chicago Tribune | @briancassella @johnkimpictures @joseochicagotrib)

Would you pay more so your server could have health insurance? ⠀
⠀
After six successful years in business, Logan Square hot spot Fat Rice is taking a calculated risk: It will add a 4 percent surcharge to all customer checks to help pay for employee health insurance and boost the wages of kitchen staff. The fee, which will be attached to checks not only at the restaurant but also at its neighboring bakery and cocktail lounge, will be explained on the menus and servers will be trained to explain it to customers. ⠀
⠀
Fat Rice’s decision is the latest in a small but growing movement among Chicago restaurants to bring health benefits to an industry notorious for not offering them, a trend advocates say is necessary if restaurants are to maintain stable workforces amid surging competition. Employees were leaving for higher-paying jobs, and 95 percent of the restaurant’s staff had no insurance. ⠀
⠀
The surcharge is already common in Los Angeles and San Francisco, and in Chicago it is being implemented at a growing number of popular haunts in Logan Square. Click the link in our bio for the full story. (E. Jason Wambsgans / Chicago Tribune | @ejwamb)

Registered nurse Lauren Underwood, 32, of Naperville, became the youngest black woman in U.S. history to serve in the House when lawmakers took the oath Thursday afternoon. ⠀
⠀
The new class of Congress “is what I always hoped the United States Congress could always look like,” Underwood said. “Diversity of thought, geographic diversity, age, race, gender, life experience are all great things that we each bring to this Congress of the United States, and I’m really proud to be part of a caucus where I’m not ‘the only.’” ⠀
⠀
The 116th Congress is like none other. There are more women than ever before, and a new generation of Muslims, Latinos, Native Americans and African-Americans is creating a House more aligned with the population of the United States. Inside the House chamber, Underwood greeted fellow new and also veteran House members with hugs and handshakes, eventually making her way to her sixth-row seat. She took her spot two seats away from Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez of New York, the youngest woman ever elected to Congress. ⠀
⠀
Click the link in our bio to see Rep. Underwood give a tour of her new office on Capitol Hill. (Stacey Wescott/Chicago Tribune | @staceywescott27)

Chicago’s longest-serving alderman, Edward Burke, has been charged with attempted extortion for allegedly using his position to try to steer business to his private law firm from a company seeking to renovate a fast-food restaurant in his ward. ⠀
⠀
Sources say that restaurant was a Burger King, located at 4060 S. Pulaski Road — the same restaurant Laquan McDonald passed moments before he was fatally shot by Chicago police Officer Jason Van Dyke in October 2014. ⠀
⠀
Federal authorities also alleged that Burke illegally solicited a campaign donation from an executive with a company who owned the fast-food restaurant for an unnamed politician. Sources have identified Cook County Board President Toni Preckwinkle, who is running for Chicago mayor, as the intended recipient of the $10,000 contribution from the restaurant owners. ⠀
⠀
Burke is arguably one of the biggest fish ever reeled in by the U.S. attorney’s office, which has famously indicted a succession of Illinois governors, aldermen and other politicians in a seemingly never-ending parade of graft. For decades, the Southwest Side alderman has used his iron grip on the City Council’s Finance Committee and key role in slating Cook County judges to build a massive amount of political capital. ⠀
⠀
While dozens of his City Council colleagues have been convicted and sent to prison over the decades, Burke was largely seen as too clever or sophisticated to be caught. Click the link in our bio to read the full 37-page criminal complaint. (Brian Cassella / Chicago Tribune | @briancassella)

As Illinois mulls recreational marijuana, its quieter cousin could be the state’s next big cash crop. Hemp — the same plant that makes marijuana but without the THC that gets users high — is ready to come out of hiding. ⠀
⠀
Earlier this year, state lawmakers authorized its production in Illinois. And in December, the new federal farm bill that legalized the production of the plant nationwide was passed with bipartisan support. With the recent explosion of the cannabis extract cannabidiol, or CBD, advocates say hemp will emerge as a cash crop for Illinois. ⠀
⠀
“CBD oil will help the industry get started,” said Andy Huston, a sixth-generation farmer near Peoria. “But there’s going to be tons of offshoot businesses that will come out of this.” ⠀
⠀
The plant could bring new opportunities in particular to smaller family farmers, many of whom have been hurt or driven out of business by the pressures of selling commodities like corn and beans. Click the link in our bio for the full story. (Zbigniew Bzdak / Chicago Tribune | @bzdak)

Some may still have been singing “Auld Lang Syne” when the first baby born in Cook County in 2019 made her appearance just five minutes into the new year. ⠀
⠀
Yarehlie Nava was born to Maria Ramirez and Freddy Nava of Elgin, said Jim O’Connell, a spokesman for Amita Health St. Alexius Medical Center in Hoffman Estates. ⠀
⠀
The girl weighed 8 pounds, 14 ounces and measured 21 inches. Her mother, 23, said she was in active labor for about six hours before the delivery at 12:05 a.m. ⠀
⠀
“I thought it was before (midnight),” she said of the birth. “I never really thought that it was going to happen like exactly at midnight.” Click the link in our bio for the full story. (Antonio Perez / Chicago Tribune | @apereztribune)

New Year’s Eve fireworks explode over the Chicago River as seen from the LondonHouse Chicago rooftop in Jan. 1, 2019. The new fireworks show, put on by Arena Partners, spread the action out with five different launch points along the river between Lake Shore Drive and Wolf Point. Click the link in our bio for more NYE coverage. (Armando Sanchez/Chicago Tribune | @mandophotos) #newyearseve #2019 #nye

The Bears topped the Vikings 24-10 on Sunday and will face the Eagles, who beat the Redskins to eliminate the Vikings from playoff contention. The No. 3 seed Bears will host the Eagles in the wild-card round at 3:40 p.m. Jan. 6. Click the link in our bio for full Bears coverage. (Brian Cassella and Stacey Wescott / Chicago Tribune | @briancassella @staceywescott27)

Once the sole territory of toymakers like Hasbro and Mattel, the past decade has seen classic 3-inch Star Wars-esque action figures become a canvas for independent artists, amateur sculptors and creative collectors. Peter Goral, 33, is a superstar within the genre, creating toys under the name Killer Bootlegs and selling them through Instagram. ⠀
⠀
Most of his creations are reassemblies — sort of 3D collages. Some are unauthorized takes on the renowned (Richard Pryor), transgressive one-note jokes (“Ewoking Dead”) and some of his biggest sellers are original characters. For a while he was assembling and hand-painting every one of these figures; now he replicates them, using molds and resins, still hand-painting many while making others with help from Chinese factories. Most, however, are made on a whim, bundled into clever homemade variations of cardboard-backed, plastic-blister action-figure packaging, then sold in batches of about 50 for about $50 each. ⠀
⠀
“Best way to explain,” Goral says, “I’m like a DJ sampling, remixing material, going over it until, when the tinkering is finally done, I get something fresh.” Click the link in our bio for the full story. (Stacey Wescott / Chicago Tribune | @staceywescott27)

Resembling Santa takes on a life of its own, as George Deangelo has discovered. The 70-year-old Hammond man, with his stark white hair and beard to match, said he was coaching a junior bowling league abound 10 years ago when he was first approached to step in for the Man in Red. Kids were “getting wise" to men sporting fake beards.
⠀
"I really get a kick out of it and like dealing with the kids," he said. "I even have business cards with ‘Elf Help Line’ on them."
⠀
Filling in for Santa fills a place in George's heart. Having spent his formative years in orphanages, he learned to be tough and protective. Being nurturing and loving came later, through his wife, their kids and his in-laws.
⠀
"He went to the doctor yesterday, and the doctor said he could tell George is more relaxed right now," his wife Pam said. "It's his time." Click the link in our bio for the full story. (Suzanne Tennant / for the Chicago Tribune)

Casey Handal and Zadette Rosado moved into their Barrington home in May, eager to raise their daughters in a close-knit and peaceful community. Their house came with a flagpole in the backyard, and they decided to use it to fly a rainbow flag to represent their family. ⠀
⠀
But in the wee hours of Dec. 9, someone with an apparently darker view of the flag sneaked onto the family’s property, lowered it from the pole and took it away. In its place was left an American flag. Though Handal considers herself a proud American, she saw the uninvited flag swap as a hostile gesture aimed at the only openly gay couple in the neighborhood. ⠀
⠀
“I think the message was quite clear,” she said. “I think if somebody would have just taken the flag and not replaced it with anything, that wouldn’t necessarily have sent quite the same message." ⠀
⠀
But what came next was a surprise — an act of solidarity that turned a disturbing experience into a vibrant show of unity. Dozens of neighbors are now displaying rainbow flags outside their own homes, tucking them into their mailboxes, planting them into their front lawns. ⠀
⠀
And that turned out to be just the start of the neighborhood’s embrace of the family. Click the link in our bio for the full story. (Armando Sanchez / Chicago Tribune | @mandophotos)

John Wayne Gacy was arrested 40 years ago following his confession to the rape and murder of more than 30 young men. The discovery of the dank, muddy mass grave underneath Gacy's yellow brick ranch house awakened America to a nightmare hidden in its own backyard, forever shattering the image of the safe suburban community. ⠀
⠀
Gacy’s nice-guy persona masked something far more sinister. Using a pair of handcuffs as he demonstrated a “trick” he learned as a clown, he restrained and sexually assaulted his victims before strangling many of them with a knotted rope. He buried 29 of his 33 victims in trenches underneath and around his home, and dumped four others from bridges once his property could hold no more bodies.
⠀
Detective Sgt. Jason Moran of the Cook County sheriff’s office, a one-man cold-case squad tasked with finding out the names of the remaining unidentified victims, has been able to identify two Gacy victims and clear four suspected victims who died at the hands of other killers. Six unidentified Gacy victims remain. ⠀
⠀
Gacy was executed by lethal injection in 1994, but the impact of his crimes went beyond tainting his neighborhood. In response to widespread criticism of local police for taking years to connect the missing victims to Gacy, federal and local law enforcement agencies began sharing information on runaways and sex offenders, implemented a national hotline and launched a computer database for missing people. ⠀
⠀
Moran granted the Tribune access to the evidence room where many of Gacy's belongings, previous psychological evaluations and personal items of his victims are stored. Click the link in our bio for a timeline of Gacy’s life. (Erin Hooley/Chicago Tribune | @malarchy)

When Becca Bernstein’s mother died three years ago, right before Thanksgiving, the family struggled to fill the void left on a treasured holiday. ⠀
⠀
Those who have recently suffered a loss might be apprehensive about the holidays. Often, people feel obligated to attend celebrations even when they don’t feel celebratory. It can seem impossible to see joy in a season of grief. ⠀
⠀
Bernstein, now 30, is community director of The Dinner Party, a national organization that connects people who have experienced loss. In the last two months, the organization has received more than 800 applications to join the group, which Bernstein says indicates people want support as holidays approach. ⠀
⠀
We spoke with experts in the field of grief and those who have lost loved ones to compile 8 tips for how to handle loss during the holiday season. Click the link in our bio for the full story. (Jose M. Osorio / Chicago Tribune | @joseochicagotrib)

A Chicago flag flies at half-staff outside the Chicago Police 5th District headquarters on Tuesday after two officers were struck and killed by a train Monday night. ⠀
⠀
The Police Department has announced that funerals for the two men will be held at St. Rita of Cascia Shrine Chapel on South Western Avenue. Services for Officer Conrad Gary will be held at 9:30 a.m. Friday, with a wake from 3-9 p.m. Thursday at Blake Lamb Funeral Home. The funeral for Officer Eduardo Marmolejo will be held at 11 a.m. Saturday, with a wake from 3-9 p.m. Friday at Blake Lamb Funeral Home. ⠀
⠀
Marmolejo, 36, and Gary, 31, were killed while responding to a call for service on the railroad tracks. They are the third and fourth Chicago police officers to die in the line of duty this year. Click the link in our bio for the full story. (Brian Cassella/Chicago Tribune | @briancassella)

Like many Americans with special needs, Andy Mitchell suffered untreated tooth decay. He had cavities in 23 teeth, bone loss and eight teeth that required extraction. ⠀
⠀
“We tried to take him to a neighborhood clinic, but they didn’t want to touch him," his father said. "He can’t really tell you when something hurts. He’ll just ball up and cry.” ⠀
⠀
Andy is intellectually and physically disabled, not easily able to communicate or control his own body, making routine dental care difficult to obtain — until his parents found St. Bernard’s Hospital on Chicago’s South Side. ⠀
⠀
A year and a half ago, Dr. Mary Joyce Gomez gave up a comfortable private practice in the Loop to become dental director at St. Bernard, in a neighborhood that has long been used as shorthand for urban blight and crime. An immigrant from the Philippines and a breast cancer survivor, Gomez believes that she can make a difference that starts with fixing teeth, and goes much further. ⠀
⠀
Under her leadership, the clinic expanded its services to serve adults with special needs — a group that finds dental care extremely hard to access in the United States. Click the link in our bio for the full story. (Antonio Perez/Chicago Tribune)

Two Chicago police officers were killed Monday night when they were hit by a train while investigating a call of shots fired on the city’s Far South Side. ⠀
⠀
Officers Eduardo Marmolejo, 36, and Conrad Gary, 31, were killed in the line of duty while responding to a call when a suspect made his way up to the Metra tracks. Mayor Rahm Emanuel said both men were fathers of young children. Marmolejo had two and a half years on the force, and Gary had 18 months, police Superintendent Eddie Johnson said. Police recovered a weapon near where the officers were struck and were questioning a person of interest late Monday. ⠀
⠀
Metra officials shut down all traffic on the Metra Electric District tracks while authorities worked at the scene. Click the link in our bio for the full story. (E. Jason Wambsgans and Armando Sanchez / Chicago Tribune | @ejwamb @mandophotos)

When the clock expired on a gorgeous Sunday afternoon at Soldier Field, Matt Nagy strode to midfield where he greeted interim Packers coach Joe Philbin and then Bears all-time nemesis Aaron Rodgers, who had won his last eight starts in the stadium. ⠀
⠀
The 24-17 victory locked up the division and a playoff spot, completing a remarkable worst-to-first turnaround. It gave the Bears a 7-1 record at home this season, their best since they had the same record in 2005. The Bears improved to 10-4, making Nagy the team’s winningest first-year head coach since George Halas went 10-1-2 in 1920. ⠀
⠀
Clinching the NFC North gives the Bears an inside track at no worse than the No. 3 seed in the NFC field, which would guarantee them a home game in the wild-card round of the playoffs Jan. 5-6. Click the link in our bio for more from today’s Bears win. (Armando Sanchez and Chris Sweda / Chicago Tribune | @mandophotos) #bears #nfl #beardown #nfcnorthchamps

Move over Denver, Seattle and San Diego. Chicago is the nation’s brewing capital. ⠀
⠀
The metro region has surged past several longtime stalwarts to become home to more breweries than any other city in the nation — 167 — according to statistics published this week by the Brewers Association. ⠀
⠀
Brewers Association’s chief economist Bart Watson derived the numbers using brewery ZIP codes and U.S. Census data. Chicago’s number of breweries per capita lags behind many other top cities. Portland, Ore., is home to 139 breweries among 1.8 million people, per 2010 Census numbers, while Chicago’s 167 breweries exist amid 8.2 million people. ⠀
⠀
But Chicago’s move to the top spot accentuates its burgeoning reputation as a brewing destination. Click the link in our bio for the full story and more info on Chicago-born breweries and taprooms. (Brian Cassella / Chicago Tribune | @briancassella)

On a bleak and biting December morning, a small team of state-contracted commercial fishermen slipped into their waders and salted down their boats to protect against ice before launching onto the Illinois River. ⠀
⠀
Armed with thousands of yards of netting the fleet set course for a cove at Sheehan Island where they suspected a horde of silver and bighead carp, the most abundant and worrisome species of invasive Asian carp, were holed up for the winter. ⠀
⠀
In less than a half hour, the fishermen transformed the inlet, which is big enough to hold Millennium Park, into an enormous booby trap, layering netting from the shores to the mouth of the bay. Once they were finished, the stillness of the muted winter morning was broken by the fishermen collectively revving their motors, driving frenzied Asian carp into the nets. ⠀
⠀
While state and federal officials debate costly preventive measures, unreliable electrical barriers near Romeoville serve as the last rampart blocking Asian carp from entering the Great Lakes. Click the link in our bio for the full story. (E. Jason Wambsgans / Chicago Tribune | @ejwamb)

Hysni Selenica’s path to becoming the first Muslim chaplain with the Chicago Police Department began at a storied Catholic high school he attended across the street from police headquarters. ⠀
⠀
A born-and-raised Southwest Sider, Selenica attended De La Salle Institute, which counts at least five Chicago mayors among its alumni. One day a religious brother asked about his roots. ⠀
⠀
Selenica explained that his father was from Albania, a communist country at the time, where practicing your faith was forbidden. His father kept his faith private even after fleeing to the United States. ⠀
⠀
“You’re Muslim,” the brother said matter-of-factly. Selenica, now 43, still remembers the brother’s thick drawl. ⠀
⠀
“I guess?” Selenica replied. The Gulf War was raging at the time. ⠀
⠀
It would take years to get back to the faith of his ancestors and eventually to become a chaplain with CPD. But he believes he was destined to make that journey. Click the link in our bio for the full story. (E. Jason Wambsgans / Chicago Tribune | @ejwamb)

As Michigan legalizes marijuana, the race is on with Illinois for the first commercial sales in the Midwest. Michigan’s experiment could serve as a blueprint for Illinois’ own efforts toward legalization, though it’s possible that Illinois could actually roll out legal recreational weed first, if all falls into place.
