Many advocates expect a wave of visitors looking to get high, despite the social conservatism of the Rust Belt. ⠀
⠀
“I bet we’ll see quite a bit of tourism,” Michigan medical marijuana grower Debra Young said. “People go to Colorado and Las Vegas. A lot of people went across the border when Canada legalized it.” ⠀
⠀
To mark the occasion, a business called Elevated Yogi hosted a pre-yoga smoking session at its studio in Detroit. The studio does not provide the product, but typically lets medical marijuana card holders bring their own. While patients may not share their medicine, the new law allows the drug to be shared for free, so the practice will no longer be legally limited to patients. ⠀
⠀
But Illinoisans should know that, as of now, there is nowhere they can buy marijuana legally in “Pure Michigan.” Until businesses are licensed the drug remains illegal to sell to the general public and illegal to take across state lines. Click the link in our bio for the full story. (Brian Cassella/Chicago Tribune | @briancassella)

Union Station’s Great Hall, a stopping point for travelers since 1925, is a lot brighter this holiday season, thanks to a $22 million renovation of its 219-foot-long skylight and decorative walls and ceiling. ⠀
⠀
For almost a year, the skylight has been obscured by a suspended working deck as Berglund Construction and architect Goettsch Partners repaired it and added another modern, protective skylight 5 feet above the original. ⠀
⠀
The 37.6 million passengers that walk through the station annually will now see natural light in the Great Hall increased by 50 to 60 percent. Click the link in our bio for the full story. (Chris Sweda / Chicago Tribune)

Sarah Parsons is ready to move forward to endure a criminal case against the man she said sexually assaulted her. But she is waiting on one thing. The evidence collected last year in a Chicago emergency room, known as a rape kit, has yet to be analyzed. ⠀
⠀
An attorney advised waiting; the results would likely bolster her case — 15 months later and "I'm still waiting," Parsons said. ⠀
⠀
In 2010, Illinois became the first state to enact a law requiring that all rape kits be tested, and in the years since forensic scientists have worked their way through the influx at labs. According to the Illinois State Police, the average time to process DNA evidence for all cases, including sexual assaults, is 285 days. Now a group of Illinois lawmakers, advocates and law enforcement officials has drafted a proposal for a system to track rape kits. ⠀
⠀
Cara Smith, the Cook County sheriff's chief policy officer, said allowing survivors to track evidence is the least officials can do to send a message that after victims endure an intrusive exam during a traumatic time, their cases are being taken seriously. ⠀
⠀
“It’s their body. It’s their evidence,” Smith said. “And they should absolutely know where in this very challenging process it is.” Click the link in our bio for the full story. (Stacey Wescott / Chicago Tribune | @staceywescott27)

For the 70 percent of the nation’s fire service that relies on volunteers, representing 814,850 of the roughly 1.16 million firefighters across the U.S., investing in costly high-tech products and cancer prevention initiatives often is not in the budget. ⠀
⠀
As a result, volunteer departments and those that are poorly funded find themselves faced with stark disparities in resources when it comes to keeping their crews safe, officials said. ⠀
⠀
“We sell pizzas, have meat shoots and hold bingo games to raise money to put fuel in the trucks and keep the heat and electricity on in the station,” said Sharon Davis, left, a volunteer assistant fire chief in Centreville Township, an economically struggling area that borders East St. Louis. “Yes, we’re worried about cancer, but we just don’t have the budget, so those things have to take a back seat.” ⠀
⠀
------- ⠀
⠀
In the series “Line of duty: Firefighters and cancer,” the Pioneer Press and the Chicago Tribune explore the research into the suspected relationship between firefighting and cancer, the challenges facing area policymakers and the effect the complexities of the situation have on firefighters and their families. Over the past few weeks, we have been sharing their stories. Click the link in our bio for the full investigation. (Stacey Wescott / Chicago Tribune | @staceywescott27)

A shooting that injured a 27-year-old man and delayed CTA trains during rush hour in the Loop Thursday evening was a "targeted incident," according to police. The shooting happened just after 5 p.m. near the Jackson Boulevard stop on the Blue and Red lines. ⠀
⠀
The shooter wore a surgical mask across his mouth, police said. He ran west through the tunnel and either exited the subway or got on a train. The victim was stabilized at Northwestern Memorial Hospital. He was not cooperating with the investigation. ⠀
⠀
Normal service on both lines has since resumed. Click the link in our bio for the full story. (Chris Sweda/Chicago Tribune)

The reports of gunfire started around 12:50 a.m. Over the radio, police reported seven rounds at an address on North Karlov Avenue. Ten more after that. In seconds, the street turned into a battleground. Four people were shot, cars smashed, shell casings up and down the block. ⠀
⠀
Four months later the shooting remains unsolved, like dozens of others from the first weekend in August, when at least 75 people were shot — the most violent weekend in Chicago in years. ⠀
⠀
“All I saw was uniformed officers, and not one attempted to talk to anybody on this block other than to give commands as to where you could or could not go,” said Tammy Sims, who has lived on Karlov 18 years. ⠀
⠀
Lori Pierson, who moved into her Karlov home in June, got to her window in time to see gunmen still firing. She called 911 and huddled with Chicago police officers who promised someone would get back to her. For nearly four months, she did not hear from anyone. ⠀
⠀
"I appreciate the work police officers do. They have the hardest job.” Pierson, said. “But it is still … This is our community. It's frustrating, of course. It’s disappointing." ⠀
⠀
The lack of progress, and the rise in fear, bring home some of the consequences of the Chicago Police Department’s yearslong struggle with clearing cases. Click the link in our bio to read the full story. (Armando L. Sanchez / Chicago Tribune | @mandophotos)

When a massive, five-alarm fire engulfed an apartment complex in Prospect Heights in July, swallowing swaths of synthetic materials in its wake, fire Chief Drew Smith said he was determined to keep his crew safe. ⠀
⠀
Many firefighters say prevention protocols designed to protect them can become a secondary priority when dealing with often high-stakes pressures to save lives in an emergency and extinguish blazes quickly. ⠀
⠀
Wearing air masks is one example of the ongoing work to change the culture at many fire departments across the country, including Prospect Heights, amid the debate over cancer and its link to firefighters. Smith recalled an era from decades past when some of his fellow firefighters refrained from wearing air masks unless a particular scene “was really bad.” ⠀
⠀
“Now, we’re of the position to never take it off,” Smith said of the masks. “More and more guys are afraid of getting cancer. … It’s become very personal, and people are trying to do the right thing.” ⠀
⠀
------- ⠀
⠀
In the series “Line of duty: Firefighters and cancer,” the Pioneer Press and the Chicago Tribune explore the research into the suspected relationship between firefighting and cancer, the challenges facing area policymakers and the effect the complexities of the situation have on firefighters and their families. Throughout this week we will be sharing their stories. Click the link in our bio for the full investigation. (Stacey Wescott / Chicago Tribune | @staceywescott27)

Ken Miller is bent at the waist with both arms extended, slowly but steadily pushing the navy trunk on wheels from the Bears equipment room toward the 40-foot semitrailer he’ll use to haul an estimated 12,000 pounds of supplies and equipment to the game. The Bears bring their uniforms on the team plane, but most of their equipment and supplies travel to most road games in Miller’s truck. ⠀
⠀
“This is nothing compared to carrying a dresser down a flight of stairs,” Miller, 68, said. ⠀
⠀
He would know. As the owner of Meyers Movers, Miller has helped move the Bears to and from games and everywhere in between since 1989. His company has moved every coach since Dave Wannstedt and every top personnel executive since Mark Hatley. ⠀
⠀
“Ken is kind of like family,” said Tony Medlin, Bears’ head equipment manager. “What he does for the Bears, he goes over and beyond.” Click the link in our bio for the full story. (John J. Kim / Chicago Tribune)

Federal agents swarmed Ald. Ed Burke’s City Hall and ward offices Thursday morning, kicking out employees and hauling away boxes of records and computers. As the longtime chairman of the city's Finance Committee, described in some circles as “the No. 2 spot in city government,” Burke has great sway over how Chicago spends its money. ⠀
⠀
When the 74-year-old arrived at his Southwest Side home late Thursday, he addressed reporters saying, "I've been involved in previous investigations. I've always cooperated. Nothing has ever come of any of those investigations. I will fully cooperate in this one." Burke is Chicago’s longest-serving politician known for his bold pinstripe suits, great political wealth and being half of one of the city’s elite power couples. ⠀
⠀
As FBI agents rummaged through his offices, the alderman attended a luncheon at the Chicago Yacht Club celebrating his wife, Anne Burke, who on Thursday was sworn into her second 10-year term on the Illinois Supreme Court. As an alderman for nearly 50 years, Burke has been under federal scrutiny several times before, but never indcited or convicted. Click the link in our bio for the full story. (Brian Cassella/Chicago Tribune | @briancassella)

Every day after Gina Ramirez finishes her 1.5 hour commute from the Loop to her home, she reaches for a mop to clean up any toxic dust that may have been tracked inside. Flanked by landfills, steel mills and metal scrap yards, pollution concerns have been part of life on Chicago’s Southeast Side since the 1930s. ⠀
⠀
In response to political pressure from activists, officials began establishing “environmental justice” policies in the 1990s to prevent toxic threats in poor and minority neighborhoods. But a decade after Illinois launched its program, communities like East Side — where 80 percent of the residents are Latino and 25 percent of households make less than $25,000 a year — have seen little progress.
⠀
“It’s just an industrial armpit of Chicago. There’s real people in this neighborhood, trying to raise families, and I just want it to be a little cleaner for my son,” Ramirez said.⠀
⠀
These lasting inequalities raise a troubling question from scholars: Are environmental justice policies actually bridging the gap, or are they solely declarations of good intentions? Click the link in our bio for the full story. (John J. Kim/Chicago Tribune)

The evolving science assessing the increased cancer risks in fighting fires does not yield many definitive answers, experts say. ⠀
⠀
As a result, many fire departments around the country try to mitigate cancer risks through a patchwork of prevention initiatives that are tethered to research, yet stymied by the sometimes contradictory studies. ⠀
⠀
While both researchers and firefighters have long known the dangers of smoke inhalation and the heightened risk of pulmonary disease, various studies within the past five years have led to a better understanding of the possible connection between cancer and the toxins that firefighters are exposed to while on the job. ⠀
⠀
------- ⠀
⠀
In the series “Line of duty: Firefighters and cancer,” the Pioneer Press and the Chicago Tribune explore the research into the suspected relationship between firefighting and cancer, the challenges facing area policymakers and the effect the complexities of the situation have on firefighters and their families. Throughout this week we will be sharing their stories. Click the link in our bio for the full investigation. (Stacey Wescott / Chicago Tribune | @staceywescott27)

Chicagoans flocked to Ivy's Christmas Trees in the Lakeview neighborhood of Chicago to pick out a tree for the holidays post-Thanksgiving. Ivy's is in its 29th year of business selling North Carolina Fraser Firs. ⠀
⠀
A market imbalance was created a decade ago when a surplus of Christmas trees and the Great Recession combined to drive many tree growers out of business, according to the Associated Press. Now the supply is tight and it takes eight to 10 years — the time needed to grow a Christmas tree — to boost the supply. While larger retailers are doing just fine, it's the smaller charitable organizations, school groups, and mom-and-pop operators that have had to scramble for trees. ⠀
⠀
With the lean supply, experts suggest starting early if you want a lot of choice and variety. Click the link in our bio for more. (Erin Hooley/Chicago Tribune | @malarchy) #christmastree #christmasdecor #christmas

Hundreds of police officers, friends and family attend the funeral for Chicago police Officer Samuel Jimenez this afternoon. The ceremony at the Chapel of St. Joseph at Shrine of Our Lady of Guadalupe was a heart-wrenching memorial to a promising young cop, a victim of yet another burst of Chicago’s gun violence. ⠀
⠀
Jimenez, a 28-year-old married father of three, was honored as a loving husband, father, friend and colleague. After the service, his wife, Crystal, received the folded Chicago flag that had been draped atop her husband’s casket as it was carried from the church. Marc Buslik, commander of the Town Hall District where Jimenez worked for a short time, said even though he meets many young officers who come through his district, Jimenez stood out. “In this era of transformation in policing, Sam understood that we don’t just want warriors, we want guardians,” he said. ⠀
⠀
Jimenez was one of three people fatally shot by a gunman who had confronted his former fiancee at Mercy Hospital & Medical Center last week. Also killed were Dr. Tamara O’Neal, who previously had a relationship with the gunman, and pharmacist Dayna Less. Click the link in our bio for the full story. (Chris Walker and Antonio Perez/Chicago Tribune | @walkerpix)

Pedestrians walk along South Michigan Avenue as a winter storm passes through the Chicago area on Sunday, Nov. 25. The National Weather Service issued a blizzard warning for the Chicago metro area Sunday, in effect until 9 a.m. Monday. ⠀
⠀
At the height of the storm, more than 2 inches of snow an hour is possible, combined with winds gusting 40 to 50 mph. The far northwest suburbs could see up to 12 inches of snow, with 10 inches possible at O’Hare and 6 inches possible at Midway. ⠀
⠀
The weather is already responsible for the cancellation of more than 800 flights from area airports, and transportation officials said car travel will be hazardous as well. Click the link in our bio for weather updates. (@mandophotos / Chicago Tribune)

The Bears won their 5th straight game, improving to 8-3 on the season. ⠀
⠀
Chase Daniel started at quarterback in place of the injured Mitch Trubisky in the 23-16 win over the Lions at Ford Field on Thanksgiving. It was Daniel’s first NFL start in four seasons. ⠀
⠀
Daniel did enough with the offense — and the Bears defense came up with two interceptions to put the game away. ⠀
⠀
Eddie Jackson had a pick-six in the fourth quarter. And with the Lions threatening to tie the game late, Kyle Fuller grabbed his fifth interception of the season in the end zone. Click the link in our bio and follow @chitribsports for more Bears coverage. (John J. Kim and Armando L. Sanchez / Chicago Tribune | @mandophotos) #chicagobears #dabears

Temperatures in Chicago teetered on freezing for the city’s Thanksgiving parade in the Loop, so most onlookers were heavily bundled up, bracing themselves against the morning wind and cold in multi-colored, many textured coats, hats, scarves.

The same goes for most of those marching in the parade, who wore long sleeves and thermals under their costumes and uniforms. Despite the cold, some attendees said, the enthusiasm from the performers helped warm spirits. Click the link in our bio for more. (Antonio Perez / Chicago Tribune)

Stefanie Clark knew it was a good roommate match when the first breakfast together in late 2017 was full of laughter. A year later Clark, 73, and Jane Callahan-Moore, 69, finish each other’s sentences and interrupt conversations to compliment each other. They enjoy explaining who cooks breakfast and who makes dinner. ⠀
⠀
Loneliness is one reason elderly adults might seek help finding a roommate. Like Clark and Callahan-Moore, many people prefer to find each other through groups or websites that connect potential roommates, versus the more anonymous and sometimes overwhelming online listings. ⠀
⠀
The two met through the Homesharing Program at the Center on Halsted, which launched as a solution for older LGBTQ adults who might appreciate a person comfortable with an LGBTQ roommate. Since that first breakfast, only the seasons have changed. “Within one month, she made my house a home,” Clark said. Click the link in our bio for the full story. (Brian Cassella / Chicago Tribune | @briancassella)

A young cop, a doctor and a pharmacy resident were killed in an attack at a South Side hospital Monday afternoon that sent medical personnel and police scrambling in search of victims and the shooter before he was found dead. ⠀
⠀
Officer Samuel Jimenez, a father of three young children, had been on the force less than two years. He becomes the second Chicago police officer to die in the line of duty this year. ⠀
⠀
Emergency room doctor Tamara O’Neal was gunned down in the parking lot over a “broken engagement.” Dayna Less, a first-year pharmacy resident, was struck as she walked out of an elevator. ⠀
⠀
The shooter was found with a gunshot wound to the head. It is unclear if the fatal shot was self inflicted or happened while exchanging fire with police. Click the link in our bio for the full story. (Photos by @mandophotos @walkerpix @malarchy / Chicago Tribune)

Did your property tax assessment go way up? Or maybe it’s been too high for years and it finally seems about right? Chicago homeowners are seeing big changes after fixes to the county’s property tax assessment system. ⠀
⠀
Cook County Assessor Joseph Berrios says the new system is “a lot fairer.” But what that means for you depends on where you live. Tax assessments have gone up in many affluent or gentrifying areas where the assessor’s office had previously tended to underestimate homes’ market values. ⠀
⠀
In 43 of the 187 city areas, the median assessed value of a home went down. All but one of those areas are on the South and West sides of the city. Meanwhile, neighborhoods on the North and Northwest sides saw substantial increases. Click the link in our bio for the full story and search for your address to see the trends in your neighborhood. (Chris Walker / Chicago Tribune | @walkerpix)

Josh Bangert was playing basketball this summer when he noticed the vision in his left eye was blurry. ⠀
⠀
The 15-year-old shrugged it off, figuring he just needed glasses. But when he went to the doctor a few weeks later, he was told he had a progressive disease that no surgery or medication could treat. ⠀
⠀
He would likely lose his sight by the end of the year. What came next was an incredible outpouring of support for the sophomore from West Chicago Community High School. ⠀
⠀
One of his mother’s friends suggested Josh make a bucket list of things he wanted to see and set up a GoFundMe to pay for the trips. Within 24 hours, his father got an alert on his phone: They had hit their $20,000 goal. In September, he and his family crossed one item off his bucket list with courtside seats to the Bulls’ first preseason game. Click the link in our bio for the full story. (Nuccio DiNizzo and Armando L. Sanchez / Chicago Tribune | @nucciodinuzzo @mandophotos)

In the past, Michelle Obama has appeared measured and disciplined when appearing in public, delivering speeches or giving interviews. But on Tuesday night, as she launched her book tour in front of a sold out 14,000 person crowd, Obama didn't seem to hold back. ⠀
⠀
Oprah Winfrey, tasked with conducting the interview of Obama, wasted little time warming up the crowd. "I see a few woke men in here," Winfrey added, drawing laughter. Through the run-up to the big event Obama’s supporters seemed to both adore and absorb it all — even those who didn't know they were going. ⠀
⠀
Students from northwest Indiana marched onto a charter bus Tuesday night, under the impression they were going to an entrepreneurial workshop. But as they began cozying into their seats, they found out the bus was headed for the United Center to see Obama and Winfrey. ⠀
⠀
Tamron Matheny, a 17-year-old high school senior from Gary, said the two women are icons for her. "Honestly, I love that they’re black and that they’re women,” she said. "It just really, really feels good to see someone of your race winning." Click the link in our bio for the full story. (Photos by @mandophotos and @malarchy / Chicago Tribune) #iambecoming #becoming #michelleobama

Bernie Bluestein never meant to become a soldier. In an effort to avoid the possibility of being put on the front lines, he decided to apply for an Army-sponsored art course. ⠀
⠀
The 95-year-old has been creative all of his life, from his youth sketching newspaper comic strips and pinup girls in Cleveland to his golden years racking up 30 years’ tenure as an emeritus art student at Harper College in Palatine. But it was in the role of soldier that he created perhaps his most remarkable work. ⠀
⠀
Bluestein was 19 when he joined the military during World War II for an assignment so secretive the details were only declassified in 1996. He and other members of the 1,100-man special unit seemingly created their own army, with lifesize inflatable tanks and planes, and hollow wooden structures meant to resemble bricks-and-mortar military installations. ⠀
⠀
The props were specifically designed to trick Adolf Hitler’s army into believing the Americans were amassing a major military response. Click the link in our bio for more photos and the full story. (Chris Sweda / Chicago Tribune) #veteransday

In January, Chicago’s oldest Billy Goat Tavern location closed temporarily to update its ancient plumbing, lighting and electrical systems. ⠀
⠀
Now the tavern features a room carved from what had been a storage area to host private parties and other events. ⠀
⠀
The most eye-grabbing items in the new space are three large oil paintings, all the work of Bill Siania, the eldest son of Billy Goat owner Sam Sianis. Click the link in our bio for more. (E. Jason Wambsgans / Chicago Tribune | @ejwamb)

When Jennifer Pagonis was born in the winter of 1986, her parents brought her home to a wardrobe of pink and white, ruffles and frills. ⠀
⠀
But three months later, Jennifer’s mother arrived at the pediatrician’s office for what would turn out to be a life-changing diagnosis. Jennifer had been born intersex, or with a body that doesn't fit standard anatomical definitions of male or female. Doctors told her stunned parents that she could never have children, but with surgery, she could look entirely female. ⠀
⠀
Now 32, Pagonis, who no longer identifies as female and goes by the first name Pidgeon, is an intersex activist calling for an end to controversial surgeries on the genitals of babies whose bodies don’t fit standard anatomical definitions of male or female. For more than two decades, intersex people have denounced the surgeries performed on their genitals during infancy or childhood as nonconsensual and damaging, citing consequences including pain, loss of sexual sensation and incorrect gender assignment. ⠀
⠀
“No matter what they say, or how they sugarcoat it, it’s medically sanctioned violence and torture,” Pagonis said. Click the link in our bio for the full story. (Erin Hooley / Chicago Tribune | @malarchy)

Voters showed up at the polls in near record-high numbers for Tuesday's midterm elections, with voters in Chicago and suburban Cook County driven by everything from a 2016 election hangover to a desire to support legal marijuana use. ⠀
⠀
Much of the Chicago turnout was driven by younger voters, with 18-to-34-year-olds casting more than 200,000 ballots. The city announced an unofficial turnout of 55.6 percent, the highest midterm turnout in 32 years. ⠀
⠀
The nights’ results ushered a blue wave into the state, including Democratic wins like Sean Casten's in Illinois’ 6th District, photo 8, and Lauren Underwood's in Illinois’ 14th District, photo 5. Other wins included J.B. Pritzker for governor, photo 6, and Kwame Raoul for Illinois attorney general, photo 2. Click the link in our bio for all our election coverage. (Nuccio DiNuzzo, Terrence Antonio James, Jose M. Osorio, Antonio Perez, Armando L. Sanchez, Abel Uribe and Stacey Wescott / Chicago Tribune | @nucciodinuzzo @joseochicagotrib @mandophotos @staceywescott27) #electionday #midterms

Illinois' 12th District stretches from the St. Louis suburbs across Southern Illinois University in Carbondale to impoverished Cairo at the southern tip of the state. About 700,000 people reside in the Y-shaped district that borders Missouri and Kentucky, then runs up the center of the state on either side of Interstate 57. ⠀
⠀
The largely rural district went for Trump by a huge margin in 2016, but GOP House incumbent Mike Bost (photo 2) is in a close contest with Democratic challenger Brendan Kelly (photo 4) making it the subject of national attention. The campaign cash flowing into southern Illinois from across the country is another signal that Democrats see an opportunity to flip the seat. ⠀
⠀
Click the link in our bio for a complete Illinois voter guide including more on the 12th district, a midterm cheat sheet and full coverage ahead of election day. (@ejwamb/Chicago Tribune)

Fall colors have taken over Chicago as a northerly breeze is keeping temperatures in the 40s for the most part Friday. Click the link in our bio for more photos and a full weather forecast. (Zbigniew Bzdak / Chicago Tribune | @bzdak)

For 21 years, Bozidar Sicel and his family, war refugees from Bosnia, have leaned on Sinai Health System’s Touhy Health Center in Rogers Park. Established in 1973, Touhy’s 15 staff members speak dozens of languages, and have served nearly 80,000 patients since its opening. ⠀
⠀
Even after moving nearly an hour away, Sicel, 68, has many reasons to remain a patient at Touhy, but that may all change Dec. 31, when the clinic is scheduled to close. ⠀
⠀
Changes in federal immigration policy have resulted in fewer refugees arriving in Illinois. Since January 2017, the new-refugee patient population has plummeted at Touhy. Click the link in our bio for the full story. (Jose M. Osorio / Chicago Tribune | @joseochicagotrib)

From Englewood to Rogers Park, Chicago residents celebrate Halloween on Oct. 31, 2018, with treats, games and music. Click the link in our bio for more photos. (John J. Kim and Armando L. Sanchez / Chicago Tribune | @mandophotos)

It’s Halloween, and even Chicago aldermen are joining in on the spooky fun. ⠀
⠀
As Ald. Anthony Beale, 9th, left, spoke today during the City Council meeting, Ald. Susan Sadlowski Garza, 10th, from left, Ald. Patrick Thompson, 11th, and Ald. George Cardenas, 12th, looked on in their respective animal masks at City Hall. ⠀
⠀
Click the link in our bio for more photos from Halloween at the City Council. (Jose M. Osorio / Chicago Tribune | @joseochicagotrib)

For years, the Chicago Skyway’s tollbooth canopies served as gateways to Chicago and northwest Indiana. ⠀
⠀
They also happened to be eyesores. ⠀
⠀
No more. ⠀
⠀
Sixty years after they were built, the canopies have been restored to their original streamlined appearance, with additional modern features like easy-to-read digital signage. Click the link in our bio for more. (Armando L. Sanchez / Chicago Tribune | @mandophotos)

People attend a vigil on Oct. 29, 2018, at Temple Beth Israel in Skokie for victims of the Tree of Life synagogue attack in Pittsburgh. ⠀
⠀
Faith and community leaders in Skokie scheduled the communitywide anti-hate vigil in the wake of Saturday’s shooting massacre at the Tree of Life Congregation synagogue in the Squirrel Hill neighborhood of Pittsburgh that left 11 people dead. Click the link in our bio for more. (Brian Cassella / Chicago Tribune | @briancassella)

Growing up on the city’s Southwest Side, Jocelyn Aranda’s belief in the power of voting was forged as she watched relatives work long hours for low wages, relatives who didn’t feel empowered to speak up because they weren’t U.S. citizens. ⠀
⠀
That experience spurred Aranda, now 19, to spend the past three months knocking on doors in the Little Village neighborhood, registering students at local high schools to vote and trying to galvanize potential voters in advance of the Nov. 6 midterm election. ⠀
⠀
At the top of the ticket, Republican Gov. Bruce Rauner is trying to fend off a vigorous challenge from Democrat J.B. Pritzker — a race in which the outcome could have ramifications on Illinois’ immigrant community. “I want them to take action,” said Aranda. Click the link in our bio for the full story. (Terrence Antonio James / Chicago Tribune)

On Oct. 12, 2018, Lee Lumber, which was founded in 1952, closed its doors after a deal to sell the business fell apart. Word got out about the closure of the largest family-owned lumberyard in Chicago, and co-owner Randy Baumgarten has fielded grateful notes from longtime customers, emotional hugs from employees and many calls about the company’s sign. ⠀
⠀
The sign, made by iconic Chicago sign company White Way, is just one memory that will be left behind as Lee Lumber shutters after 66 years. The company’s materials and workmanship grace structures across the city, including the windows on the Chicago River bridge houses and the ornamental ceiling at Holy Name Cathedral that was restored after a 2009 fire. ⠀
⠀
The company will hold an auction Nov. 6 to sell everything that remains, including showroom merchandise, building materials, tools, manufacturing equipment and the iconic neon sign. Click the link in our bio for the full story. (Jose M. Osorio /  Chicago Tribune | @joseochicagotrib)

Alpana Singh has plenty to say. She’ll talk about the dynamism of Chicago dining, the glory of a well-baked slice of bread and the plot holes in “A Star Is Born.” ⠀
⠀
She’ll photograph her food for possible later posting on Instagram and chat pleasantly with managers, waitstaff and chefs, all of whom are thrilled to see her in their place because of the business boom her visit portends. ⠀
⠀
But when you’re out to dinner with Singh, who has returned to the host’s chair at “Check, Please!,” she will not actually ever say the words that have made her a celebrity in Chicago. Her first episode back airs tonight at 8 p.m. Click the link in our bio for the full story. (Chris Sweda / Chicago Tribune)

If you’re out and about the next few nights, you might want to look up. The moon should look pretty spectacular, if the clouds stay away. ⠀
⠀
But this is not unusual. What Chicagoans are seeing is a standard October full moon and a mix of seasonal changes that make for a more conspicuous sight. Click the link in our bio for the best moon viewing times this weekend. (John J. Kim / Chicago Tribune)

Viewed from the air, the 60 acres between Navy Pier and Michigan Avenue have undergone a stunning transformation. But people experience cities on the ground, not from above. ⠀
⠀
Put that same piece of land under a microscope and what you see is a cityscape of great expectations and half-kept promises. ⠀
⠀
Tribune architecture critic Blair Kamin breaks down the “urban planning flop” that is Cityfront Center and how it serves as a cautionary tale for Chicago’s next round of megaprojects. Click the link in our bio for the full story. (Photos by @briancassella/Chicago Tribune)

As fish farmers dumped 7,500 pounds of rainbow trout into select Cook County Forest Preserve District fishing holes last week, a district official explained why they’re going through the effort. ⠀
⠀
Rainbow trout “are highly sought after, because they’re not available as much around here,” said Steve Silic, head fisheries biologist for the district. “People love to catch them and to eat them.” ⠀
⠀
As proof of that love, he pointed to the hundreds of anglers — perhaps even up to 1,000 per location, Silic said — who were expected to show up when trout season opened Saturday. The opportunity to hook the fresh batch of “catchable-sized” trout may not last, though. Click the link in our bio for more. (Zbigniew Bzdak / Chicago Tribune | @bzdak)

Irma Ruiz Collins, daughter of Irma Ruiz, attends a ceremony Oct. 19, 2018, during which a park in the Archer Heights neighborhood was renamed Irma C. Ruiz Park. ⠀
⠀
Thirty years ago, Ruiz, a Chicago police officer who “took care of everyone,” became one of the first female officers to be killed in the line of duty when a gunman entered a Near West Side school and shot her, instantly ending the life of the beloved wife, mother of four and police partner. ⠀
⠀
More than 100 friends, family, fellow officers — and even the horse named after Ruiz — gathered for the dedication. Click the link in our bio for more. (Zbigniew Bzdak / Chicago Tribune | @bzdak)

In the heart of corn and soybean country, Hans and Katie Bishop of PrairiErth Farm are cultivating an unconventional dream, one pesticide-free, dirt-encrusted sweet potato at a time. ⠀
⠀
Like many young farmers drawn to the local food movement, the Bishops were enthralled by the idea of growing and selling fruits and vegetables that end up on plates in their communities, not commodity crops exported to other countries. ⠀
⠀
Their passion remains strong, but they’ve had to adapt to a changing food industry rife with new competitors. ⠀
⠀
This rush of competition has hurt revenue at many small farms in Illinois — particularly those that rely on sales through what’s known as community supported agriculture programs, or CSAs. Some farms have scaled back operations or closed altogether. Others, like PrairiErth, have changed their business models to survive. Click the link in our bio for the full story. (Chris Walker / Chicago Tribune | @walkerpix)

UniverSoul Circus turns 25 this year, and with that milestone comes acts not seen in last year’s tour including a Rough Riders Cossack Horse Act and a Cuban trampoline act. ⠀
⠀
The Tribune talked with circus founder Cedric Walker about the legacy of his Atlanta-based creation and what the next 25 years will bring. ⠀
⠀
“I think the spirit of UniverSoul emanates from a culture that is always fresh and funky and always finding something new," he said. "People come here with their fresh ideas, so we just keep it funky.” Click the link in our bio for more. (Zbigniew Bzdak / Chicago Tribune | @bzdak)

About three dozen dogs and cats arrived in Chicago on Wednesday after a 20-hour trip to evacuate them from area of Florida hit by Hurricane Michael. ⠀
⠀
The animals, including puppies and kittens, were brought in two vans from Pets Are Worth Saving Chicago, or PAWS, and are expected to be available for adoption Friday. Click the link in our bio for the full story. (Jose M. Osorio / Chicago Tribune | @joseochicagotrib)

America is known as the land of opportunity. But new research suggests the American Dream is much harder to reach for some kids, and that wide differences exist even for those who grow up mere miles apart. ⠀
⠀
A study mapped what happened to kids from different Chicago neighborhoods and found that lifetime earnings and incarceration rates vary greatly. Chicago, which is pictured here from Whiting Lakefront Park as air traffic passes, may be one city, but its neighborhoods present vastly different opportunities. Click the link in our bio to read the full study. (Armando L. Sanchez / Chicago Tribune | @mandophotos)

This morning Chance the Rapper, who’s become increasingly more involved in Chicago politics, threw his support for mayor behind a local activist with whom he says he shares a political vision for the city’s future. ⠀
⠀
Despite rumors he would be announcing his own run for mayor, Chance, whose full name is Chancelor Bennett, said he was backing Amara Enyia, director of the Austin Chamber of Commerce. ⠀
⠀
“I probably won’t ever be running for mayor of this city but I believe that me and Amara share a vision of what Chicago should be,” he said at a City Hall news conference. Click the link in our bio for the full story. (Jose M. Osorio / Chicago Tribune | @joseochicagotrib)

Leaves near the Wrigley Building in downtown have started to take on their autumn colors as chilly weather dominated Chicago Monday. A quick reversal will follow on Tuesday as brisk southwest winds send readings back into the 50s. Click the link in our bio for more weather updates. (Brian Cassella / Chicago Tribune | @briancassella)

Barbie sits with owners Justin Morgan and Walter Reed as she and other pets were blessed during a service on Oct. 14, 2018, at the All Saints Episcopal Church in the Ravenswood neighborhood of Chicago. Services were held as part of the celebration of the feast of St. Francis of Assisi, who is often recognized as the patron saint of animals. Click the link in our bio for more photos. (Erin Hooley / Chicago Tribune | @malarchy)

Less than two years after the attack on Pearl Harbor on Dec. 7, 1941, Technical Sgt. Harry “Bud” Carlsen, 31, a native of suburban Brookfield, died in November 1943 during the Battle of Tarawa in the Pacific theater of World War WII. ⠀
⠀
His remains, along with the remains of 549 other Marines following the battle, were never identified or recovered for decades. But on Wednesday, nearly 75 years after his death, Carlsen finally returned home. ⠀
⠀
Family members and local veterans gathered at O’Hare International Airport on Oct. 10, 2018, to greet the arrival of Carlsen’s remains with a hero’s welcome. Click the link in our bio for the full story. (Stacey Wescott / Chicago Tribune | @staceywescott27)

Chamira Williams, pictured, arrived at Stroger Hospital at 12:15 a.m. Aug. 5 during one of the most violent outbursts of gunfire in Chicago that weekend. Between midnight and 7 a.m. that day, dozens of people were shot across the city and at least 12 of them were also taken to Stroger. ⠀
⠀
Her mother, Lachaka Hobson, said she watched from a waiting room as harried doctors, nurses and other medical personnel worked to save patients. ⠀
⠀
“My baby’s here too,” Hobson remembers thinking. “Why hasn’t anybody come here to even say anything?” ⠀
⠀
Apparently no one from the hospital staff called police after Williams was brought there by friends. Hospital policy requires staff to report so-called walk-in gunshot victims to Chicago police, but the department said it has no record of being notified about Williams until Aug. 21. ⠀
⠀
By that time, evidence was long gone. The car in which she was shot had been broken into. A window shattered in the shooting had been replaced. The recollections of the other people in the car were no longer fresh. No one is in custody. Click the link in our bio for the full story. (Armando L. Sanchez / Chicago Tribune | @mandophotos)

Jose Torres, left, passes the busy commercial intersection on his way to and from work most days. ⠀
⠀
The area on the Southwest Side has changed a lot since that night four years ago when fate brought him and his son, Xavier, there moments before a Chicago police officer fatally shot Laquan McDonald. But the violent images and explosive sounds of gunfire remain seared in their minds. ⠀
⠀
Both took the witness stand last month at Jason Van Dyke’s trial, playing subtle but significant roles as the only civilian eyewitnesses to testify about the shooting. Click the link in our bio for the full story. (Nuccio DiNuzzo / Chicago Tribune | @nucciodinuzzo)

About 45,000 runners wound their way through 29 Chicago neighborhoods throughout the day in the 26.2-mile course of the 2018 Bank of America Chicago Marathon. Participants endured rain and humidity on the fast, flat marathon course, which is home to four world records and several national records. Tribune photojournalists captured moments along the route on race day. Click the link in our bio for more photos and full marathon coverage. (Erin Hooley, Antonio Perez, Armando L. Sanchez, Abel Uribe, E. Jason Wambsgans / Chicago Tribune | @malarchy @mandophotos @ejwamb) #chicagomarathon

Chicago police Officer Jason Van Dyke was convicted Friday of second-degree murder in the death of 17-year-old Laquan McDonald, marking a stunning end to a racially tinged case that roiled the city when now-infamous police dashboard camera video of the shooting was released three years ago by court order. ⠀
⠀
Around the city, a smattering of protesters gathered in public places to watch the verdict unfold. More than two dozen protesters formed a tight circle outside the LaSalle Street entrance to City Hall with their heads leaning in to listen to a livestream of the verdict on a cellphone. ⠀
⠀
The verdict comes after a landmark trial that featured testimony over 10 days by 44 witnesses, 24 called by the prosecution and 20 by the defense. ⠀
⠀
The three-week trial flipped the script of most murder cases at the Leighton Criminal Court Building, with prosecutors questioning the credibility of police officers who typically serve as their most trusted witnesses. Click the link in our bio for more coverage. (John J. Kim, Antonio Perez, Armando L. Sanchez, Chris Walker and E. Jason Wambsgans / Chicago Tribune)

After 13 innings, the Cubs’ season came to a close Wednesday night at Wrigley Field. Rockies catcher Tony Wolters hit an RBI single off Cubs pitcher Kyle Hendricks in the 13th to lift the Rockies to a 2-1 victory in National League wild-card game. ⠀
⠀
The Cubs won 95 regular-season games, but back-to-back losses to the Brewers in Game 163 on Monday and the Rockies on Tuesday night sealed their early playoff exit. ⠀
⠀
For more photos and Cubs coverage, click the link in our bio. (Photos by @nucciodinuzzo @briancassella / Chicago Tribune)

People gathered Oct. 2, 2018, to remember Eliyahu Moscowitz and Douglass Watts after they were both shot and killed in Chicago’s Rogers Park neighborhood. ⠀
⠀
The back-to-back killings seemed to be as random as they were brutal: an elderly man walking his dogs just steps from his home on Sunday and then, barely 36 hours later, a young man walking blocks away on the Lakefront Trail near Loyola Park. Both were shot once in the head and left for dead. ⠀
⠀
But police on Tuesday confirmed what for many residents was their worst fear: The same gun was used to shoot both men, most likely by the same gunman. Just about every other detail remains a mystery. Click the link in our bio for the full story. (Chris Sweda / Chicago Tribune)

After leading the National League Central by five games on Sept. 3, the Cubs’ season has been reduced to a win-or-go-home scenario. ⠀
⠀
The Brewers applied a blend of timely hitting and dominant pitching Monday to beat the Cubs 3-1 in the division tiebreaker before 38,450 fans at Wrigley Field. ⠀
⠀
By virtue of their victory, the Brewers earned the NL Central title and won’t play until Thursday, when they host the first of two games of the best-of-five NL Division Series. ⠀
⠀
The Cubs, whose two-year reign as NL Central champions was snapped, will play host to the loser of the NL West tiebreaker between the Rockies and Dodgers on Tuesday in the NL wild-card game. ⠀
⠀
The winner will face the Brewers. Click the link in our bio for more Cubs coverage. ( Brian Cassella and Armando L. Sanchez / Chicago Tribune) #cubsvsbrewers

Bears quarterback Mitch Trubisky threw six touchdown passes to drive the Bears to a 48-10 victory over the Buccaneers Sunday at Soldier Field. The win gives the Bears their first three-game winning streak since September 2013. ⠀
⠀
Trubisky became only the second player in NFL history to throw five touchdown passes to five different receivers in the first half of a game including a 35-yard pass to Tarik Cohen and a 33-yard pass to Taylor Gabriel. ⠀
⠀
Trubisky was one touchdown pass off his season total of seven in 12 games in 2017. Outside linebacker Khalil Mack has a sack and forced fumble in the second quarter, which he has had in each of his four games this season. Click the link in our bio for more Bears coverage. (@malarchy and @nucciodinuzzo / Chicago Tribune) #bears #nfl #sundayfootball

Some mornings, Jalen Ivy wakes from his dreams and cries. In his dreams, he can walk. ⠀
⠀
He relives the day everything changed and blames himself. If he hadn’t stayed up late writing in his new journal, he wouldn’t have become thirsty and gone downstairs for tea. If he hadn’t gone downstairs for tea, he wouldn’t have been shot. ⠀
⠀
He’s made concessions, from “I want to walk again” to “I want to stand” to “I want to feel my legs.” ⠀
⠀
He doesn’t know whether he will have kids, whether a woman will want him. Whether he will always struggle with bad dreams. And pain. ⠀
⠀
In moments of progress, his mother, Judy Celio, will remind him that, together, they are learning a new way to live. ⠀⠀
⠀
--------- ⠀
⠀
Tribune reporter Pete Nickeas and photojournalist E. Jason Wambsgans reported on and documented Jalen’s recovery in the months following the night he was shot with a bullet meant for someone else. Now, the 12-year-old and his family struggle to find “a new normal.” Click the link in our bio for the full story. (E. Jason Wambsgans / Chicago Tribune | @ejwamb)

Severe thunderstorms hit northern Illinois Tuesday afternoon, leaving downed trees and power lines in their wake and triggering warnings for much of the Chicago area. ⠀
⠀
Storms that prompted a tornado warning west of Galesburg, moved east through the Chicago area, with severe thunderstorm warnings expiring at 6 p.m. in Cook County and northeast Will County including Joliet, as warnings for Lake, Kane, DuPage, Kendall and parts of McHenry counties were called off earlier. ⠀
⠀
Cook, Lake, DuPage, Kane, Will and Kendall remained under a severe thunderstorm watch until 10 p.m., according to the weather service. Click the link in our bio for more. (Terrence Antonio James / Chicago Tribune)

Bears cornerback Bryce Callahan intercepted Cardinals rookie quarterback Josh Rosen with 1 minute, 10 seconds to play to help preserve a 16-14 victory at State Farm Stadium on Sunday. ⠀
⠀
After the Bears forced Cardinals quarterback Sam Bradford to fumble in the fourth quarter, they took a 16-14 lead on Cody Parkey’s 43-yard field goal. ⠀
⠀
The Cardinals then put in Rosen, who drove his offense to the Bears’ 45-yard line. On fourth-and-5, Callahan then stepped in to record the Bears’ third interception of the afternoon and fourth turnover. The Cardinals had 55 seconds to try for a final score, but the Bears defense took Rosen down. ⠀
⠀
The victory gave the Bears (2-1) a record better than .500 for the first time since they beat the Jets on Sept. 22, 2014, to improve to 2-1. The Bears are also alone in first place in the NFC North. Click the link in our bio for more Bears coverage. (John J. Kim and Armando L. Sanchez / Chicago Tribune | @mandophotos) #chivsaz #dabears

Kanye West holds his son, Saint, and waves to fans before the start of the game between the Chicago Cubs and the Chicago White Sox at Guaranteed Rate Field in Chicago on Sept. 23, 2018. The rapper made headlines last week when he announced that he plans to move back to Chicago. ⠀
⠀
“I’ve got to let you all know that I’m moving back to Chicago,” West said Sept. 17 at “Open Mike,” Chance the Rapper’s open mic event at Harold Washington Library for high school students. “I’m never leaving again.” ⠀
⠀
West threw the ceremonial first pitch at the start of Sunday's Cubs-Sox game. Click the link in our bio for more coverage. (Nuccio DiNuzzo / Chicago Tribune | @nucciodinuzzo) #cubsvssox

Miguel Orr Jr., left, and Steve McMullan II watch the sunset from Burnham Park along Lake Michigan on Sept. 19, 2018. The waterfront likely will see more traffic later this week as warm, humid air will surge into our area, potentially pushing heat indexes to the 100-degree mark Thursday before dropping again for the weekend. Click the link in our bio for more. (Armando L. Sanchez / Chicago Tribune | @mandophotos)

This year, Riot Fest kicked off on Sept. 14, 2018, in Chicago’s Douglas Park and is running through Sept. 16. The shows have gone on even though the music festival's initial rollout was rocky — the second wave of the lineup hadn’t been announced a week before its start, fans were without stage-by-stage schedules and set times, and single- and two-day tickets didn’t go on sale until early Friday evening. Click the link in our bio for more coverage. (John J. Kim and Chris Sweda/Chicago Tribune) #riotfest

Laquan McDonald, 17, was fatally shot in 2014 near this Southwest Side street. His death at the hands of a Chicago police officer initially drew little attention. More than a year later, though, that changed in dramatic fashion with the court-ordered release of a video showing the white officer shooting the black teen 16 times. The vivid image of Officer Jason Van Dyke unloading his gun on McDonald as the teen appeared to walk away with a knife in his hand has rocked Chicago in the three years since. ⠀
⠀
In a decision with potentially far-reaching consequences, Van Dyke’s attorneys announced Friday they will let 12 jurors selected this week decide the Chicago police officer’s guilt or innocence. It was extraordinarily rare for such a critical choice — a bench or jury trial — to be decided so late in such high-profile proceedings. ⠀
⠀
Opening statements are slated to begin Monday. Click the link in our bio for more. (Armando L. Sanchez / Chicago Tribune | @mandophotos)

Striking hotel workers and supporters marched up North Michigan Avenue to the Drake hotel today in Chicago. ⠀
⠀
The downtown hotel worker strike, which UNITE HERE Local 1 says is the broadest coordinated hotel strike the city has seen, ended its first week with no end in sight as workers miss paychecks and hotels feel the pinch of missing workers. ⠀
⠀
Some guests have complained of long lines to check in, rooms not being cleaned and noise from chanting protesters, and some hotel restaurants have closed because of the work stoppage. In addition, at least two conferences have relocated so as not to cross picket lines. Click the link in our bio for the full story. (John J. Kim / Chicago Tribune)

Falling behind early thanks to a lack of hitting created an ominous task for the Cubs as they fell 5-1 to the Brewers Wednesday night in Wednesday’s National League Central showdown at Wrigley Field. The loss shrinks their NLC lead to just one game. ⠀
⠀
The Cubs managed only five hits in seven innings against Chase Anderson and three relievers. Milwaukee left-hander Josh Hader struck out Kris Bryant, Anthony Rizzo and Javier Baez — all on 97 mph fastballs. Ben Zobrist was the lone Cub to to get a hit off Hader. Click the link in our bio for more Cubs coverage. (Armando L. Sanchez / Chicago Tribune | @mandophotos) #cubs #mlb #baseball

Horse-drawn carriage rides could soon be coming to an end in Chicago. Tonight, the City Council’s Committee on License and Consumer Protection is scheduled to consider a proposed ordinance that would bar horse-drawn carriage owners from renewing their licenses, effectively putting them out of business. ⠀
⠀
A group of aldermen have been pushing to ban the carriages for years, claiming it is archaic and from an "era that no longer exists." But horse and carriage owners say they’ve done nothing wrong, the horses are well cared for and their presence adds charm to the city’s Magnificent Mile. ⠀
⠀
Click the link in our bio for the full story. (Chris Sweda / Chicago Tribune)

“Four nerds from Chicago” were exactly what fans at Wrigley Field got Saturday night as the pop-punk prodigal sons of Fall Out Boy wrapped up the concert season at the ballpark with a nearly two-hour set. ⠀
⠀
A montage of baby pictures and the band’s rise to fame flashed across the lone projection screen, as beloved Cubs’ announcer, the late Harry Caray, sang “Take Me Out to the Ball Game.” ⠀
⠀
Feelings of nostalgia and sentimentality were in the air long before the band ripped into early fan favorite “Chicago is So Two Years Ago." Read the Tribune’s full review of the concert by clicking the link in our bio. (Chris Sweda/Chicago Tribune)

Ken Walczak, senior manager for Far Horizons at the Adler Planetarium, holds a hot air balloon in place as other team members make final adjustments before releasing it from Kankakee River State Park in Bourbonnais on July 24, 2018, in an effort to map Chicago’s light pollution. ⠀
⠀
Mapping terrestrial light emissions has been done with images from satellites in orbit, of course. And it’s been done with airplanes. But that middle realm, with the balloons operating at about 80,000 feet, should provide a better perspective than a plane and more detail than a satellite. And it is much cheaper to pull off than the other two options, assuming the not-insignificant engineering challenges can be solved. Click the link in our bio for the full story. (Chris Sweda / Chicago Tribune)

On a muggy July morning, Othea Loggan walked into the kitchen at Walker Bros. Original Pancake House. He arrived as he had for decades, since March 30, 1964, through a side door, at 5:50 a.m., a headlong wave of motion among a staff still getting adjusted to the hour. ⠀
⠀
He is 72 now. He’s never left the restaurant, never graduated to serving tables, never became a manager or a chef — he says he never asked to do anything else. So, he has stayed a busboy, for 54 years. Click the link in our bio for the full story. (Stacey Wescott / Chicago Tribune | @staceywescott27)
Edwin Mackell, 64, feeds birds at Lane Beach while the sun rises over Lake Michigan on Sept. 2, 2018, in Chicago. (Armando L. Sanchez / Chicago Tribune | @mandophotos)

Built on a foundation of limestone to discourage tunneling out, the Old Joliet Prison once housed 1,800 inmates, some as young as 10 years old. One of the largest in the nation at the onset of the 20th century, it was never intended to appear pleasant, but rather, consciously impervious and intimidating. ⠀
⠀
The 160-year-old prison has been a tourist preoccupation as early as the 1880s. In its first decades the prison charged 25 cents per tour, handing each visitor a card telling them not talk to or point at the criminals. This week the Joliet Area Historical Museum reopened the prison for its first round of tours. ⠀
⠀
The deeper you go into the jail the more you feel a palpable desertion. Since the facility was abandoned in 2002, tall stacks of medical paperwork are still strewn, glass litters the floor and dust fills the air. Its spooky, neglected grounds still attract the curious. Tours will be held three days a week, for $20 per person. Click the link in our bio for the full story. (Zbigniew Bzdak / Chicago Tribune | @bzdak)

America’s Best Frisbee Dogs took the field at halftime last night during the #ChicagoBears’ and #BuffaloBills’ preseason finale at Soldier Field. (Brian Cassella / Chicago Tribune | @briancassella) #dogsofinstagram

Nine children were killed in an apartment fire Sunday morning in what officials say was the deadliest city fire in a decade. One boy, 14, remains in critical condition. ⠀
⠀
The children, most of whom are cousins, were at a sleepover at the apartment in the 2200 block of South Sacramento Avenue in Little Village when the fire broke out. At least three GoFundMe campaigns have been launched to help affected families. ⠀
⠀
Officials have ruled out electrical problems as a possible fire source, noting evidence of fireworks and smoking materials were found at the scene. Click the link in our bio for the full story. (Photos by Antonio Perez, @malarchy and Abel Uribe / Chicago Tribune)

More than 100 people attended the “Bridging the Gap Globally” charity basketball tournament Aug. 18, 2018, at 61st and Halsted streets in Chicago’s Englewood neighborhood. ⠀
⠀
Although the violence affecting parts of the city did not touch the weeklong event, it was certainly on the minds of some attendees. Just a day before, on Aug. 17, a fight broke out at a basketball league in Garfield Park. A 15-year-old was shot in the chest and later died at Stroger Hospital. He would have turned 16 over the weekend. ⠀
⠀
As the tournament was underway, a shooting broke out Aug. 18 at a similar event, a “peace picnic” in a Near North Side park. Three people were shot after an argument ended in gunfire, a witness said. ⠀
⠀
The violence is worrisome, organizers of the Englewood event said, but tragedy would not stop them from concluding their tournament. Click the link in our bio for the full story. (Armando L. Sanchez / Chicago Tribune | @mandophotos)

Dr. Irwin Adam Eydelnant is the co-founder and creative director of Chicago’s new Instagram-friendly pop-up attraction known as the wndr museum. The museum began with a calculated mystery: What was this thing that would feature an “Infinity Room” by Japanese artist Yayoi Kusama, and where would it be? ⠀
⠀
Last Thursday, it had another kind of mystery: What happened that is keeping it from opening on time? ⠀
⠀
Hours before the multimonth West Loop attraction was to open Friday, Aug. 17, and apparently shortly after its VIP preview party Wednesday night, wndr museum stopped selling tickets on its website. Click the link in our bio for the full story. (Nuccio DiNuzzo / Chicago Tribune | @nucciodinuzzo) #yayoikusama #infinitymirrors #infinityroom

Barry the dog pauses for a cool drink at Jackson Bark in Chicago’s Jackson Park. Although not officially designated a dog-friendly area, Jackson Bark has been a place to take four-legged friends for years. ⠀
⠀
South Side residents have been hounding officials for years about creating some open spaces for their pups but with little luck. Of the city’s 25 dog parks, 23 are on the North Side. Just two are in the South Loop and none are south of 18th Street, a fact that prompted the Tribune Editorial Board to ask last year “Is Mayor Rahm Emanuel a cat person?” ⠀
⠀
But that’s starting to change. Five dog parks are either in the proposal or groundbreaking stage on the South Side. Click the link in our bio for the full story. (Terrence Antonio James / Chicago Tribune)

U.S. Air Force Thunderbirds pass over Lake Michigan near Chicago on Aug. 16, 2018, after taking off from the Gary Jet Center before performing over the weekend in the 60th Chicago Air and Water Show. ⠀
⠀
Click the link in our bio to check out where to watch, how to get there and the planes you’ll see this weekend. (Armando L. Sanchez / Chicago Tribune | @mandophotos) #chicagoairandwatershow

Nora Flanagan, an English teacher from Northside College Prep, shows her tattoos that include references to her favorite books and the words, “read more” during a visit to Googlepalooza, an education technology summit at Whitney Young High School. ⠀
⠀
“There was definitely an idea of what a teacher should look like,” Flanagan, now 42, recalls of her early career in the late 1990s. But several years into her job at Chicago’s Lane Tech College Prep High School, Flanagan got a teaching award, tenure and greater confidence. She accumulated more tattoos, letting them creep visibly down her arms. ⠀
⠀
“I’m the tattooed teacher,” said Flanagan, adding that she has gotten no complaints from parents or administration. “It’s a big deal to the kids for a day and then I start to give them grades like everyone else, and no one cares.” ⠀
⠀
A new study on tattoos at work has come to a similar conclusion: No one seems to mind. Click the link in our bio for the full story. (Chris Walker / Chicago Tribune | @walkerpix)

Despite years of lower-than-expected demand in Illinois’ medical cannabis pilot program, growers around the state are expanding with the expectation that more residents will gain access to the drug; be it through patient applications, legislation or the election of a more weed-friendly governor. ⠀
⠀
The opioid bill sitting on Gov. Bruce Rauner’s desk would allow medical marijuana to be used in place of prescription painkillers. If the bill becomes law, a boost in demand is certain. The state’s prescription monitoring program tracked 1.5 million opioid prescriptions in the first quarter of 2017 — that equates to more than one opioid prescription for every 8.5 Illinois residents. ⠀
⠀
Since Illinois' marijuana dispensaries opened almost three years ago, more than 42,000 people have enrolled in the medical cannabis program. Click the link in our bio for the full story. (Erin Hooley / Chicago Tribune | @malarchy)

Cubs third baseman David Bote’s walk-off grand slam home run stuns the Washington Nationals in the ninth inning and propels the northsiders to a 4-3 victory, Aug. 12, 2018. Click the link in our bio for Bote’s reaction. (Nuccio DiNuzzo / Chicago Tribune | @nucciodinuzzo) #cubs #chicagocubs #wrigleyfield #grandslam #everybodyin

The Bud Billiken Parade (nicknamed "The Bud") has been a back-to-school celebration and showcase for the city's talented young people since 1929. Tribune photojournalist John J. Kim photographed the dozens of bands, dance and drill teams, marching units, local and state politicians, floats and celebrities that traveled the 2-mile parade route through Bronzeville yesterday, Aug. 11, before gathering in Washington Park for a picnic with food and drink, a mini job fair, face painting, games and giveaways including medical screenings and school supplies. Click the link in our bio for more photos. (John J. Kim / Chicago Tribune)

The Cook County Forest Preserve District can’t explain how half its elk herd at Busse Woods died last year. ⠀
⠀
Kept in a 17-acre pen with an open pasture and shaded woodland, the animals sometimes disappear into high grass, making them nearly invisible to even the forest preserve workers responsible for caring for them and giving them water. ⠀
⠀
For more than three weeks last September, the employees responsible for the animals’ care noted in internal logs that they had not spotted a single one of the six elk that roamed there. By the end of the month, however, officials discovered three were dead — possibly from dehydration, records show. Click the link in our bio for the full story. (Stacey Wescott / Chicago Tribune)

Immigrants at the Marie Joseph House of Hospitality in Cicero get their first taste of what feels like freedom as they wait for their asylum cases to be heard. Those staying in the house have their own bedrooms and regular meals they can prepare and cook themselves. ⠀
⠀
Behind the building is a community garden where residents, many with farming backgrounds, plant and pick vegetables for meals. Inside is a social room filled with board games where residents can chat or watch television. A second-floor chapel inside the building is filled with boxes of clothing and other donations. ⠀
⠀
Staff members at Joseph House think their model of providing housing and resources will help asylum-seekers integrate into American life, and could be extended to the myriad immigrants turning themselves in at America’s southern border. Click the link in the bio for the full story. (Antonio Perez / Chicago Tribune)

Lola, 82, folds clothing inside a laundromat surrounded by crime scene tape where a person was shot near the 3900 block of South Archer Avenue early Monday Aug. 6, 2018 in Chicago. ⠀
⠀
At least 75 people were shot and 12 killed in one of the city’s most violent weekends this year. The victims’ ages ranged from 11 to 62, with most of them shot on the South and West sides. ⠀
⠀
The staggering numbers attracted national attention and Mayor Rahm Emanuel and police Superintendent Eddie Johnson reacted angrily Monday, calling on neighbors to come forward to help police stem the runaway violence. ⠀
⠀
“Don't think for a moment people don't know in the neighborhood who was responsible ... The offender in almost every situation is known by somebody," Emanuel said. "They have a moral responsibility to speak up.” ⠀
⠀
Over the weekend, shooters targeted large groups at a block party, a funeral and other outdoor gatherings. Police say many of the shootings appear to be targeted attacks by gang members who shoot into summer crowds at night. Click the link in the bio for the full story. (@mandophotos / Chicago Tribune)

Four people were shot in the 1600 block of South Avers in Lawndale. Eight in the 1300 block of West 76th Street in Gresham. Six in Lawndale again. Four more in West Humboldt Park. Three others in West Garfield Park. ⠀
⠀
At least 41 people were shot from 11 a.m. Saturday through Sunday morning, four fatally, police said. Three of those deaths happened since about midnight in a period when 35 people were shot. During one 2½-hour early morning period alone, 25 people were shot — two fatally — in five multiple-injury shootings, police said. ⠀
⠀
Resources at local hospitals were taxed as victims and their families poured in. Access to Stroger Hospital, where Tribune photojournalist Antonio Perez took this photo, was tightened. At one point, more than 200 people had converged on the hospital. Mount Sinai Hospital had to stop accepting new emergency cases for a while. ⠀
⠀
About 15 victims were in their teens. One was 11. In the shooting in Gresham, seven of the victims were 21 or younger. Click the link in the bio for the full story. (Antonio Perez / Chicago Tribune)

Halfway through Lollapalooza 2018, acts such as Camilla Cabello, Tyler, the Creator, Post Malone and The National have taken the stage among many others. Day one of the festival sent 46 people to local hospitals and two arrests were made. Click the link in our bio for full day-by-day coverage. (Photos by Abel Uribe, Kristan Lieb and John J. Kim / Chicago Tribune)

A demonstration trumpeted as a way to deliver an anti-violence message to the more affluent North Side briefly shut down Lake Shore Drive during the afternoon rush on Aug. 2, 2018, and culminated with a peaceful protest beneath Wrigley Field’s iconic marquee. ⠀
⠀
The protest was not large in size, with only a couple of hundred protesters marching and chanting in the streets. But it caused a ripple of traffic disruptions that clogged Lakeview streets for several hours. The anti-violence protest was the second in less than a month to target the shutdown of a Chicago expressway, a tactic designed to maximize exposure for the message. Click the link in our bio for the full story. (Brian Cassella, John J. Kim and Armando L. Sanchez / Chicago Tribune)

From his windows up high in a Hyde Park retirement home, Eugene Parker can see, fittingly, the great mass of the Museum of Science and Industry, and the distinctive rooftops of the University of Chicago.⠀
⠀
He also can watch the sun as it rises over the lake and sets in the west, which is even more fitting because, as much as any human alive, Parker is responsible for our understanding of the star that keeps us alive.⠀
⠀
As a young U. of C. scientist in the mid-1950s, he performed some calculations and realized there must be a “solar wind” — his term — propelling material outward from the sun and affecting the entire solar system. The astronomical community scoffed at this upstart insight, and then, within a few years, early space missions proved it true.⠀
⠀
As a 91-year-old emeritus professor, he will be at Cape Canaveral next month to watch NASA launch its Parker Solar Probe, the agency’s first mission named for a living person. Click the link in our bio for the full story. (Chris Sweda / Chicago Tribune)

Last night, the Foo Fighters played for a packed Wrigley Field in the first of a two-night stand. The veteran band embraced almost any opportunity to go bigger and longer, and the 160-minute concert came across as the antithesis of the get-in, get-out mentality of leader Dave Grohl’s hardcore roots and allowed the energetic frontman ample time to serve as an everything-to-everyone showman. The band takes the stage again tonight. Click the link in our bio for more photos and the full review. (Armando L. Sanchez / Chicago Tribune | @mandophotos) #foofighters

Tonight is the last night of @refinery29’s @29rooms, Chicago’s latest “sensory” event, with each room offering a range of emotions. ⠀
⠀
Chicago artist Shani Crowe and muralist Max Sansing are featured in the space. Crowe, a resident of the Greater Grand Crossing area, said her work, “Rest in Power, Rest in Peace,” is a “humanitarian, cathartic shrine experience for a city who needs it; a shrine for the dead and the living on the astral plane, the ‘in between’ or in another dimension.” The exhibit is made up of two rooms: one has a chair and many cowry shells; the other one, below, has a shrine with a golden glow. Visitors can write a note to someone they’ve lost or a hope for the future. ⠀
⠀
Sansing, an Avalon Park native, put his stamp on 29Rooms via a mural on the warehouse space that holds the event. The image overlooks Ashland Avenue, and Sansing describes the work with phrases like feminine energy, innovation, vividness and respect. Click the link in our bio for more photos and the full story. (Jose M. Osorio / Chicago Tribune | @joseochicagotrib) #29rooms

Just eight classes into a music education course at Cook County Jail, inmate D’Andre Morris already looked like a professional. Using an Apple computer connected to two subwoofers, Morris deftly cut and blended musical tracks at a new recording studio in the basement of the jail’s medium-maximum Division 11. ⠀
⠀
“It’s a blessing,” Morris said of the freshly painted 33-by-25-foot cinder block storage room, the result of fundraising efforts by local musician Antony Ablan. ⠀
⠀
As Morris adjusted sound levels at Ablan’s gentle instruction, four other young men sat in a semicircle behind them. They laughed and chatted about their new song, “Choices,” scribbling down lyrics or shortcut keys for the sound-editing software. ⠀
⠀
In Chicago, where scores of young men, some with ties to gangs and violent drug-selling cliques, dream of reaching rap music stardom, Ablan and others believe the music studio could be a new approach to keep inmates mentally engaged. Click the link in our bio for the full story. (Zbigniew Bzdak / Chicago Tribune | @bzdak)

Cubs first baseman Anthony Rizzo gets dunked by Albert Almora Jr. and Kyle Schwarber after launching a 453-foot, walk-off home run in the ninth inning to culminate a dramatic 7-6 comeback victory over the Diamondbacks Thursday in his 1,000th career game. ⠀
⠀
Rizzo's homer came right after David Bote’s two-run, game-tying home run. Bote now has been promoted from Triple-A Iowa five times and has responded with a .326 batting average while filling in capably at second and third base. ⠀
⠀
“The best is yet to come for our starting rotation,” Rizzo said. Click the link in our bio for the full story and gallery. (@briancassella / Chicago Tribune) #Cubs

John Kiefner, a Manhattan, Ill., farmer who grows corn and soybeans is trying this year to make a profit from production of straw and hay in response to the United States' trade war with China and lower soybean prices. ⠀
⠀
Illinois soybean farms could lose up to $420 million as a result of the Chinese tariffs imposed earlier this month on $34 billion worth of U.S. imports — a retaliation to Trump’s tariffs on an equivalent amount of Chinese goods. Illinois was the largest soybean-producing state last year, with more than $3 billion in exports, shipping more to China than any other state. ⠀
⠀
This week the USDA said it would free up $12 billion in short-term aid, a one-time “bridge” for farmers. But some worry that in the long run, the tariffs will prompt China to take its business elsewhere and become more self-reliant. Click the link in our bio for the full story. (Zbigniew Bzdak / Chicago Tribune)

Earlier this month, Chicago’s Pilsen neighborhood was listed by Forbes as one of the world’s “coolest” alongside neighborhoods in cities around the globe, from Athens and Amsterdam to Barcelona, Cape Town and Saigon. This West Side enclave with a rich heritage made the list as those behind the compilation noted its “hip galleries and walls decorated with colorful murals dating from the 1970s.” ⠀
⠀
The article also cites its importance as home of the National Museum of Mexican Art, a 10,000-piece collection in Pilsen. ⠀
⠀
The president of the museum, Carlos Tortolero, said his institution is right where it should be, given the historical influence of Mexican immigrants on the area. ⠀
⠀
“Pilsen is the heart of the Mexican community,” he said. “It’s not the largest concentration of Mexican immigrants, it’s not the oldest, but it’s the heart. It’s like a holy land — and so we had to be in Pilsen.” Click the link in our bio to read the full story. (Antonio Perez / Chicago Tribune)

Last weekend, Pitchfork Music Festival returned to Union Park in Chicago for its 13th year and brought all kinds of musical artists including Lauryn Hill, Chaka Khan, The War on Drugs, Tame Impala and more. Click the link in our bio to check out more sights and sounds from the festival. (John J. Kim, Kristen Norman and Courtney Pedroza / Chicago Tribune) #p4kfest

It’s been 25 years since Michael Jordan’s father was murdered beside a road in North Carolina, a shocking crime that, in part, prompted the Bulls star’s retirement from basketball and sent two teenagers to prison for life. Now, as one of the convicted felons bids for a new trial, key questions about the case remain. ⠀
⠀
In 2009, Chicago Tribune photojournalist @briancassella photographed this parking lot of the now-demolished Quality Inn on Kenric Road, a service drive near the intersection of U.S. Highway 74 and Interstate 95. According to the prosecution's case, James Jordan was killed in his Lexus while parked near the old motel. Click the link in our bio for the full story. (Brian Cassella / Chicago Tribune | @briancassella)

Blood-soaked smocks have moved on from Chicago’s Fulton Market district, replaced by the white tablecloths of hip restaurants and the white collars of office workers. ⠀
⠀
Soaring property values have been good for many longtime meatpackers, who have cashed out for millions of dollars and relocated to modernized facilities. But as food wholesaling businesses fan out from the area just west of the Kennedy Expressway, a tightly concentrated ecosystem that once supplied many of the city’s restaurants is now mostly gone. ⠀
⠀
Chicago Tribune photojournalist @joseochicagotrib spent some time at Bridgford Foods, which until now has made its jerky and sausage in Fulton Market. The meatpacker is one of the businesses in the process of moving its operations to a larger and more efficient building in Back of the Yards. Click the link in our bio for the full story. (Jose M. Osorio / Chicago Tribune | @joseochicagotrib)

Monarch butterflies are in their high summer mating and reproductive stages and Chicago, which is right in the center of their migratory range, is enjoying an annual upsurge in monarch sightings. ⠀
⠀
Even so, the number of monarchs we see today is still lower than what Chicago used to see in past seasons. The monarch population has plummeted over the past two decades, dropping nearly 80 percent, mostly due to habitat loss. ⠀
⠀
Scientific work spearheaded by Abigail Derby Lewis, a conservation ecologist and senior program manager for the Field Museum’s Keller Science Action Center, is finding more opportunities for changes in urban land use that will support their habitat. ⠀
⠀
Chicago could have a key role to play in the monarchs’ story: “Chicago,” Lewis says, “is right in the heart of the most important area for monarch breeding throughout the summer.” Click the link in our bio for the full story. (Chris Sweda / Chicago Tribune)

Harith Augustus was shot on July 14 while Chicago police officers tried to detain the 37-year-old barber for carrying a gun in the city’s South Shore neighborhood. Unrest and outrage followed, as protests over the shooting began shortly after and continued throughout the weekend. ⠀
⠀
On Sunday police released a snippet of video taken from an officer’s body-worn camera, which appears to show Augustus break away from officers and move his hand toward his waistband. He was shot dead in the street. The video runs less than a minute and does not include sound, prompting questions about what exchanges occurred in the seconds before the shooting. ⠀
⠀
Monday, just one day after Superintendent Eddie Johnson promised transparency, Chicago police refused to release additional footage of the shooting and protests continued. Click the link in our bio for the full story. (Nuccio DiNuzzo and Terrence Antonio James / Chicago Tribune)

As France and Croatia took the field to play the final match of the 2018 World Cup, Chicagoans gathered at watch parties at the Hilton Magnificent Mile in Streeterville to cheer on the French and the Croatian Cultural Center in West Rogers Park on July 15, 2018. France won 4-2 and took home its second World Cup title. Click the link in our bio for more photos. (Brian Cassella and Courtney Pedroza / Chicago Tribune) #WorldCup

By the time a stream of speeding police squad cars, fire trucks and ambulances arrived at Loyola Beach on July 6, 2018, and officers started jumping into the turbulent waves, 13-year-old Darihanne Torres couldn’t even be seen in Lake Michigan. At the time this photo was taken, another 13-year-old girl was rescued, but Darihanne was pronounced dead a few hours later. She is among a handful of people since 2010 to drown at a Chicago beach when no lifeguard was on duty, according to data collected by the Great Lakes Surf Rescue Project. ⠀
⠀
Nine years ago, a lifeguard would have been nearby to warn Darihanne and her friends to stay out of the lake — or jump to the rescue if they did go in. Prior to 2009, lifeguards were on duty at Chicago Park District beaches from 9 a.m. to 8:30 p.m. ⠀
⠀
But in an effort to save about $700,000 a year — about $825,000 in today’s dollars — the Park District cut the hours covered by lifeguards by 30 percent, stationing them on beaches only from 11 a.m. to 7 p.m. In the wake of Darihanne’s death, some Chicagoans think it’s time for the Park District to revisit that decision. Click the link in our bio for the full story. (Armando L. Sanchez / Chicago Tribune | @mandophotos)

The third floor of the Center on Halsted is home to many things — a gymnasium, youth programs and art installations. But tucked behind the doors of an “Authorized Personnel Only” sign is a small kitchen where 25 people from all walks of life train in the culinary arts for nine weeks at Silver Fork. ⠀
⠀
“I call it culinary boot camp,” said Nicole Pederson, director of culinary arts. The program is a 9-week-long course that trains people on understanding recipes, the language of the kitchen, knife skills and front of house responsibilities. The program itself is free, and students are given a stipend to pay for shoes, knives, a uniform or other necessities. ⠀
⠀
