Chicago set a record high temperature Monday at O'Hare Airport, and with temperatures still rising it's not clear where the new record will stand, according to the National Weather Service. It's the fourth day in a row the city has seen record-high temperatures.  Friday's record of 67 beat the old high of 60 in 1880. Saturday was 70, which beat a record of 62 from 1981. Sunday saw a high of 69, which overtook a high of 65 from 1930. The city also tied a February record for longest stretch of 60 degree or higher days in February with four. Ryan Loess, cultivation manager at PharmaCann, LLC, a medical marijuana cultivation center in Dwight, Ill. tends to cannabis plants on Jan. 23, 2017. State lawmakers approved Illinois' pilot medical cannabis program in 2013, and dispensaries started opening two years later. Despite generating more than $42 million in retail sales so far, the nascent industry in Illinois is going through more than the normal growing pains of new companies. It's marijuana, after all, and entrepreneurs are learning just how hard it is to shake off the stigma attached to a substance the federal government puts in the same class as heroin and LSD. Illinois companies also are grappling with slower-than-expected growth of patient numbers, so while they wait for demand to increase here, they are eyeing other states for expansion. Photo @bzdak #marijuana #cannabis #medicalmarijuana #illinois

People cheer as Maha arrives at Terminal 5 of O'Hare International Airport on Sunday, Jan. 29, 2017, two days after President Donald Trump ordered travel restrictions on seven Muslim-majority countries. Originally from Syria, she has lived in Chicago for five years and was on a trip to Lebanon. Family said she was stopped for about three hours of questioning after arriving. Trump's executive order freezes entry of all refugees to the U.S. for 120 days, halts Syrian refugees indefinitely and places a 90-day moratorium on the arrival of citizens of the predominantly Muslim countries of Iran, Iraq, Libya, Somalia, Sudan, Syria and Yemen. At least 50 people were held Sunday at O'Hare for further questioning, including those from non-Muslim countries like Mexico, according to lawyers at the scene. It was unclear whether the questioning of the Mexican travelers was related to Trump's order. Brian Cassella/Chicago Tribune @briancassella #immigration #protest #ohare

Protesters block a road at O'Hare International Airport Saturday night after travelers were held, including those with green cards and visas, following President Donald Trump's executive orders on immigration. Thirteen people were believed to be in custody Saturday night as authorities enforced Trump’s executive order on immigration from certain majority-Muslim countries – a crackdown that left relatives frantic and prompted protesters to rush to the airport. Hundreds protested inside and outside O’Hare’s international terminal, chanting, “The whole world is watching.” As the crowds swelled, police shut down vehicle access to the terminal. “It’s horrifying,” Chicago resident Rachel Shinville, 24, said of the ban. “It’s inhumane and I’m pretty sure it’s illegal. It takes a lot of people to allow something like this to happen.”Chris Sweda/Chicago Tribune #refugee #immigration #protest

Syrian refugee Huda Hidar sits with her daughter Yara, 15, in their Evanston home. Hidar, 43, fled war-torn Syria with her daughter and four sons last summer after surviving an airstrike and then losing her husband and son in a chemical attack. She worries that the new restrictions might make it harder for other refugees like them to escape the Middle East. “We are not doing anything, not terrorism or anything. Why would he ban us?” Hidar says of President Donald Trump. Chicago immigration reform advocates and Muslim leaders denounced President Donald Trump 's executive order to temporarily block refugees coming to the U.S., calling it an effective ban on Muslims in America. In issuing the order Friday, which calls for a four-month halt on all refugee admissions, an indefinite ban on Syrian refugees and a temporary moratorium on immigrants from countries that don't comply with security procedures, Trump said he seeks to protect the nation from terrorist attacks. Noor Saadeh and her nephew Zain, 2, and fiancee Roshan Ali watch family and friends play #basketball during a Chicago Muslim Basketball League game on Jan. 17, 2017. The all-Muslim league began about 10 years ago, and it quickly grew into an annual league drawing players throughout Illinois and out of state before teams began traveling nationally for tournaments. The league also picks a charity or cause — such as helping a local woman who needed an organ transplant or donating to Syrian refugee organizations — to contribute money raised each year. “In the current climate, when there's a lot that's negative in the news and media about Muslims, you find people who come with a common goal. It doesn't matter what you think or what your differences are, you're on the same team and have a good bond. People start to learn from each other. Newton Minow, the former FCC chairman famous for describing TV as a "vast wasteland" in 1961, poses inside his Chicago residence near Lake Shore Drive. No, he doesn't think TV is a vast wasteland anymore.  No matter how long you put off asking about his relationship to TV, it's never far from his mind. He knows people who know his name remember that his "vast wasteland" speech, given to a conference of broadcasters in 1961 and advocating for community and educational responsibility from the medium, angered the TV industry and delighted highbrows. He knows that most people don't realize that speech was also, in part, an argument for TV's ambition at a moment when television and its programming was still considered a very low art. "As in most of life, there is good and bad." Read the full story by Christopher Borrelli on our site | Photo by Chris Sweda #television #lakeshoredrive #chicago #tv #fcc #skyline

For now, whether you’re young or young at heart, I do have one final ask of you as your president – the same thing I asked when you took a chance on me eight years ago. I am asking you to believe. Not in my ability to bring about change – but in yours.” Photo by Brian Cassella / Chicago Tribune @briancassella #obama #farewelladdress #chicago #president @barackobama

"I probably need to be (more concerned), but I'm not," 71-year-old Kathye Dawoudi said on a recent morning at a senior cafe and center in the South Side's Chatham neighborhood. "I'm not going to put that on my mind. ... Fear can be smelt." Dawoudi's 23-year-old grandson was shot and killed in 2015 about two blocks away. Each day, however, Dawoudi makes her way from her home to a bus stop in her neighborhood. Her sister copes differently. Eighteen months older than Dawoudi, she won't leave her Edgewater home. Experts point to Dawoudi's sister as an example of the self-isolation that often results from fear of crime. It can keep seniors from leaving home and participating in activities that benefit their health and emotional well-being. In interviews with the Tribune, however, many seniors also expressed resilience, declaring they won't be prisoners in their own homes. Read the story at chicagotribune.com  Photo by Erin Hooley / Chicago Tribune @malarchy #elderly #violence #chatham #chicago #shootings

Bison graze on Nachusa Grasslands in Franklin Grove, Ill., on Dec. 19, 2016. The bison project was started in 2014 to boost the grasslands restoration at Nachusa. The herd's population has grown to a robust 90, from the original herd of 20 brought in October 2014 from Broken Kettle Grasslands preserve, said Nachusa Project Director Bill Kleiman. Beyond the primary objective of helping restore the native landscape by what they do while they roam about 1,500 acres of the preserve, the bison have helped the cause by being effective marketers and ambassadors. The deep affection for and interest in the bison open people to the conservancy's larger messages of environmental awareness and action, Kleiman said. "I like how it connects people to the landscape," he added. "They're more engaged and more receptive to other messages outside the bison." In an investigation published in August, "The Price of Pork," the Tribune found hog waste spills accounted for nearly half of the 1 million fish killed in Illinois water pollution incidents from 2005 to 2014, killing at least 492,000 fish and impairing 67 miles of rivers and waterways. Now, residents of rural Bernadotte Township in western Illinois say a proposed 20,000-hog facility would imperil the Spoon River as well as their rural way of life. Neighbor Paul Stoops, 81, noted that a proposed hog confinement operation will be on a knob of land that slopes down to a fork of Tater Creek, which drains into the Spoon River in Bernadotte Township. "If you think about it, it is a terrible location," he said. Read this follow-up story by following the link in our profile. Photo by Stacey Wescott/Chicago Tribune @staceywescott27 #pollution #illinois #pork #hog #hogconfinement #investigativereporting

Chicago Blackhawks right wing Patrick Kane during the first period of the Blackhawks’ game against the Winnipeg Jets at the United Center Tuesday Dec 27, 2016. The Tribune’s Chris Kuc wrote “ On Dec. 27, 2015, Patrick Kane was on top of the NHL world following a scorching start to the season. The Blackhawks winger had at least one point in a franchise-record 26 consecutive games, piling up 21 goals and 29 assists through the season's first 36 games.
Exactly one year later, Kane took the ice to face Jets in the Hawks' 37th contest of this campaign with 10 goals and 24 assists. While his 34 points ranked ninth in the league going into Tuesday, the numbers paled in comparison to his remarkable accomplishment of a season ago.
"You always want to build off a season like that so it's a little disappointing with the start I've had so far this year," Kane said before the Hawks lost to the Jets 3-1 on Tuesday night at the United Center. "There is a lot of time left in the season and I'm trying not to get too caught up in numbers.” Nuccio DiNuzzo photo. #nhl #nhlblackhawks #nhljets

Anas plays with his daughter, Haneen, at their family's Chicago apartment on Dec. 18, 2016. Syrian refugees Anas and his wife Nareman arrived in Chicago with their two children nearly two weeks ago after fleeing the violence in Homs, Syria in 2012. When they left Homs, they presumed they would return within days. But days turned into months and within a year they realized they could not go back. They eventually underwent the painstaking screening process to enter the U.S. as refugees —  the highest level of security screening for any category of traveler to the U.S.  In November 2015, Illinois Gov. Bruce Rauner vowed to bar Syrian refugees — a largely symbolic threat since that authority resides with the U.S. State Department. Anas and Nareman were welcomed to their new home by Heather and Kevin Phillips of Exodus World Service, a Christian ministry that welcomes refugees. "Politics aside, once they are here it is our job to be a good neighbor and to love them and show them that love that they need at this point," said Heather Phillips. Photo @alyssapointerphoto /Chicago Tribune #refugees #syrianrefugees #chicago

Just as spring was beginning to warm Chicago, an extraordinarily courageous actress named Donica Lynn found herself in an off-Loop production of "Dreamgirls," playing Effie White, a role she had coveted for her entire adult life. Lynn, who is 42, was diagnosed with brain cancer in 2010, and 2016 was not an easy year for her, healthwise. There was CyberKnife surgery. There was chemotherapy. There were bills that insurance did not cover, so there were debts. And there were days, weeks, months of weariness, especially since Lynn also has three children ages 10 to 21. They take her energy. So does survival.  But somehow — surely not coincidentally — Lynn made this past year the most extraordinary professional year of her life. Read more about Lynn and our other picks for Chicagoans of the Year at chicagotribune.com. Photo by @josecito2 Jose M. Osorio/Chicago Tribune #cancer #chicagoans #chicago #chicagoansoftheyear #dreamgirls #actress #acting #2016

Tavon Tanner makes his way to school Nov. 28, 2016. Tavon has started attending school for a few hours a week after recovering from his gunshot wound that occurred in August while he was on his front porch.  After the surgery to excise the bullet, Tavon moved into his great-aunt's house with his mother. He lives there with his twin, his little brother, and, lately, one of his aunts and four cousins. At night, he shares an air mattress in the living room. And some days, while waiting to return to school full-time, he goes to classes for a couple of hours.  Tavon, 11, is one of 24 children 12 or younger shot in Chicago this year. Read his story by Mary Schmich and see more photos by E. Tavon Tanner tears up before surgery at Lurie Children's Hospital on Oct. 17, 2016, to remove a bullet that pierced his body in August while he was on his front porch. He had carried the bullet in his small body since that night it pierced his back near the base of his spinal cord and ripped upward, ravaging his pancreas, his stomach, his spleen, a kidney, his left lung. He sometimes texted his mother in the middle of the night to tell her that it hurt. Now, on a gray October day, a doctor is about to cut the bullet out, and he's hoping for the chance to inspect the little metal invader.  Tavon, 11, is one of 24 children 12 or younger shot in Chicago this year. Eight surgeries later, Tavon is still here. Read his story by Mary Schmich and see more photos by E. The space was designed to maximize natural light, augmented by architectural lighting fixtures. "Restaurants are too dark these days," Fyfe said. Pictured here is something called an "umami doughnut" which includes braised beef and raclette cheese, and “sounds like a comfort-food bomb,” says Tribune food critic Phil Vettel. The sun rises on a frigid morning over Lake Michigan on Dec. 15, 2016, viewed from Leone Beach Park on the Far North Side of Chicago. The fog seen over the lake is called arctic sea smoke or sea fog. This phenomenon happens when a mass of very cold air (about 3 degrees at the Harrison-Dever Crib, approximately 2.75 miles offshore at 9 a.m. Thursday) blows over warmer water (35 degrees at the same location). It's similar to what happens when a football player removes his helmet, and "smoke" appears above his head during a cold game. This process is aided by wind, which was gusting over the lake near 30 mph Thursday morning. "Winds are out of the west, from the land to the lake, driving cold air out over Lake Michigan," National Weather Service Chicago meteorologist Ricky Castro said. "If winds were calm, then the effect might not be as dramatic." Chris Walker/Chicago Tribune @walkerpix #leonebeachpark #lakemichigan #mishigami #sunrise #subzero #seafog #arcticseasmoke

"Welcome to the CTA's Holiday Bus!" Darlene Coleman, playing an elf on CTA's Holiday Bus says as the bus makes its way east along Chicago Ave. Her fingernails long, curled, green and bedazzled, her elf shoes, long, curled, green and bedazzled, she says "Happy Holidays!" with the explosive joy of a professional elf. Today, the CTA Holiday Train is a public transportation legend, six cars of blinking, over-the-top seasonal excess that runs at least once on all six lines (and delivers 300 meals each holiday season). It has a Santa (an actual person) and his eight tiny reindeer (dead-eyed statues) waving from an open-air flatbed car; it has Christmas classics playing in a loop; elves mingling with passengers in the exhaustively decorated cars, handing out candy canes, leading singalongs. Cinnamon smells are piped through ventilation systems. This year the Holiday Train even has a six-car Elves Workshop train trailing behind on Saturdays. Antonio Perez photo. #ctaholidaybus

Wendy Burtt, a driver with Antique Coach & Carriage, waits with her horse Cisco for a customer near Tower Court and Chicago Ave. in Chicago, on Wednesday, Dec 7, 2016. After surviving bouts of bankruptcy and a fire, the historic Noble Horse Theater in Old Town may finally meet its end when a developer seeks approval to erect a multi-story apartment building in its place. Two of Chicago’s three horse-drawn carriage companies rented stables at the facility and have been forced to find space elsewhere. They say it’s the latest blow to a beleaguered industry that already faces challenges from the city, including restrictions on carriage stand locations, rush hour operation and real estate prices. Nuccio DiNuzzo photo. #carriageride

A project by the Defense POW/MIA Accounting Agency begun in earnest last year with the goal of identifying and returning to loved ones the remains of 388 sailors and Marines — 18 from Illinois — killed when Japanese fighter planes riddled the USS Oklahoma with torpedoes at Pearl Harbor 75 years ago today, on Dec. 7, 1941. 
A total of 64 of those nearly 400 sailors and Marines have been identified by the Defense POW/MIA Accounting Agency. With each one, families reopen a powerful, personal connection to the event that drew the U.S. into World War II and created what's come to be known as the greatest generation. A testament to modern forensics, each identification also moves one tiny step toward completing that chapter of history and gives families the chance to provide a final honor to a relative who made the ultimate sacrifice.
At an assisted living center in Zion, Ill., Joseph Triolo, 96, waits to hear if the Defense Department effort will identify Donald R. McCloud, a sailor aboard the Oklahoma. He was one of about 2,400 Americans killed in the Pearl Harbor attacks.
McCloud was one of Triolo's closest friends, and he followed Triolo's lead to enlist in the Navy in 1937. The two ended up at Pearl Harbor in December 1941 on different ships. The night before the attacks, both young sailors had watched a baseball game between Navy teams. Then McCloud bought Triolo a beer.
Triolo was on the U.S.S. Tangier and remembers the chaos of the attack.
"There were so many men getting killed, you couldn't think about it," he said. "You just went on and did what the hell you needed to do."
These days, Triolo said, he often thinks about how his friend suffered before he died and he feels regret for leading McCloud into the Navy.
At least, Triolo said, if McCloud's remains are identified, Triolo will know his friend's fate.
"You get a satisfaction," he said. "You'd be lifted from wondering what happened." @briancassella photo #pearlharbor #wwiivets #veterans

Delores Anderson feeds dinner to one of her three granddaughters on Tuesday, Dec. 6, 2016 at her home in Chicago’s Englewood neighborhood. Chicago police were dispatched to a cold, filthy, abandoned apartment on Nov. 6 when they discovered three young sisters. The oldest, a 7-year-old was doing her best to look after the two babies, ages 2 and 1. There was no electricity, running water or food in the unit, but the babies knew to turn to their big sister when they were scared, police said. Police alerted officials at the Illinois Division of Child and Family Services who located the girls’ estranged grandmother and placed them with her. They arrested the girls’ father and he’s been charged with aggravated battery with use of a deadly weapon, aggravated battery of a child under 13 and domestic battery, according to court records. A GoFundMe page started by one of the police officers during off-duty hours has collected more than $100,000 for the girls. Brian Cassella/Chicago Tribune @briancassella #cpd

The Major League Baseball Commissioner’s Trophy, presented to the Chicago Cubs after defeating the Cleveland Indians in the World Series, made a stop at the @chicagotribune this morning. The initial World Series trophy was created by Major League Baseball in 1967. According to mlb.com, “MLB first commissioned Tiffany & Co. to create the World Series trophy in 2000. It takes Tiffany & Co. master artisans more than three months and more than 200 troy ounces of sterling silver to create the trophy that stands 24-inches high (not including the base) with a diameter of 11 inches. It weighs about 30 pounds. The trophy features 30 flags, one representing each Major League team, with latitude/longitude lines symbolizing the world and 24-karat vermeil stitches representing those on a baseball. Engraved on the base are the words: "Presented by the Commissioner of Baseball" along with the signature of Baseball Commissioner Rob Manfred.” @mtercha photo.

Marcus Wright takes part in a group discussion about violence in Division 2 of the Cook County Jail on Oct. 3, 2016. Chicago has seen the worst violence in decades this year, with more than 600 people killed and more than 3,000 shot. Blamed in part on gangs, access to guns, poverty and distrust of policing, the violence has seemed intractable. This past spring, officials launched a small pilot program they hope will get at one of the roots of that problem — changing attitudes toward violence. The program is called SAVE, for Sheriff's Anti-Violence Effort. Months into the effort, officials say it's too early to say whether it will live up to its name. The inmates, 18 to 24, live in an open dorm setting, away from the general jail tiers, and are in class or therapy six to eight hours a day. Most of them come from Chicago's most violent neighborhoods — Austin, Lawndale, Englewood — and many have been on the giving and receiving end of violence. They all are awaiting trial or sentencing for felonies. Photo by E. Jason Wambsgans | Link to full story in profile #violence #chicago #jail #therapy

Laura Mendoza, 27, is a volunteer with the Resurrection Project and a DACA (Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals) recipient. The Resurrection Project in Chicago's Pilsen neighborhood gives workshops for people worried about the the Trump presidency. About 450,000 unauthorized immigrants lived in Illinois in 2014, compared with about 500,000 in 2009. Unauthorized immigrants make up 3.5 percent of Illinois' population and 24 percent of all foreign-born residents. About 71 percent of the state's unauthorized immigrants are Mexican. "We don't know how to even get ready because we don't know how (Trump's) politics are going to look," said Mendoza, who came to the U.S. from Mexico at age 6 and does not have legal protection. "But we're not gonna go ahead and leave, and do what they want us to do — 'go home' — because this is home for us." Photo by  Nancy Stone / Chicago Tribune #immigrants #mexico #trump #pilsen #DACA

Barbara Chyette holds up a picture of her late brother, Loren Braun, a group home resident who choked to death during a supervised outing. State investigators cited his personal caregiver for egregious neglect. In a wrongful death suit, Chyette alleges that Anixter failed to address his choking risk, served her brother unsafe food and didn't protect him from neglect. Anixter executives declined to comment. "Loren was like a baby," Chyette said. "Like you would have to be with a 2-year-old or 3-year-old — that's the kind of supervision that clients like Loren need. And the system does not provide that kind of supervision." In a new Tribune Watchdog series, Suffering in Secret, reporters found that Illinois hides abuse and neglect of adults with disabilities. David Sudzus stands in the alley of his South Loop home on Nov. 2, 2016. His neighbor was killed there in August. As the numbers of shootings and killings skyrocket in Chicago, most of the violence has been driven by traditional gang conflicts on the South and West sides. But over the past two years, violence in developing and more affluent areas close to the Loop has also spiked, giving more Chicagoans a taste of the danger and fear that people in the city's poorer neighborhoods have experienced for decades. "The capper was the murder of a guy walking on a Sunday morning at 10 o'clock," said Sudzus, a lawyer who lives down the block with his wife and two children.  Now, Sudzus has found himself at the center of an emerging community group, the South Loop Safety Association. While the group, and others like it, have put pressure on local political leaders to respond to the increase in crime, Sudzus said the group has really focused on opening lines of communication among residents about what's going on around them. Photo @bzdak / Chicago Tribune #chicago #violence #shooting #loop #safety #community

Paris "Tree" Brown teases his mother Marketta Sconyers, while she wipes the tears that roll down her cheeks during a conversation in Paris' room on Nov. 7, 2016, in the East Garfield Park neighborhood. "Paris is so intelligent," said Marketta in a tone of admiration, while she held her curious 4-month-old grandson, Jacuez Pearson. During an early July morning in 2012, Paris was shot in the back while sitting in a van with his friends. That night he became paralyzed from the chest down. Paris says despite his circumstances, the accident was for the better. "I wasn't in my element. I was always ripping and running. But by me being shot and paralyzed, it caused me to sit down, literally and spiritually too," he said. "I'm grateful this happened." Paris wants to use the art of poetry to spotlight the injustices in his neighborhood while also helping others to appreciate and discover their true personalities. Head to www.chicagotribune.com to check out how Paris and the Chicago arts community are responding to violence in the series “Chicago Violence: The Arts Respond” Photo @alyssapointerphoto / Chicago Tribune #chicago #violence #rap #garfieldpark #arts #music #shootings

The #supermoon sets behind the Congress Hotel in Chicago before sunrise Monday morning, Nov. 14, 2016. This full moon is special. Not only is it a supermoon - which appears larger than a "regular" full moon -- it will be the closest such moon to Earth since January 1948. We won't see the full moon this close again until Nov. 25, 2034, according to NASA. The distance between Earth and the moon can range from 221,208 miles at its closest possible point to 252,898 miles at its farthest. That's a difference of nearly 32,000 miles. This month, it gets close at 221,524 miles between Earth and the moon -- just 316 miles from its nearest possible location.@josecito2 photo #supermoon2016

A bystander looks on as members of the Chicago Fire Department work the scene of a 5-alarm fire at a vacant building in the Little Village neighborhood on Nov. 5, 2016. Norman Malone plays during a final sound check at the Roberts Theater two hours before his concert. It  was a performance that the Chicago pianist never thought would happen. Sure, he had been studying Maurice Ravel's monumental Piano Concerto for the Left Hand for nearly 60 years.  But the days leading up to the big performance had been difficult. "I started having a little panic attack. So I had to put that aside," he said. Wherever Malone went, he was followed by a crew from Chicago's Kartemquin Films, which is developing a documentary about Malone in association with the Tribune.  At age 5, he was a prodigious pianist growing up in a Chicago housing project. Tragically, when Malone was 10 his father attacked him and his two younger brothers as they slept, wielding a hammer to their heads, then took his own life. The boys survived, but each was partially paralyzed on the right side. Which meant Malone no longer would be able to play the piano. Or so everyone told him. But Malone refused to accept that verdict, spending years trying to find someone who would teach him to play the instrument with one hand — someone, anyone who knew there was a vast repertoire of piano music written for left hand alone. Bob Caughey, who has been diagnosed with primary progressive #aphasia which makes speaking very difficult, helps his wife Linda cross a makeshift bridge on Oct. 20, 2016 at their home in Pontiac, Ill. Bob still goes to his law office most mornings, after he's fed his sheep and eaten his Raisin Bran, but the job is no longer the same. He can still do the work of drafting an estate plan or real estate contract. He could, if necessary, read the millions of words in the tax code. What he can no longer do is hold a long, easy conversation. He has given up talking on the phone. Big words, the kind beloved by lawyers, are the hardest to say. Collateral. Descendant. Precedent. Beneficiary. Irrevocable. There is no medicine to cure or slow PPA, and until recently there seemed to be no way to change its momentum. But Caughey is participating in a novel Northwestern University program designed to test whether speech therapy, delivered person-to-person over the internet, can relieve some of the speech loss brought on by dementia. A tangle of charred octopus tentacles over shelling beans gets a bit of a spark from #shishito peppers at Smyth, a newly opened #restaurant in Chicago. Tribune’s food critic Phil Vettel wrote: You couldn't ask for a better homecoming than the one that John B. Shields and his wife, Karen Urie Shields, have created on Ada Street. John was sous-chef for Charlie Trotter for two years, then was sous-chef for Grant Achatz for the first two years of Alinea. Karen was pastry sous-chef under Gale Gand at Tru for two years before jumping to Trotter's for five, the last two as head pastry chef. When the Shieldses left Chicago in 2008, their collective resume was already impressive, even if name recognition was scant. Handed the opportunity to open Charlie Trotter's new restaurant in Las Vegas, the couple went in the opposite direction, heading to rural Chilhowie, Va., to open their own restaurant...Now the Shieldses — at this point very much known in the restaurant community, thank you very much — are back in Chicago with a triumphant restaurant that justifies every nice thing that's ever been said about them. At Smyth (pronounced "smith," in case you were wondering), the Shieldses have achieved that very tricky balance between culinary excellence and unaffected informality. Darnell Arrington Sr. carries daughter Yari, 2, as contractors for the EPA prepare to leave after inspecting his neighbor’s unit for lead in the West Calumet Housing Complex in East Chicago, Indiana on Sept. 8, 2016. Arrington is planning to move back to Chicago after residing in the complex for a year. Residents of the housing complex must move out due to dangerously high lead level readings. Arrington and his daughter are among the approximately 1,000 residents — the majority of them children — of the West Calumet Housing Complex who are now scrambling to find places to live. But they face few good options. The rental market is already tight, and when an apartment is available it is often situated in a more dangerous neighborhood. Making matters more difficult, many potential landlords do not accept tenants who receive the federal rent subsidies, commonly known as S  ection 8  vouchers, which most West Calumet residents are counting on to help them move. Catrina Pickens, the mother of Drequan Archie, cries in his old room with a picture of him behind her on May 24, 2016, in #Chicago. Her son Drequan was killed two years ago by a #gun used in other #shootings.  Nearly two years later, a sense of the family's loss is still apparent in its Southeast Side apartment. In what was Archie's bedroom, a shrine of candles and keepsakes remains. Photos adorn the walls, including a selfie of his thick dreadlocks framing a handsome face with soulful eyes. Pickens typically avoids his bedroom, but on a recent afternoon she shared jokes and tears with her sister, Regina, as they gazed at the mementos. There was anger, too. The sister, who lives in the same apartment building, questioned why police hadn't solved the killing. Pickens, a home-health-care worker, said she has struggled providing help to dying patients because it brings back memories of her son's killing. She also said she no longer talks to people who don't seem to understand why she is still grieving. Randolph Strahan poses for a #portrait outside his home after cutting the grass on Aug. 23, 2016. "I've seen five young men lose their lives on this block," Strahan said from his front yard, just steps from a neighbor's porch where a father of two was killed in a #shooting linked to a gang #gun. If you stretch your head up and gaze east from the porch's steps, you can see a bright blue stretch of #LakeMichigan, just a few blocks away at Rainbow Beach. On the North Side, this would be prime real estate, but on this block, longtime residents say violence ebbs and flows. Strahan, 68, a retired electrician, said the violence was incessant a few years back when a gang controlled a corner store on the east end of the block. Two of those killings took place right across from his home, while three others died down the block, he said. "What's it like to live here?" the retiree asked rhetorically when a reporter inquired about the block. His soft voice was nearly drowned out by the whistle of a Metra train passing nearby. "Where are you from?" he asked. "You don't know what it's like to be numb." Streetwise vendor Samuel Sanders, dressed in a bear costume, playfully jokes with a crowd waiting in line for Cubs' tickets Friday, Oct. 7, 2016 at Wrigley Field in Chicago. Can't stand to miss the Cubs during their final homestand this week? You may have to — literally.

Coal miner Michael Tucker plays basketball with his son in the driveway of their home on Aug. 31, 2016, in Equality, Ill.  Tucker, 33, learned last month that he'll lose his job in November when his employer, the Pattiki Mine in Carmi, Ill., shuts down permanently. He said when mines close, the aftershocks touch many more who indirectly depend on them. "The number of jobs that will be lost or negatively affected will be hundreds, thousands," Tucker said. "That's what people don't realize. It's just enormous what it'll do to southern Illinois." For more than a century coal has fueled the economy of this often-depressed region. Miners risk their bodies in labyrinthine tunnels and on mineral-rich hillsides, and in exchange, they can earn $80,000 or more — wages far beyond anything else available in the area. But this long-standing covenant could be reaching its end. Illinois mining companies have shed more than 1,200 jobs over the last year as strict new environmental regulations and cheap natural gas have encouraged utilities to drop their reliance on coal. Only about 2,800 jobs remain, the lowest tally in decades. Howard Learner  of Chicago's Environmental Law and Policy Center said regulations aren't the major reason for coal's decline. More relevant, he said, are bad business decisions: Some mining companies went on a buying spree believing that economic growth in China would continue at a breakneck pace, only to go bankrupt when that bet went sour. "Those are real economic factors that are not likely to be affected by who is president," he said. Photo @anthonysouffle #coal #coalmining #jobs #illinois

Artist David Allen paints at his home in #Chicago on Sept. 7, 2016. A sought-after #tattoo artist, Allen works in a quiet, second-floor loft with no sign on the door, for select clients who wait six months or more to secure an appointment. Some of his clients are well-known — @ladygaga got a David Allen tattoo earlier this year. But about five times each month, Allen spends a day or two constructing elaborate, delicately shaded tattoos on the scarred, imperfect breasts of women who have undergone mastectomies to rid their bodies of life-threatening cancer. More than that: He lets them cry, and cries with them. And though, in the end, a tattoo is just an image on skin, Allen says the story underneath is the reason he keeps doing it. "I don't think it's about the final product," he says, "it's about the process. If the product is the focus, you're skipping the person.” He stops, feeling for something deeper. "You know what?" he says. "I don't really care about tattoos. It's just that they're connected to people. They matter. They are why you're here.” Link to video in profile | Photo by @staceywescott27 #breastcancer #art #artist #breastcancerawareness #tattoos @davidallen

Ouch! Kaiden Whittman, 3, receives a flu shot from medical assistant Gigi Hernandez at Advocate Children's Hospital, Thursday, Sept. 29, 2016. For the past few years, most adults and children had a choice of how to get vaccinated against the flu: the more common shot in the arm or the FluMist spray in the nostrils.
But the less painful method no longer is an option. National health authorities determined FluMist essentially was useless last year in protecting against the dangerous influenza virus. The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention ruled FluMist should not be used at all for the upcoming season. Antonio Perez photo. #flushot

#Penguins are back on the North Side. Five years after they were rousted from their home at Lincoln Park Zoo to make way for new exhibits, the popular flightless #birds have returned to the #zoo in a new outdoor habitat. And it's a new breed. Literally. The birds the zoo is keeping now are African penguins, a critically #endangered species less and less commonly found off the coast of South Africa and Namibia. The birds that exited in 2011 were Antarctic rockhopper penguins, a cold­weather species kept in a frigid — and fading — indoor space. The African birds do better in temperate zones, such as Chicago. Jamary McKinney, 19, said he discovered his first love when he started playing baseball at age 5. McKinney has taken the route of many talented baseball players, starting on his local #LittleLeague team with Jackie Robinson West,  progressing to elite travel teams as a teen and starting for his high school team at Simeon. But McKinney, who now plays for #Chicago State, says he sometimes feels like an anomaly in the sport he adores. "Being from the South Side of Chicago, baseball is just not a big sport," said McKinney, who is from Roseland. "It's like being foreign on the South Side of Chicago. I get, 'What sport do you play? You don't look like a baseball player.'" It's not an uncommon feeling among black baseball players. But many are eager to see an increase in African­-American players again. McKinney would like to help start a new trend one day in MLB. "It's my dream to play in the big leagues," he said. "I really feel like (the number of African­-American youth playing is) starting to change slowly but very surely." Lupita Nyong’o was new to most moviegoers in 2013 when she played Patsey, the 19th-century slave who befriends Solomon Northup in “12 Years a Slave.” She was cast two weeks before graduating from the Yale School of Drama. “I must admit,” she told Tribune film critic Michael Phillips, grinning, “I was an insomniac during the entire shoot! It was a combination of things, the emotional place I had to go, but also the excitement and the joy of making the project as well.”
The film’s richly deserved success changed her life.
Now the Oscar-winning Nyong’o is back on screen in a Disney release, director Mira Nair’s “Queen of Katwe” which tells the rousing true story of Phiona Mutesi, the young Ugandan chess champion who grew up in the slums surrounding the Ugandan capital, Kampala. 
Nyong’o’s interview with Michael Phillips is online now and in print tomorrow. Antonio Perez photo. @lupitanyongo #queenofkatwemovie

@Mig.Cervantes and the Chicago company of “Hamilton” @hamiltonmusical rehearse September 8 at the New 42nd Street Studios in New York.
“Hamilton” still has to prove that it can be scaled without any loss of quality or any risk of the diminution of its brand. Chicago is the first test of that. “People are spending a lot of money,” says Cervantes, the actor with the most pressure of all, playing the title role, as originated by @lin.manuel.miranda. “We all are working hard to make sure the people of Chicago get the show they deserve. And I had better not mess up any of the words.”
As it happens, the self-effacing Cervantes was about to quit the business when “Hamilton” came calling. He’d gotten married, moved to New Jersey and set up a business teaching kids Little League baseball. He’d decided the theater life was too hard, despite some Broadway success. Then this happened. His is just another amazing “Hamilton” story.
“When you drop the ‘H’ bomb,” Cervantes says of his new, post-“Hamilton” life, “the pitch of people’s voice changes. I guess it is a tool you can use if you want to. But really, the fanfare already has happened. The hoopla is done. For me this a show. Laughing. Crying. Loving. A show that breaks my heart.” @jessedittmar photo for the Chicago Tribune.
Tribune theater critic Chris Jones (Twitter @ChrisJonesTrib) takes you inside the rehearsal online today, and interviews @lin.manuel.miranda at the @chi_humanities Festival tomorrow.

Thirty children younger than 13 have been shot in Chicago this year, but all summer —  as the count has risen —  Derrick Brown has run his boxing program out of his garage in North Lawndale, trying to keep kids out of harm's way. The boxing program, called Boxing Out Negativity, is his restitution for the kids who followed in his misguided footsteps, who wound up dead or, like his brother, in prison. "Home," to these kids, he said, "is just a place you lay down. Their so­-called real family is on the corner." Brown joined the Vice Lords when he was 12, in the days when Chicago's gangs were highly structured. His gang ruled a swath of the West Side known as the Holy City. "I was a child who had dreams and ambitions to become great," he said. He is 40 now. During the academic year, Brown runs his program out of William Penn Elementary School, but he keeps it going at home in the summer, the months when Chicago violence is especially volatile and kids, playing outside, are especially vulnerable. It feels to him, as it does to many others, that since Chicago's old-­style gang hierarchies have collapsed, violence continues to get more capricious. For these kids, he wants more. "I want #intelligence. I want a future. I want a #calmness." Yes, he tells them, life is unfair. But take the unfairness and make the best out of it. Most of these kids have already witnessed more violence than the average American ever will. From a column by Mary Schmich | Photo by E. Sir the Baptist on Thursday, Sept. 8, 2016 in the van where he lives and records music. Greg Kot writes “Sir the Baptist (born Sir William James Stokes) climbed inside a casket one Sunday afternoon in Grant Park a few months ago at the Lollapalooza festival, and imagined himself as a corpse.
"Would you care if it was me?" he asked, and the crowd of several thousand onlookers stirred. They may have come to the festival to be entertained, but now they were getting a harsh dose of what it feels like to be a young African-American in a city where blood and bullets are as commonplace as bicycles and schoolbooks.
Gospel music is very much alive in Chicago, and thanks to performers like Sir the Baptist, it's resonating with a new generation of artists and listeners in a way that echoes the songs of strife, striving and salvation during the civil rights era.” @TribuneKevin interviewed Stokes backstage at #Lollapalooza about why he brought a casket. http://trib.in/2cAn4Dv @briancassella photo @sirthebaptist #gospel #gospelmusic

Fidencio Sanchez, 89, pushes his cart down 26th Street on Sept. 12, 2016, in the Little Village neighborhood of #Chicago. Sanchez has been a #pushcart vendor for Paleteria Poncho for more than 20 years. There’s no way of knowing how long it would’ve taken Sanchez to sell 90,000 #paletas, or Mexican ice pops, for $1.50 each from the paleteria he pushes. But online donors saved the 89­-year­-old man the trouble of finding out. Through $5 to $2,000 donations, 6,300­ plus people collectively raised more than $135,000 ­ the equivalent of 90,000 paleta sales ­for Sanchez in a #GoFundMe campaign started by a stranger wanting to offer the older man a little relief from pushing his cart. Crediting friend Joe Loera with coming up with the idea to start an online #fundraiser, Joel Cervantes said in this case it took a village – Little Village – to make all the difference to Sanchez and his wife, Eladia. Eladia Sanchez also used to sell paletas but now sells Mexican candies because pushing the heavy cart became too physically demanding and hurt her arm, according to the Sanchez' granddaughter, Dulce Perez. "I am very thankful for the men that thought of doing this ... Well, seems to me like it won't be necessary anymore and I will be able to rest more at home," Perez said for Sanchez. "It means a lot, and the changes will be that there will be no need for me to work, and we will have help in all aspects; Like getting better clothes and things that will improve our life at home." Photo by @alyssapointerphoto / Chicago Tribune

Stein, who was born in Chicago and raised in Highland Park, contrasted her legal plight with Democratic presidential nominee  Hillary Clinton  and Republican contender Donald Trump . Adonis Clayborn, who was part of the Manufacturing Careers Internship Program, is photographed May 3, 2016, at Skolnik Industries in #Chicago. The morning of his final #internship evaluation, Adonis Clayborn woke up in his girlfriend's car. Unable to afford a motel room, he had reclined the driver's seat, covered himself in sweaters he kept in the trunk and slept the night in the silver Nissan Sentra with the Hello Kitty license plate frame. Still, the soft­spoken 22­-year-­old showed up to work on time, wearing a pink tie given to him by a colleague. Clayborn was nearing the end of his eight­-week internship at Skolnik Industries, a manufacturer near Midway Airport that makes steel drums, and would soon learn if he would be offered a job. Programs that link "disconnected" youth to employers are putting young men like Clayborn on career paths they might not have considered, at companies that might otherwise not have considered them. The road isn't always smooth. But despite some heartache, employers like Skolnik say it's one worth taking. "Adonis has really opened a lot of eyes around here," said Dean Ricker, vice president of sales at Skolnik. Photo by Terrence Antonio James / Chicago Tribune. Link to full story in bio.

Jaqueline Gutierrez, 9, and her father Edgar Gutierrez, 35, watch police work the scene of a fatal #shooting near the intersection of South Komensky Avenue and West Marquette Road on Aug. 31, 2016. After ending August with the most #homicides for any month in more than 20 years, #Chicago is on the verge of surpassing last year's toll with four months to go in 2016. As many as a few hundred officers each day work overtime on the department's "violence reduction initiative," assigned to designated #crime "hot spots," primarily on the South and West sides. Additional officers are assigned to #NavyPier, McCormick Place, public housing, #CTA train stations and parks. In an interview Wednesday, Chicago Police Department Superintendent Eddie Johnson Johnson told the Tribune he was confident staffing levels for the #LaborDay weekend would be adequate. If the department falls short on the number of officers needed to work overtime this weekend, Johnson said, he'd cancel days off for some officers, a common move by officials over holiday weekends during the summer. On a day when Elijah Sims should have been celebrating his 17th birthday, his family and friends were instead attending a vigil Wednesday night for the late Oak Park teen. Sims, an Oak Park-River Forest High School student, was shot and killed in Chicago's Austin neighborhood on Monday.  Edith Harris is the aunt of Sims' mother Sharita Galloway. 
Just two days earlier, Sims and a 15-year-old boy were shot in the 5500 block of West Quincy Street in Chicago's Austin neighborhood. Sims was shot in the head. The 15-year-old was shot in the back.
Both boys were taken to Stroger Hospital, where the younger boy's condition was stabilized, but Sims died overnight.
The vigil drew a crowd of hundreds to Scoville Park in downtown Oak Park. Sims' mother, Sharita Galloway, was grateful for the turnout.
"It's nice to feel support," Galloway said. "Oak Park, thank you so much. I want to thank everyone for coming out." Chris Sweda photo.

Contract #fisherman Jim Dickau, 49, right, and Damian Seidemann, 18, catch Asian #carp for the Illinois DNR at Hanson Material Service quarry on the #Illinois River on Aug. 23, 2016. In less than half a century, Asian carp went from being unknown in U.S. waters to making up 90 percent of the biomass in some stretches of the Illinois and #Mississippi rivers. Bighead and silver carp were first introduced to the United States in the 1970s, when they were imported to control algae growth in aquaculture and sewage treatment ponds. They escaped into the Mississippi River during floods a few years later. Like many invasive species, they've been able to out­compete local populations and have spread quickly. There is no silver bullet for eradicating the invasive species. But a decadelong rush to prevent Asian carp from entering the Great Lakes may be paying off. With a slew of methods, from electric barriers to noise cannons and "fences" made of carbon dioxide, researchers hope to keep Asian carp at bay. Next summer, some of those new tools will be put through final tests. Photo by @bzdak /Chicago Tribune #carp #fish #invasivespecies #environment

@Oprah Winfrey may have packed up and left town, but just because her Harpo Studios site on the Near West Side is now a pile of rubble, it doesn't mean the freebies immediately dried up.
Sources say late-night scavengers at the Randolph Street site have been acting as if the queen of daytime TV had been telling them, "You get a brick, you get a brick, everybody gets a brick!"
So many trespassers were helping themselves to mementos from the ruins that the demolition crew from Heneghan Wrecking has been forced to employ overnight security guards.
But that hasn't stopped demand from treasure hunters, according to neighbor Moshe Tamssot, who admits he has liberated several bricks for himself, picks up bricks and gives them away to people. "There are two security guards, and I saw them offering to toss one brick over the fence for $10 or two for $25," he said. "Their math may be a little bit off, but an Oprah brick is a hot commodity right now — it's a piece of West Loop history." Nancy Stone photo. #HarpoStudios #Oprah #yougetacar

Sharon Moore, 48, and her grandson Kyren Gonzalez, 7, stand near a #memorial on Aug. 24, 2016, while looking up at a building where three children and a man were killed a day earlier in a fire in the 8100 block of South Essex Avenue in Chicago. The man apparently had an argument with someone in the building and started #fires in different locations, according to police and fire officials. Inspectors with the #Chicago Department of Buildings are inspecting the apartment complex to determine whether it is safe for residents to stay put, officials said in a statement. A jogger and his dog run along the lakefront at Milton Lee Olive Park in Chicago on an overcast and muggy Wednesday morning, Aug. 24, 2016. The park just north of downtown commemorates 18-year-old Milton L. Olive III, who, on Oct. 22, 1965, threw himself on a hand grenade in Vietnam to save four soldiers he hardly knew. Six months later, President Lyndon Johnson posthumously awarded Olive the Medal of Honor. In a Rose Garden ceremony, flanked by Mayor Richard J. Daley, the Olive family and two of the saved men--one black, one white--Johnson said that Olive's "instinct of loyalty" caused him to put others first and himself last. "In dying," the president said, "Pvt. Milton Olive taught those of us who remain how we ought to live."@josecito2 photo #Chicago #lakefront #running

Shooting victim Jamia Barnes, 8, stands outside a #Chicago home on Aug. 22, 2016, following a shooting Sunday night. Jamia was playing on a front lawn near a vigil for a teenage boy killed hours earlier when she saw a man in a car arguing with a woman outside. "Somebody had the gun in their lap ... and he got it out and started shooting," recounted the soft­spoken third­-grader, fiddling with the bandage on her right wrist and pulling at her hair. She saw a flash and smoke in that instant. "That's when I felt my arm stinging," she said Monday. "And I was hollering for my mommy. And that's it. And I went to the hospital." Jamia's family has been marked by violence almost her entire life growing up in the Austin neighborhood on Chicago's West Side. Seven years ago, her aunt, then 28, was shot dead in an apparent drive­-by shooting. Then last summer, her 11­ and 19­-year­-old brothers were shot not far away while working on a dirt bike on a sunny afternoon. So far this year, at least 2,702 people have been shot in Chicago, according to data kept by the Tribune. As of 5 a.m. Monday, homicides totaled 441, a 49 percent increase from 296 a year earlier, according to official Police Department figures. Photo by Antonio Perez / Chicago Tribune

USA's Kent Farrington, of Chicago, competes aboard Voyeur in individual jumping Friday, Aug. 19, 2016 at the Olympic Equestrian Centre in Rio de Janeiro. Farrington finished fifth in a dramatic sudden-death jump-off Friday in the show jumping competition.
Nick Skelton of Great Britain won the gold, Peter Fredricson of Sweden earned silver and Canada's Eric Lamaze won the bronze.
Farrington, who grew up in Lincoln Park, won silver earlier this week in the team event despite the last-minute scratch of a veteran American rider.
Ranked No. 4 in the world, the 35-year-old equestrian was in a six-way tie for first heading into the jump-off.
Farrington was riding Voyeur, a 14-year-old gelding.
"I'm thrilled with my horse," Farrington said earlier. "I thought he tried very hard. You can see a lot of the horses are getting tired here now. It's very hot outside and there has been a lot of heavy jumping all week."
@BrianCassella photo #Rio2016 #equestrian

Jane Goodall pauses after a press conference to kick off 'Chimpanzees in Context', featuring nearly 300 primatologists from around the world participating in discussions aimed at improving chimpanzee welfare. Speaking to reporters at the beginning of the 2016 edition of “Understanding Chimpanzees” at Lincoln Park Zoo, the famous primatologist said the things she learned in Chicago, including about the trade in chimpanzees for their meat and the treatment of some chimps in laboratories, made her realize she needed to shift her focus from close­up study of chimps in the wild to a bigger­ picture, more holistic approach to the conservation of humans' closest living relative. She said she hopes people leave the conference with “a sense of urgency” about protecting and studying chimps in their native habitats, “before it's too late.” Photo by E. Jason Wambsgans/Chicago Tribune #chimpanzees #janegoodall @janegoodallinst

The new pet restroom at Chicago Midway International Airport is seen on Thursday, Aug. 18, 2016. A family restroom was repurposed into an indoor dog bathroom, with artificial grass, a mini fire hydrant, poop bags and an automatic flushing system to wash away liquid waste. The pet relief room means travelers passing through Midway don’t have to take animals outside and then wait in security lines multiple times. The pet bathroom opened this month in compliance with a federal mandate to have such designated areas on the secured side of terminals in all U.S. airports, according to the aviation department. The cost was $25,000, paid for through the department’s operating and management budget, which is funded by landing fees, terminal rent and other fees paid by airlines, as well as parking and concession revenues, the city said. Chris Sweda/Chicago Tribune #midwayairport #petbathroom #petrestroom #petreliefroom #gooddog

A plastic lion emerges from a Mold-a-Rama machine at Brookfield Zoo August 11, 2016. Mold-A-Rama, a souvenir born at a world’s fair more than half a century ago has held on against competition from cheap T-shirts, refrigerator magnets and, now, 3-D printers.
Scraped out of their machines warm, shapely and smelling of recently melted plastic, Mold-A-Ramas are an upscale answer to the penny smasher.
A Mold-A-Rama Hall of Fame, featuring such collectible figures as the difficult-to-make Fairy Castle from the Museum of Science and Industry and new ones like the Willis Tower, is on display through August in the zoo’s Memory Lane gift shop.
There are 13 of the machines operating at Brookfield, including the one producing the all-time best seller, a blue leaping dolphin. Antonio Perez photo. @brookfieldzoo #nostalgia

Zariah McCray Muhammad, 6, and her cousins play at her grandmother’s house in Chicago Monday, August 15, 2016. Zariah was shot in the head last week, and her uncle, who she referred to as "her best friend,” was struck in the chest by the gunfire and died.
The bullet that hit Zariah fractured her skull, and she underwent nearly two hours of surgery at Comer Children's Hospital on Friday, her family said.
A small bandage was visible on the side of her head as she walked down the sidewalk arriving home in Chatham Sunday afternoon.
"Welcome home, Zariah," neighborhood children shouted Sunday as Zariah held onto her mother with one hand and about a dozen balloons in the other. 
So far this year, at least 27 children age 13 and younger have been shot in the city, according to data collected by the Tribune. Last year at this time, 23 children in that age range had been shot.  A total of 36 were shot over the entire year, according to Tribune data. Nancy Stone photo.

Young Julius Bradsfield was testing the waters of competitive swimming in Chicago eight years ago when he met his idol — the idol of so many swimmers — Olympian Michael Phelps. Fast­forward eight years. Bradsfield, now 20, stayed with swimming and works as a lifeguard at North Avenue Beach, competes on the water polo team at Monmouth College and has been glued to the TV watching Phelps as a dominating force in Rio de Janeiro. "I thought he was superhuman then, and that was eight golds then. Now it just seems impossible, but he's doing it," said Bradsfield, who lives in Chicago's Bridgeport neighborhood. Bradsfield went on to swim at Curie Metropolitan High School on the Southwest Side, where his water polo team was crowned city champs in Chicago Public Schools before he went on to compete at the collegiate level. Great Britain diver Tom Daley trains in a pool that had begun to turn green on August 12, 2016 at the Maria Lenk Aquatics Center in #riodejaneiro Soon after, the pool closed for diving practice to allow more time to clean the green­-tinged water. The diving well was shut down when athletes arrived for morning warm ups, though it did finally open at 1 pm local time — just 2 1­/2 hours before the start of the women's 3­-meter individual event. Daley, who won bronze in the synchro platform event, commented on the state of the pool in a Twitter post. Tacarra Morgan, center, plays in a pool donated to her by Chicago Police officers on August 11, 2016.  A Chicago police sergeant placed a pink inflatable life vest around Tacarra and officers, who had placed their bullet­proof vests on a nearby fence, held up an inflatable pool they had brought to the West Englewood house as two garden hoses slowly filled it with cold water. It was a strikingly different scene three weeks ago, when those same officers responded to home where Tacarra lives after gunfire erupted on the block. A three­car convoy had been cruising down Pauline Street near 59th Street when two dozen shots rang out. Tacarra was struck on the left side of her abdomen as she tried to run inside her grandparents’ home. “Granddad, I been shot,” she was heard saying. “Look, I been shot.” Standing in a vacant lot next to Tacarra’s home, Chicago police Sgt. Elise Padilla paused as she explained how the officers who responded were in disbelief. “A 6­-year-­old should not know what it means to be shot,” Padilla said. Padilla purchased the pool and shipped it to Tacarra’s home about two weeks ago and hopes the pool is one way Tacarra can feel safe outside her home. Story @elviamalagon | Photo by Terrence Antonio James / Chicago Tribune #chicagopolice #pool #summer #chicago #shootings

A member of the Chicago Police Department looks inside a car at the scene of a shooting on the 4200 block of West Grenshaw Street early Thursday, Aug. 11, 2016, in Chicago. The Tribune’s Alexandra Chachkevitch writes on chicagotribune.com: “Beat 1132, 1:30 a.m. Thursday, Aug. 11. The father paced up and down as a police officer stood in front of his Lawndale home and wrote down the address, noting exactly where his adult son had been shot.
After a few minutes, the father lifted the crime tape and walked down the 4200 block of West Grenshaw Street. He put his hands on his hips. His eyes darted from one side of the street to the other. His breathing was heavy.
“I’m just dumbfounded,” he said. “We were just sitting out there. … All of the sudden a car came through shooting. Normally this don’t happen on this block.
“Once they started shooting, all I did is duck down," said the man, asking not to be identified.
Police said at least 12 shots were fired around 12:20 a.m. Thursday, and five of them hit the man's son, who was taken in critical condition to Mount Sinai Hospital. Friday is the son's 35th birthday." @mandophotos photo.

A dead rose­-breasted grosbeak is shown with volunteer Erin Englerth’s similar arm tattoo at the Field Museum in Chicago on July 27, 2016. On Wednesdays, 15 or so volunteers prepare birds for the museum’s massive bird collection. More than a half­-million bird specimens - representing 90 percent of the bird species in the world are stored above the Bird Hall, the part of the museum that visitors see. The specimens — whole body skeletons, stuffed birds (known as study skins) and "pickles" (birds in jars of alcohol) — are crucial to scientific research that happens not only in Chicago but also around the world. The majority of the birds are brought in by Chicago Bird Collision Monitors, a group of 100 volunteers who work in teams before sunrise, making daily treks through the downtown during migration season to pick up injured and dead birds that have hit the windows. Nancy Stone/ Chicago Tribune #fieldmuseum #rosebreastedgrosbeak #birdtattoo #putabirdonit

Laura Pascual, right, a corn detasseling veteran, drove to Rantoul, Ill. from Texas this year with two generations in tow. “It’s cooler up here than over there,” the 45­-year­-old native of Mission, Texas, said. Pascual has spent every summer for some 20 years. She is among the hundreds of migrant workers who travel to the area for corn detasseling season, a short burst of intense work critical in the production of the nation's largest cash crop. This year, Pascual drove the 1,400 miles with her three daughters, a nephew and eight grandchildren. The family stayed in a hulking old hospital converted into the state's largest migrant labor camp, which is leased by Monsanto, sleeping on mattresses on gray concrete floors. Pascual described it as a vacation of sorts, a break from the suffocating Texas heat, though there seemed little restful about it. She wakes at 2 a.m. daily to hand­make 100 flour tortillas for her family and anyone else who wishes to buy them before they head out before dawn to the corn fields for a workday that sometimes stretches to 15 hours. Zbigniew Bzadak/Chicago Tribune @bzdak #corndetasseling #rantoul

Ruperto Casares, 13, left, and other migrant workers return to Nightingale Camp, located in the old hospital building on the former Chanute Air Force Base, in Rantoul, Ill., on July 20, 2016, after a 12­-hour shift of detasseling #cornfields for #Monsanto. Detasseling is a step in the production of hybrid corn seed in which workers walk among the stalks and pull off the pollen­ containing tassels at the top of each stalk to prevent the corn from self­-pollinating. Farm labor, among the most backbreaking and lowest­ paid jobs, is, for many, an honorable career passed from generation to generation. But it also is subject to conditions not tolerated in most other industries. Children can work in the fields as young as 12. The composition of the farm labor force, which toils largely out of public view, gives workers little leverage to challenge poor treatment, worker advocates say. Of the estimated 2.5 million farmworkers in the U.S., between 50 and 70 percent are #undocumented, and fear of deportation keeps workers from complaining, said Bruce Goldstein, president of Farmworker Justice, a Washington, D.C.­-based advocacy group. Follow the story at chicagotribune.com Photo by @bzdak / Chicago Tribune

Michael King, 15, visits the memorial for his brother Paul O'Neal in the South Shore neighborhood on August 4, 2016. Here’s another photo from the Tribune’s investigation titled: The price of pork: Cheap meat comes at high cost in Illinois. These sows are marked with pink dye in their gestation stalls in Montgomery County, Ill. Various colors are used to communicate to workers where to move the animals. For almost their entire lives, iron bars will hold mother pigs on slotted concrete floors of the 6,000­-animal breeding operation as they produce litter after litter. They can step a few inches forward or backward but not turn around. Keeping pregnant and nursing sows in tight stalls called gestation or farrowing crates is a practice that pork producers say keeps the mother pigs and their litters safe and well cared for. Opponents say it amounts to animal torture and are pushing for change. Stacey Wescott/Chicago Tribune @staceywescott27 #tribuneinvestigation #illinoispork #cafo #piglets #pork #hogs #pigs #hogconfinement 🐽

Over 2,000 weaned piglets are loaded onto a truck at a Montgomery County breeding operation for shipping to a large pig grower. Illinois is the nation's fourth­-largest seller of pigs. Hundreds of large hog facilities have been constructed across the state in recent years, using a factory-like system to grow thousands of pigs and put inexpensive pork on your plate. But a Tribune investigation finds all that cheap meat is coming at great cost to rural communities. Sickening odors imprison people in their homes. Vast lagoons of manure leak into streams and ponds, killing fish. And weak Illinois laws put few restrictions on pork producers who want to build and expand. See the chicagotribune.com for the four­-part investigation. Stacey Wescott/Chicago Tribune @staceywescott27 #tribuneinvestigation #illinoispork #cafo #piglets #pork #hogs #pigs #hogconfinement 🐽

It was announced this afternoon that Jackson Park, on Chicago's South Side, will be the home of the Obama Presidential Center. "For the first time, a presidential center will be in the heart of an urban community," Martin Nesbitt, chairman of the Obama Foundation, said in a statement. Jackson Park also was the site of the World’s Columbian Exposition in 1893, where "The Republic," a sculpture by Daniel chester French, towered over the fairgrounds. This “Republic” is a 1918 replica of the original, 65-foot high plaster original, which was destroyed after the fair closed. Terrence Young, 18, fishes for "anything that will bite" along the shoreline of #LakeMichigan on his first trip to Illinois Beach State Park on July 26, 2016, an area that has been hard hit by #erosion. For two centuries, man­made structures that jut into Lake Michigan along the shore north of #Chicago have impeded the natural southward drift of sand — the geological phenomenon that created the #IndianaDunes. In areas without sand blanketing the clay lakebed, Lake Michigan waves have permanently carved out deeper shorelines, creating the conditions for higher and more violent swells, which in turn lead to accelerated erosion. Less than one mile from #LakeShoreDrive — hidden underwater and teeming with life— is #MorganShoal, Chicago's own remains of a great #coralreef and the site of a 1914 #shipwreck. Unknown to many #Chicagoans who pass by the site each day, the shoal was once part of a great series of reefs that extended from #NiagaraFalls. Back when Chicago was south of the equator 425 million years ago, its waters were shallow, tropical and replete with extensive coral, algae and sponge reefs. Over time, rising and falling sea levels exposed and eroded some of the reefs, while burying and compressing others under sediment. @shedd_aquarium Photo @anthonysouffle /Chicago Tribune. Story and short doc now up at www.chicagotribune.com

Jose Montanez celebrates his release from prison and hugs nephew, Aiden Vazquez, 7, and with sisters Carmen Vazquez, center, and Norma Montanez, in Danville, Ill. on Wednesday, July 20, 2016. Cook County prosecutors on Wednesday dropped murder charges against two men who were convicted more than 20 years ago on the police work of a West Side officer whose conduct in murder cases has increasingly come under scrutiny. The announcement by prosecutors came after a harshly worded appeals court ruling last month found that “profoundly alarming acts of misconduct” had led to the convictions of Jose Montanez and Armando Serrano for a 1993 murder. Both were convicted on the testimony of Francisco Vicente, a heroin addict facing four felony charges who allegedly told Detective Reynaldo Guevara that the two men had confessed to killing Rodrigo Vargas as he left his Humboldt Park apartment for work. In 2004, after a series of interviews with students from the Medill Innocence Project, Vicente recanted his testimony, saying Guevara fed him the story. At the newly remodeled Alinea, the “smoke” course includes a molcajete filled with burning palo santo sticks alongside a volcanic stone bearing chicken thigh, chicken­-liver mousse rolled in dehydrated huitlacoche and hoja santa, and a cube of coal­-charred pineapple skewered with a skull pin. Servers whisk by and snuff out the flames with a cloth, releasing a cloud of citrusy­-wood aroma. This is served with a tiny clay saucer bearing a few sips of smoky #mezcal. The theatrical look is hardly coincidental; the Alinea experience today combines a dozen or so courses (always in unexpected forms) with performance art, and service that borders on choreography. "I feel like we're one of the few restaurants in the world that have the responsibility to exude a certain amount of creativity," chef @grant_achatz says. "I feel that we have to perform in a theatrical manner; it has become our personality." Read critic Phil Vettel’s review at www.chicagotribune.com/dining. @thealineagroup Photo by @bzdak

Gunner, a husky, had to have his right ear removed after sustaining a gunshot wound to the head. When Gunner was plucked off the streets near 63rd and Western in Chicago the night of June 30, 2016, his rescuer thought he'd been bitten by another animal. "He was being chased," said Frank Guiliano, a 31­-year­-old South Side resident who regularly trolls some of Chicago's toughest areas looking for lost, sick and injured pets. "But I couldn't tell if it was by another dog or a coyote." It wasn't until the bloodied stray was treated later that night in Mokena that Guiliano and volunteers at PAWS in Tinley Park who helped him realized Gunner had been shot. "He is one lucky dog," said Dr. Jared Settle, veterinarian at Midwest Animal Hospital in Orland Park, where Gunner is now recovering. Gary Middendorf photo @gmiddendorf #husky #animalabuse #dogsofinstagram #oneluckydog

Kourtney Glenn and others gathered for a candlelight vigil for Sandra Bland at Federal Plaza in downtown Chicago on Wednesday, July 13, 2016.  The vigil took place on the one year anniversary of Bland's death. “To be here with folks who really just knew Sandy (from her death) a year ago, with so many people … it’s amazing,” said Geneva Reed-Veal, Bland’s mother, who attended the vigil.
Bland died July 13 last year in a Texas jail. She was in custody there after a confrontational traffic stop, and her death, which authorities ruled a suicide, has since been a part of the conversation around police treatment of black citizens.
People gathered in Federal Plaza under the 53-foot Alexander Calder "Flamingo" sculpture and listened to speeches and songs from multiple participants. Some attendees held distributed signs with an illustrated portrait of Bland, with the words "#SandyStillSpeaks" and "#Black Lives Matter."
“I know for sure my sister’s smiling right now,” said Shavon Bland, 30. “She’s not in the ground. She’s with us every step of the way.”
More than a dozen of Bland’s relatives attended the vigil, some of whom traveled from out of state, Shavon Bland said. Chris Sweda photo. #sandrabland

Larry Schlabach, ground display organizer for The Arthur Fireworks, stands on top of a #fireball #cannon named Vesuvius on June 30, 2016 in #Arthur, a small town in Illinois about 3 hours from Chicago. Schlabach is a former member of the #Amish community turned #pyrotechnic and he spends all year waiting for the annual fiery display. During the town’s traditional celebration, a local crew takes over and replaces fireworks with molten plumes of fire, thick as lava and reaching hundreds of feet into the air. Many members of the Old Order Amish population — about 4,500 strong — watch the glorious pageant at home, from the roofs of sheds, barns and houses. “When you have a stage like that, it really motivates you,” Schlabach said. “I only have a three­ minute window every year...I like to take advantage of it.” @btruetoyou photo #fireworks #fourthofjuly🇺🇸

A woman and child slide down the Picasso statue at Daley Plaza in  Chicago, Thursday, June 23, 2016.
The Picasso, a gift "to the people of Chicago" was from an artist who had never visited--and had shown no previous interest in--the city. Pablo Picasso at age 85 had dominated Western art for more than half a century. He had been approached by William E. Hartmann, senior partner in a Chicago architecture firm. The architect visited Picasso, presenting several gifts (including a Sioux war bonnet and a White Sox blazer) plus a check for $100,000. The result was a forty-two-inch maquette, or model, for a sculpture made of Cor-Ten steel. U.S. Steel in Gary, Indiana, translated the maquette into a piece that weighed 162 tons and rose to a height of 50 feet. It was the first monumental outdoor Picasso in North America.Mayor Richard J. Daley said at the unveiling: "We dedicate this celebrated work this morning with the belief that what is strange to us today will be familiar tomorrow.” Ultimately, the Picasso became a symbol of the city.  Antonio Perez photo #picasso #publicart

Chicago White Sox infielder Tyler Saladino spent 30 excruciating hours at The Red Crow Studio, a tattoo parlor in San Diego, getting this dragon tattooed on his back in memory of his childhood friend, Nikko Maeva, who was killed in a drunk-driving accident in 2008. Tribune sports writer Paul Skrbina writes on chicagotribune.com:
“When the needle first punctured the skin on his back, Saladino wanted to quit.
"It was brutal," he says as he sits in the home dugout at an empty U.S. Cellular Field before a recent game. "But that was the process I needed."
As the pain went in, with each poke that formed each scale of the dragon that covers nearly his entire back, the pain began to find a release. He talked of the good times he shared with Maeva. He cringed. He cried.
Saladino knows the pain never will go all the way away, unconditionally or otherwise.
They weren't together the day Maeva died.
In a strange way, and in a way that makes perfect sense, they haven't been apart since.”
E. Jason Wambsgans photo. #tattoo #whitesox
