The first Bactrian camel born at Lincoln Park Zoo since 1998, of a sex yet to be determined, was born May 9 and weighs 81 lbs. and is 4 feet in height. The two-humped species can grow to 1500 lbs. and 7 feet. The calf is the first successful offspring of the female Nasan, 7, and the male Scooter, 6. All the animals are in the zoo's Antelope Zebra Area, along with two more adult females.
“He is still a bit wobbly on his feet but remains quite strong and is ready to begin meeting the rest of the herd,” said zoo Curator Diane Mulkerin.
Two types of camels survive today, the Bactrian, which inhabits central Asia and has two humps, and the dromedary, which lives in the Middle East and parts of Africa and has one hump. Anthony Souffle @anthonysouffle photo. #lincolnparkzoo #babycamel #twohumps #humpday

A garter snake slithers through a front yard in the 1800 block of West Chase Avenue. Some residents in the Rogers Park neighborhood have been going without mail delivery because the carrier is afraid of snakes. Mark Reynolds, spokesman for the Postal Service's Chicago district, said mail carriers have the right to determine if an environment is unsafe and, if so, they are not forced to deliver mail to that area."In this case, the woman is terrified of snakes. When she saw them she freaked out," he said. "It is irrelevant if the snakes are dangerous or not. Our employees' safety is the utmost priority." Reynolds said a supervisor has been assigned to walk with the carrier from door to door to assess the situation for the next week or so. A resident on the block, said that she has seen the supervisor walking alongside the mail carrier. "When they get to a house, he goes in front of her, and then signals to her with his hand that the coast is clear." Brian Cassella/Chicago Tribune @briancassella #snake #gartersnake #uspostal #snakesinaneighborhood

Illinois State Police search for evidence at the scene of a shooting on the northbound lanes of the Dan Ryan Expressway between 87th and 95th Street early Friday, May 20, 2016, in Chicago. A semi driver was shot and seriously wounded as he drove north on the Dan Ryan Expressway near 95th Street on Thursday night, the second shooting on a Chicago expressway in five days and among more than a dozen this year, state police said.
The 68-year-old driver was struck in the face around 11:45 p.m. and was taken to Advocate Christ Medical Center in Oak Lawn, where he was listed in critical condition, state police said.
The semi was stopped in the middle of the expressway, the driver's side window shattered. Investigators found at least one shell casing at the scene, police said. The shooting was the second on a Chicago expressway in five days.  Early Sunday, a man and a woman were found shot to death inside an SUV on the Kennedy Expressway near Armitage Avenue, according to state police. Their deaths were ruled a murder-suicide.
A week earlier, a 35-year-old man was fatally shot as he rode in a car near Montrose Avenue, according to police.
Chicago and state police could not provide an exact number of people shot on expressways this year, but it is believed to be close to 20.
"Usually I'd be able to tell you how many we've had, but we've lost count," said State Police Sgt. Alexander Diaz. Armando L. Sanchez/Chicago Tribune @mandophotos

A pedestrian and bicyclist pass each other on North Milwaukee Avenue in Chicago on a sunny and beautiful Thursday, May 19, 2016. Jose M. Osorio/Chicago Tribune @josecito2 #chicagocolor #chicagocycling

Crime scene tape is secured to a door with a gun sign on the window at the scene of a shooting in the Logan Square neighborhood on the Northwest Side Thursday, May 19, 2016, in Chicago. Around midnight, in the 2600 block of West North Avenue, a 34-year-old man was wounded when someone in another vehicle pulled up and fired shots, said Officer Ron Gaines, a police spokesman.  The victim's car drove on the sidewalk and crashed into a building. The man was shot in the neck and was taken to Stroger Hospital in fair condition, Gaines said. At  least 20 people were shot over 16 hours in Chicago on Wednesday into early Thursday, including a 12-year-old boy shot while at a restaurant and a couple in their 20s shot in the South Loop during a road rage incident that began on Lake Shore Drive, police said. Armando L. Sanchez/Chicago Tribune @mandophotos

Mary­-Therese Heintzkill, of Chicago, walks with her 1­-year­-old dog, Jett, at Evanston's vanishing dog beach. Experts say heavy snowfall from the winters of 2013 and 2014 plus increased precipitation from El Nino is contributing to rising waters of Lake Michigan. Ray Doerner, the Evanston recreation services manager, said the 15-year­-old dog beach was expected to open April 1 but is now set to open May 28. “Our dog beach has slowly been getting smaller over the past few years and now has some pretty significant damage to it,” he said. “The middle section of our dog beach is completely underwater and essentially gone any day there are high winds or waves.” Doerner said the city dredged sand from the Church Street boat ramp to build a new dog beach on the south side of the ramp. This beach will be around 90 feet long and 20 feet wide versus the old beach, which was about 300 feet long and 75 feet wide, he said. Jose M. Osorio/Chicago Tribune @josecito2 #evanstondogbeach #dogbeach #lakemichigan

Levi Todd fixes his mother's bike at a repair station along the elevated 606 trail near North Ridgeway Avenue in Chicago. June 2016 marks the one­-year anniversary of the renovated trail. The 606, a 2.7­-mile­-long park on abandoned train tracks, opened June 6, 2015. The 14­-foot­-wide multiuse trail along the narrow Bloomingdale Avenue runs through four neighborhoods — Bucktown, Wicker Park, Logan Square and Humboldt Park. It was originally dubbed the Bloomingdale Trail, but the city changed its moniker to The 606 in 2013 — in a nod to Chicago's ZIP code prefix.
